Dark brown haze. No head. Intense vanilla bourbon dark fruits like raisins dried prunes. Sweet heavy body close to syrup. Sharp Alcoholic finish. This is heavy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours cola brown with a thin tan head. Nose is intense vanilla, honey, toffee, bourbon, maple syrup. Flavor is maple syrup, vanilla, caramel, a little coffee (but only a hint). Sweet finish. So syrupy and delicious, with a lowish carbonation and a syrupy and heavy body. This beer has such intense barrel character, its really insane. Very sweet and sticky, really amazing.
Bottle 2014 vintage B written on neck in green. Poured dark brown red with min beige head. Aroma sweet strong oaky barrel vanilla. Light carb med bod. Taste mellow barrel juice, get that char.
Backlog. 2009 bottle ->mini snifter from Churchkey Vintage Vault event. Dark brown with no head. Tons of sweet malt, toffee, molasses, booze. Really good.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with no head. Nose is lots of bourbon and a little vanilla. Taste is a cross between vodka and tequila with a little vanilla and caramel. Lots of alcohol.
Bottle shared by Brad, thanks. Dark brown caramel pour. Super sweet boozy aroma. Sweet taste, booze comes through a little. Really good.
Big massive boozy malty nose. Sweet tequila, bourbon sweet goodness. Really easy to drink and nice malt profile.

2010/2011 bottle, whatever you want to call it. Pours an opaque black with minimal head or lace, but nice oily slickness on the side of the glass. Aroma is big booziness, barrel notes overpowered by roast and molasses, a hint of soy from oxidation. Taste follows, a bit more of the barrel here, with some vanilla and chocolate playing off the brown sugar. A bit past its prime, but still really nice.

Bottle (375 ml) at home. Split 2½ ways. At least 2 years old already, maybe more. Dark reddish-brown with no head or lacing to speak of. Aroma is complex with loads of figs and dark fruits along tobacco, roasted malts, bourbon, vanilla, oak, alcohol and molasses. Taste is moderately acidic so it probably mean that theres something wrong going on in there but its probably an early phase since theres still residual sugars. Theres the same dried fruits and molasses presence than in the aroma with the booze being more present and the bourbon/vanilla/oak trio also being upfront. Medium body. Dead flat. A bit vinous mouthfeel. Fruity and hot finish. Not what I expected (except for the lack of carbonation) but its tasty, rather complex and I would even say quite enjoyable (in small portions).

A great brandy aged strong ale. Pours a deep black with a tan head. Smells of lots of vanilla, caramel and booze. Taste is sharp, with lots of brandy all around, and a good amount a vanilla. A bit of caramel and red apples as well. Had on tap at the Winchester Goose.
Hooo, this is strong.  Boozy.  Like drinking wood. Whiskey. If you like barrel aged beers, this is for you. Hints of vanilla. Tasted at Elijah Ps Monsters of Beer
Backlog. Vanilla, tobacco, dried fruits in the aroma. Palate is slick, some yeasty notes, strong hint of bourbon, well balanced, fantastic.

375ml bottle at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki. Dark copper brown color with small beige head. Malty aroma, dark dried fruits, plums, figs, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, wood, alcohol. Sweet and light bitter taste like aroma with alcohol addition. Medium oily body with soft to flat carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2015 On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours muddy reddish brown with minimal head. Aroma is big rich earthy malts, heavy sweet barrel-aged notes dominate the finish. Taste is huge boozy malt, rich lightly roasty caramel flavor, full mouthfeel, big oaky finish with lots of alcohol heat. Still balanced, given all the malt here. Very approachable for a barleywine, not excessive in any dimension, just big. Outstanding beer.   

UPDATE: 2015 Brandy barrel version, on tap @ Chucks CD 3 months later. Taste is similar to the original, brandy seems to add another layer to the caramel candy sweetness of this beer, still retains balance of the original and lacks the heavy bourbon notes of the bourbon version - the brandy barrels seem to meld with the case beer a bit better. Not hot, even at 12.5%, likely due all the big flavor here. Great beer.

Draft. Pours what is looking like a murky dark brown. Dissipating head. Im gonna give the appearance the benefit of the doubt. Big. Complex. Full of character. Warmth with a mild booziness. Caramel, toffee, dark fruit, brown sugar..all that malty barley wine goodness. Strong and good. Initial sweetness gets balanced out. Great balance. Lighter full body. Superb.

Bottle shared from 2009 375ml. Omfg nuff said. Pours almost black with oily slickness no head at all. The aroma is amazing dark fruits, oak, caramel, toffee, alcohol, earth goodness very complex. The flavor is ten times more powerful amazing goodness out of s bottle everything that you can smell is in the flavor personified. Overall one of the highest ratings I have given.

Pours deep black with no head. Nose is dark fruits and carsmel. Aromas are roasted malts, coffee, caramel, dark fruits, with whisky notes. Creamy texture, low carbonation. Long alcoholic and sweet-roasty finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A great barleywine...and barleywines seem to meld to me...2009 release...too 10 easy

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2016 Bottle at Antwaerps Bierhuyske. Very thin, off-white head only retaining around the edges, deep reddish bronze colour, very dark but still transparent. Very complex, beguiling barley wine bouquet, of the kind I could sniff for hours; tawny port, banana liqueur, black olives, tons of vanilla tannins, milk chocolate, raisins soaked in brown rhum, coconut, marzipan, liquorice touch, candied orange, walnuts, cinnamon, mocha ice cream, red wine, candied dates. Intense candied sweetness in the onset but perfectly in place, bit syrupy, amaretto, sugary but in a refined, exotic kind of way, basic sourish accent, very soft, velvety, creamy mouthfeel, caramelly and lightly nutty undertone becoming deliciously chocolatey in the end, viscous and vinous as any big barley wine should be, peppery alcohol accent in the finish but only adding warmth and depth, orange liqueur, Pineau de Charentes, wonderfully bittersweet with oaky drought, long and very complex. Very expensive but fantastic, especially if you like deep barley wines the way I do.  It doesnt get a whole lot better than this...  Epic!

Rating #950. On tap at Toronado. Dark brown color with small tan ring. Aroma is burnt sugar, a strong brandy barrel in there. Taste is sweet, lots of vanilla, more brandy booze, malts, quite intense. Is this the first half of Deliverance? Probably. Not bad, but just heavy and strong. The brandy barrel might be too strong in here.

375ml bottle enjoyed @ home, 2009 vintage. Pours very dark brown with no head. Aroma is lots of alcohol, oak, vanilla, leather. tobacco, caramel and molasses. Flavour is medium sweet, light bitter and boozy. Full bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation. The booziness mellows as it warms up. Finish is caramel, vanilla, oak and warming alcohol.
Cloudy dark brown with tiny tan head. Aroma of vanilla and dark fruits. Some leathery hops. Medium alcohol and some dark rum character. Great beer.

Bottle shared at the Cotteridge convention, 24/01/2015. With thanks to SarkyNortherner. Aroma is nice vanilla oak, caramel, cherry, alcohol. Viscous mahogany brown caramel coloured pour. Flavour is composed of sweet oak vanilla, caramel ,warming alcohol, praline and tangy cherry. Palate is velvety full and lovely. Cracker.
On tap at the Red Hot. Pours dark brown. Creamy tan head. Scent is pretty boozy. Taste is pretty strong alcohol. Caramel, vanilla, molasses. Very smooth. Very tasty.

Bottle; pours dark brown with a thin tan ring of head; sweet aroma of caramel, dark fruits, vanilla, and booze; taste is sweet with dark fruits, caramel, and vanilla with hints of malt; finish is bitter and slightly dry with some alcohol warming; very nice barley wine
Black with white head. Draft at Tiger Tiger in San Diego. A lip puckering bastard. Massive booze flavor. Smells like wine. Tastes like prune juice. I appreciate it but couldn't drink much of it

On tap at Jons Philly BW Lost Abbey tap take over with Tomme Arther himself. Pours murky dark brown with a half finger tan head with nice legging. Aroma is brandy, dark fruits, vanilla, dates, butterscotch, caramel, sweet malts, molasses, woody notes, and amazingly almost no noticeable cohol. Taste is brandy, dark fruits, woody notes, vanilla, molasses, caramel sweet malts, butterscotch, and maybe just a little booze has it warms. Has a medium-full body with a creamy, chewy, slightly oily mouthfeel and mostly sweet, slightly warming, long, lingering finish. Overall, a amazing world class barley wine that is just as good as the bourbon barrel aged Angels Share.
Weird beer. Smells amazing. Looks amazing. But its too sweet. The complexity it incredible, its just not enjoyable to me.

Dark mahogany brown, decent ringed wet sandy head. Rich, sweet, burnt wine and noteably boozy. Sultry initial taste; lean boozy, soft woody, blackcurrant soy and . Fades quickly from the richness, although its a decent dunt of a mouthfeel from a soft carbonation. Finishes lean, meaty sweet malt and a rainbow of barrell sweetness. 

Bottle, 2009 Vintage fae CGArvieuk, Whole Lotta Rosie Tasting
Bottle at Craigs. Probably 2009. Pours dark brown with no head. Aromas of chocolate, nuts, sherry, brandy. Taste is dungy, light chocolate, red fruit, brandy. Dry finish.
A fantastic brandy like aroma. Flavor of complex malts balanced by mild brown sugar. Pour with medium carbonation and mild fruits lingers through malty complexity.

Unique and unique, for a barley wine. Combo of barley wine and Belgian strong. Wine like flavor if elderberries. Hops of earthy English barley wine. Some oak and cigar box in there. Well balance with all the unique flavors.
Awesome barrel aged beer. Raisin, date, vanilla aromas. Review from memory.

Draught at neighborhood. Pours a diseased black blood brown. Unreal aroma of brandy, wood, vanilla, caramel / maple, plum. Taste is sweet. Palate is chewy, sticky, soft. I'd turn into a cannibal if a person were marinated in this.

Draft at Barrel Republic. Pours murky brown with a thin, off white head. Tastes like smooth strong alcohol, lightly astringent, very strong raisin, dried dark fruits, earthy malt, light licorice. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like raisins, booze, astringent, dark fruits, woody.

2009 bottle, big brandy wine aroma with some intense fruity and dark oak nose. Flavor of sweet alcohol heat and plenty of different malts. Nit too bad on carbonation considering. Definitely for the angels.
Bottle @ Fermentoren. Slightly hazy, oily brown. lots of chocolate, caramel, bourbon, in both taste and aroma.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2015 Bottle at home. Pours deep brown, nose is oak, vanilla, chocolate, toffee, taste is similar, dark fruit, rich and boozy.

Bottle at craigs, from 2009. Pours deep brown, nose is wood, vanilla, chocolate,  taste is similar, sweet.

Poured a muddy dark brown with little bit of head and lots of lacing. Lots of vanilla and caramel, lots of brandy barrel but well balanced. Overall it was an awesome beer, the barrel aging was done perfectly and the 14% abv was well hidden

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2016 At almost 15% we don?t expect any lacing or head retention, and we get none. Smells like brandy, butterscotch and raisins. Tastes identical to that with a buttery, rich finish. A nice winter beer but not one that you have several of.

Brandy brarrel version. Love the raisens and oak that really steer This beer. Lots of burnt cInnamon as well. Comparing this to the burbon barrel. The burbon may be my favorite of the two. The burbon may be a bit more smooth.

Nez puissant sur le caramel, la vanille et le bois. Beaux arômes de bourbon. Bouche ample et onctueuse, explosion de vanille, sur fond de bois et dépices. Viennent ensuite de subtiles arômes de caramel, réglisse, noisette, chocolat... Finale longue et puissante douce et amère sur le chocolat et la vanille.
Bottle cotteridge pissup. Black ok head. Dark fruits wood molasses in aroma and taste some alcohol good dark malts. Nice chewy body. V good.

Taster at The Beer Store, SF. Pours chestnut with a foamy tan head. Nose is molasses, vanilla, caramel, dark dried fruit, and brandy. Flavour is dark roasted malts, charred oak, brandy, raisin, fig, leafy decay, and huge vanilla and caramel. Outstanding American strong ale. Or is this a barleywine? Either way fantastic.

Bottle Share at The Cotteridge Convention 24/1/15

Poured a Deep dark Brown almost black with tiny tan head covering. 

Aroma of spice, raisens, dark fruits, hints of rum, barley, forest fruit and malt. A very proud punchy Barley Wine.

Bottle. Slightly bitter, malt, rich caramel, aged character... too much tannine aftertaste for me. Something isnt rightly combined, maybe the malt and oak/brandy? Nice booze and full flavours. Should retry on draught.

Bottle split at the Cotteridge Convention, big thanks to Sarky for dropping this off even though he couldnt stay, 24/01/15.
Extremely dark mahogany brown with little in the way of a covering.
Nose is rich caramel, toffee, dark fruits, spice, malts, raisens, sultanas.
Taste comprises rum and raisen, toffee, spice, dark fruit rinds, dates.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, lightly warming booze in the close.
Solid BW.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Appearance- Deep dark brown with little to no head or lacing.
Aroma- sweet dark fruits, alcohol, malts, port wine, bourbon.
Flavor- heavy sweet with vanilla, oak, bourbon, raisins, plums, caramely, nice and thick, almost like a good balsamic.

Bottle shared @ home from Saveur-Biere.com - Color: dark black beer with no carbonation and small brown head. Smell: roasted malt, young barrel and bourbon vanilla notes. Taste: nice oily sensation very smooth and great! Malt domination with vanilla balance. Very amazing and with barrel finish. Very well balanced. Aftertaste: malt roasted and chocolate with vanilla and barrel.

Barley wine bottle share on 1/31. Very smooth, tasty stuff. Pours out a nice mahogany, , lots of sweetness, brown sugar, molasses. Silky, syrupy mouth feel, tons of warmth. deserving of the (mostly) high praise.

Bottle share at Cotteridge Wines. Cheers Sarky. Dark brown, small tan head. Aroma is boozy, sweet vanilla, background pine or mint. Body is medium, slightly foamy, low carbonation. Taste is sweet toffee, some meaty flavours going on, tangy alcohol reminding me of spirits like Aftershock, a little salty Decent sipping beer.
Bottle share. Cotteridge Beano. Hazy brown. Tan head. Big, woody, dark, oaky malts. Sweet. Some dry. Rich, a bit boozy, and a bit chewy. Lovely this.

Bottle at Cotteridge Wines convention; hazy dark brown pour with a thin light tan head, quite a robust malts aroma with hint of roast, taste has chocolate, caramel, some dark fruits and a hint of vanilla.
Fantastisk öl! Aromen av bounty med chokladen och cocos. Smaken balanserad av sötma beska chocklad och cocos. Fin fyllighet

I presume this is the regular LA share, was on tap at the madmex so I presume they are not good enough for the real aged thing. Black and foamy, quite alarming volatile sweet aroma. Big whisky alky impacy. go figger. Over the top on the taste buds, wew. Warming all over. A mans beer fer sure eheheh. If you want to drink shots of this give it a 5.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Draft at Moriartys. Opaque brown/black body with some off-white foam. Strong barrel flavors meeting a tremendously full mix of full-bodied dark roasted malts. Charcoal grill. Bitter chocolate malt. Espresso. Very dark red stone fruit and berries. Slick black liquorice. Have had this brew in very guises for many years. Rating this one as the "generic" version now found only on draft. Love it!

Butelka 375ml.
OCZY : piwo jest mętne o ciemnobrązowym kolorze. Piana jest malutka i szybko znika. 

NOS : od razu wyczuwam nuty podobne do whisky czy bourbon. Do tego czekolada i bakalie. Czekolada i whisky są tak intensywne, że przypominają czekoladkę nadzianą alkoholem. Niesamowicie przyjemny i głęboki aromat. 

USTA : brak nasycenia. Piwo jest tłuste i mocno gęste. 
Smak jest bardzo intensywny i kolonizuje wszystkie kubki smakowe. Słodki o nutach czekolady, suszonych fig, śliwek i orzechów. Do tego alkohol rozgrzewa i szczypie. Nie da się zrobić dużego łyka. Trzeba go powoli siorpać bo nie da rady inaczej. Ogólnie dominuje whisky. 

ODCZUCIA : fantastyczne i wymagające. Mocny smak whisky świetnie łączy się z czekolada i suszonymi owocami. Smak jest super intensywny i sprawia niesamowita przyjemność. Polecam na koniec dnia, najlepiej przy kominku (którego chciałbym teraz mieć). Fantastyczny trunek. 

OCENA : 
smak : 9/10
pijalność : 2/10
styl : +2
Dark brown to black body with a medium beige head. Aroma is malty, dark fruit, chocolate. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter. Full body, thick texture, nice long finish.

On tap at POUR. Bourbon, oak, vanilla, rum raisin, figs, dates, rich ripe macerated fruits, tobacco, and glycerin. Wonderfully rich aroma. Dark brown-black opaque with thin light tan lacing head. Medium-heavy body, short of chewy, with medium-high carbonation. Big, big beer - huge flavors that mimic the aromas - bourbon and rum raisin. Sweet but not cloying, a little woody and tannic but not big distractions. Huge bourbon finish and after, mildly bitter. Big warming.

Dark mahogany color, rum raisin, port, oak, brown sugar, molasses, chocolatey nose. The mouth is totally flat, sweet malty mouth, with lots of port, brown sugar and raisins with a touch of oak. Warming portion finish. Cant believe how flat this is and Tomme Aurther actually said it (2008 version) was an English BW. Losses points just for that.

12.7 oz, corked and caged, 12.5% abv, vintage 2014A. This is somewhat of an oddity in that I had an upgraded version on tap in Colorado some years ago, and am only now wrapping back around to the original. Nose is heavy brandy with a little port, oily even in the nose, tons of barrel character overwhelming just about everything else, but man is it good! [If there is a serious flaw here, its the way overstayed time in barrels, which could mask delicate nuance or even a bad recipe.  I guess that is its calling card, though, its reason for being, and its a good one.] Caramel and vanilla, spirited booze. Pours tawny but ends up essentially black in the glass at full volume, briefest of heads. Taste sweet with caramel, toffee, strong and very punchy red fruit, firm fruit esters, wood/oak barrel character, brandy, vanilla, light toast and excellent rounding tannins sugary alcohol and gentle burning fusels. Full body oily, boozy, but not obese or undrinkable; its heavy but not the heaviest Ive had this year ... seems to have earned the stature somehow. Very malty.  There are some wonderful unfurling notes of tobacco leaf, and rum-raisin sugars before and after the flambé. Light-medium bitterness and a touch of yeast deep under the alcohol. Smooth and superb sipper, really exemplary traditional barleywine flavors married to strong, complex brandy/port overtones from the long barrel aging; its worth showing to someone to demonstrate just how varied beer can be, and its worth the high price point if you get to take the bottle home and enjoy it all by yourself.Just so much here!  Shouldve sent a poet.

12/17/014. 12.7 oz bottle. Not sure of the year, but labels says 12.5% ABV. Murky dark brown with basically no head. Sweet oaky aromas with caramel and dried fruit. Similar, sticky sweet flavors, hints of vanilla with a boozy warm finish.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a smallish light tan head on there. Nose has some caramel up front with a lot of dark fruits in there. Taste is slightly sweet and very warming, and seems to have just a bit of wood and Belgian yeast to it. I like.
On tap at Beercraft. Pours a dark brown color without any head. Low carbonation. Very noticeable alcohol booziness that overpowers a little.

On tap at The Hopping Pig in San Diego. Pours a slightly hazy brown with a thin off white head. Aroma is oaky bourbon toffee malt. Really nice. Flavor is sweet bitter with lots of oak and caramel. Some vanilla. Really smooth and nice. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle (12.7oz $18): Murky brown with little head. Sweet fig smell. Taste... Sweet. followed by some warming. Not worth the cost IMO.

Bottle. 2012 vintage. Dark brown pour with a bit of head that disappears, looks like a fine liquor after the fact. Aroma is loads bourbon, vanilla, raisins, caramel, and oak. Taste is toffee, caramel, burnt sugar, rum soaked raisins, followed by some light bitterness, oak, with a boozy spirit forward finish, mouthfeel is medium, carbonation is light but certainly not flat as some have suggested. Really nice barley wine, surprisingly boozy given I sat on this for two years.
Tap, brown pour, tan head, nose is caramel, taste is more mild than the grand cru, cherries, sweet

375ml bottle. Burgundy colour, thin off white head. Lovely vanilla, oak chip and deep caramel nose, some vinous fruit action in there. Big boozy dark fruit and vanilla taste, lovely whiskey notes coming through, lovely and oaky, some spice, little bit of heat. More vanilla and deep caramel, filling it out nicely. Lovely figs, caramel and oak to finish. Lacking carb perhaps. Body is pretty good though. Well rounded, right amount of booziness, really very good.

Bottle pour split, enjoyed side by side with the bourbon aged vintage version. Thanks T for making this happen! Pours a reddish black with a fading tan head. Strong rich chocolate and sweet dark fruit. Sweet like a cookie flavor. Smooth flavor with a dark, more tart finish.  Medium carb. A little boozy but overall drinks smooth. What a good beer this is.

2009 vintage. Very well done barley wine. Pours dark maroon with good head and lacing. Light sourness, lots of mash malt here. Some citrus, some booze. Brandy is light and well-integrated. Light bitter-sour finish. Bottle pour at Churchkeys 5th anniversary - thanks to Jackl for a taste of this.

For it's ABV, not super boozy. Chocolates, tart cherry. Really nice back of the tongue flavor stay

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
At surf side tap room oceanside. Malty aroma, wee cherry flavor and smell. Pretty thick, nice head. Booze finish.

Complex. Pours liquid brown lava. Flavor explosion with each sip as well as a designer flavor twist. Woody and chocolately with a slight hint of a Belgian quad. This is wonderfully decadent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12.7fl oz bottle @El Lúpulo Feroz, Oviedo. 09-02-2014.
In short: smooth robust sweet ale.
Pours very dark with little tan head. Some head retention and lacing. Wood, liquor, caramel aromas. Medium body, soft carbonation, oily texture. Taste is smooth, wood, liquor, caramel, vanilla flavours. Creamy mouthfeel. Balanced and very enjoyable.
Bottle @ cafe sara, Oslo. Sugar roasted figs meets sourdough bread. Deep oak flavor. The alcohol comes through. Has an untypical bitter finish which is nice. Nice beer, just dont buy it in Norway ;)

Bottle from no idea when. Pours dark brown with a small, off white head. Aroma has lots of bourbon, caramel malts, butter, fat sugary sweetness. Not too much though. Taste is not as sweet, but still lots of caramel, licorice, filled chocolates, port wine, some candy. Full body, medium carb. Lovely. Just my style of barley wine.
Murky brown without foam, this has a boozy aroma with fruit, caramel, raisins, and toffee flavors that melt in your mouth. Alcohol just adds to the sweet finish. Beautiful.

Bottle. This is the stuff. Pours a dark brown, almost black, off white thin head. Aromas of bourbon, caramel malt, brown sugar, coffee, booze. Taste is very bourbon up front, roasted coffee, slight caramel malt, booze, yeast, earthyness.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2014 2012 vintage.   Pours a a dark cola brown with almost no head and little lacing. Aroma is wonderful with nutty, caramel scent along with plums and figs. Also get some toasted coconut and vanilla. Taste is very similar with molasses sweetness and some chocolate syrup and a bit of roastiness. Get those nutty flavors with the dark fruits and the toasted coconut. Just a bit of alcohol. Finishes with some sweetness. Mouthfeel was oily and medium bodied with low carbonation. Delicious. Best barleywine Ive had.

2013 bottle. Pours a fairly clear dark amber brown with a few bubbles but no head. Slick, oily lacing. Nose and taste are virtually identical. Malt, Coffee, chocolate syrup, coconut, vanilla, caramel, prune/raisin, a little roast and just the faint bit of alcohol. A soft, smooth mouthfeel, medium body. Not much carbonation and just a little alcohol warmth. Balance is incredible with just the right amount of everything. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled vertical: 2008 vintage is 375 ml, 2009 vintage is 750 ml. Pours a translucent dark brown/caramel color, nearly still (after head quickly faded). Aroma is dark fruit and booze, with notes of plums, dark cherries and prune. Flavor is malty, sweet caramel, and dark fruit with overall delicious sour tang. A slight port complexity. From notes 1/23/10 (Geist Dark Lord tasting)

Bottle at Falling Rock Tap House in Denver. Pours pitch black and inky with no head whatsoever. Aroma is sweet brandy and some light anise, molasses, more sweet sugar. Flavor follows with thick brandy and molasses flavors, some light oakiness, burnt caramel, very sweet. Nearly no carbonation in this one, and on the sweet side which cuts through the thickness and puts things a bit on the cloying side. Big bodied though. I definitely liked the bourbon version better than this one, but would be nice on a winter day.
This Barleywine is amazing. Slightly toasted, with oak, Vanilla, toffee and bodied. I drink This Beer at Lost Abbey and was a unique experiente.

10 brandy barrel draft from Alla Spina. Pours a murky maroon with no head. Aroma of sherry, cardboard, chocolate, tootsie roll, butterscotch. Definitely infected but delicious. Nice tartness. Chocolate, red grape, sherry

On my third and final flight at Stones Liberty Station outlet in San Diego on 17th March 2014. Came black with a thinning tanned head. Rich and deep malty molasses rule the nose and taste, this is one heavy brew with plenty going on to occupy your senses. A great send off from a lovely setting, slow walk back to the hotel took a bit longer because of this beer!

Tap. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is strong vanilla, bourbon, sweet molasses, extremely complex. Taste is exceptional!! Great bourbon flavors, smoooooth, rich, absolutely Delish!!!! Damn, this is great!

Poured from tap to glass. Dark hue with off white head . Huge aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak, caramel, molasses, toffee, soy, prunes, leather, tobacco. Mouthfeel is fantastic with full body and soft carbonation. Taste is sweet initially with woody tannins in the following and ethanol finish. Overall...wow!

Dark brown pour with reddish tinge and no head whatsoever. Aroma of malts, caramel, raisins, toffee and vanilla. Taste of caramel malts, prunes, figs, toffee, vanilla and slight oak barrels. Slightly fruity. Full bodied, no carbonation. Very tasty beer, a little carbonation would have upped the score, felt like I was drinking a beer I had left on the counter overnight!

Bottle, 2009 edition. Pours dark brown with no head. Tobacco sauce, wood, dark raisins, molasses, leather, caramel, prunes. Full body, heavy sweet with some bitterness, acidity, tannins and alcohol to challenge it. Heavy, I find this a bit more rough than the bourbon version, and here is another cognac barrel that doesnt really win me. I miss the sweet backbone that the bourbon has, this ends a bit raw and boozy.

375ml corked bottle from ??? (not sure - somewhere in CHI), labelled as "bourbon 2013", and cellar aged 10 months. Served at cellar temperature into my New Holland tulip. Pours a darker-than-cola color with an off-whte head leaving nice streaks of lace. Aroma has pure bourbony vanilla. On further inspection, chocolate and nuts and caramel show up. Lovely bourbon-heavy, though. Taste is of sweet vanilla, caramel, chocolate, some dark fruit, nuts ... and more sweet vanilla bourbon. Some alcohol presence, but super smooooooth. Medium bodied. Finishes mostly sweet - even a bit cloying. Different than most barleys; love the bourbon presence with the chocolate/caramel. Excellent brew!

(Bottle, 2010 vintage) Dark brown colour, with a hint of ruby when seen through light. Almost flat, with just a few quickly disappearing bubbles. Malty, fruity, vinous nose with notes of caramel, oak wood, dried fruit, raisins, vanilla, port wine and a touch of brandy. Malty, fruity taste with caramel, dried fruit, raisins in brandy, vanilla, oak wood, port wine and a vinous finish with fiery alcohol and a touch of tannin acidity. Full body, despite the lack of carbonation, its actually quite massive. Fairly sweet, with fiery alcohol in the finish. Low bitterness. Different, but quite lovely. (Rating # 6000)
2009 release. The aroma is very fruity with plum, raisin and caramel. The taste is similar and the fruityness is really to much for me. Unbalanced. Low carbonation.

Flaska från 2009. 75cl. (Parallellt mot bourbon 2010, ej blint). Privatimport från Brill & Co. Tunn bourbondoft. Vattnig. Helt flat (?). Hur fasen kan den vara så vattning? Hade inte Lost Abbey problem med infektion alldeles nyss?...på det stora hela är den god.

Bottle: 2008 vintage: Served in a Duvel glass:
Flat deep dark brown to black beer.
Aromas of soya, toast, oak, light bourbon, brown sugars, light vinous and a sprinkle of alcohol tints.
Flavours of alcohol, oak, spices, some fruit like prunes and grapes, light tart (infection?), dried leaves, light sticky, malts, light toffee, light yeast, some brown sugars, bitters and light vinous.
Aftertaste is a mix of spices, malts, prunes, oak, toffee, vinous tones and some toast.

No carbo, watery mouthfeel, full bodied and a light oily texture.
Strange, spicy, light tart, flat... But not bad!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: APR 15, 2014 Bottle / 2011: Thanks, Mike. Opaque, deep brown. No head, no carbonation at all. Nothing. Still, oily, no movement. Aroma is awesome; almost like a Utopias junior. Notes of brandy soaked raisin bran bread, sweet cherries, sticky toffee, caramel candy & brown sugar, with a light dusting of cocoa dust. Taste is not on the same level. Theres an apparent tartness, doesnt taste like actual infection (vinegar or overly sour) but more just like an evolution of the brandy character. Tart red grapes & tangy raisins, sweet cherries coated in brown sugar & brandy, mild wet wood, & a butter toffee finish. Starts a little tart, finishes mostly sweet. The brandy is apparent, flavorful, but smooth & never hot. Mouth feel is lacking, due to lack of carbonation. This has potential to be amazing, based on the aroma. The flavor of this bottle was lacking, though, as was the carbonation.

12.7oz bottle, 2008 vintage. Thanks to DanielCoor for sharing. Opaque brown color. No head or lace. Yeast sediment visible in the body. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of creamy texture. Little to no carbonation. Pretty much completely flat. Light heat in the finish. Light sweet taste, more drying in the end. Moderate bitter. Flavor is pretty nice... Some chocolate, light spice, big barrel aroma. Getting the brandy flavors... Hints of apple, light cinnamon spice. Dark fruit. Solid, interesting stuff. Very nice big complex barelly flavor to it.

2008 vintage. Deep black color with no head. Aroma is heavy on the bourbon and caramel. Flavor is more nuanced, with notes of chocolate, plum, bourbon, and subtle hoppiness. 



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours deep dark murky black with the shortest lived fizzy beige head Ive ever witnessed. The aroma is BIG chocolate, toffee, caramel, dark fruits, oak, vanilla, and alcohol. The flavour is sweet, chocolate, toffee, caramel, anise, dark fruits, oak, vanilla, light sourness. Oak in the finish, semi dry mouth feel, a little chewy. Expensive, but Id likely buy this again.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein rötlichoranges Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch intensiv süß malzig, Karamell, holzig, alkoholisch. Geschmack angenehm malzig fruchtig, wärmend, Karamell, alkoholisch.
A very unique barley wine. Vinous and sherry aromas. Flavors are sour cherries, sweet raisins, boozy heat at the end. Excellent.
Fresh on tap. Big vanilla aroma carries through to the taste; needed to be reminded that this was brandy barrel aged.
Easily one of the top 5 barley wines Ive ever had. Sweet, boozy and smooth just like I was hoping. Wish I bought more than one bottle and hope I can get my hands on another one day.

375 ml bottle thanks to my Secret Santa, jckp64. Pours burgundy with no head. Aroma is just ok, something seems off about it. Sour cherry, paper, candy and musty oak. Taste is awful. Overpowering sweet and sour fruit, medicine, and vomit. This has to be an infected bottle. No pop from the cork, no head, and its undrinkable. Ill re-rate if I get a better bottle later.
Pours a hazy brown with a small tan head. Smells of oak, vanilla, bourbon, candied malt. Taste is sweet, moderately bitter, strong vanilla oak, some burn present - toffee, brown sugar.

Dark brown with no head. Strong bourbon and liquor aromas. No carbonation, sticky, loads of molasses and a strong alcoholic whisky presence is felt troughout the palate. Finishes very sweet, alcoholic with some dark fruits. Intense, sticky and barely drinkable. Must make exquisite sauce tough...

Botella de 37.5 cl en el lúpulo, en el momento el 12-02-2014. Color negro con reflejos cobrizos oscuros y espuma beige poco persistente. Cuerpo intenso con gran sensación alcohólica. Sabores bastantes dulces con toques de maderas al final algo secos y ligeramente amargos. Alucinante barley wine de 12.5 vol. Muy buena sin duda alguna
Bottle. Pours a nice dark color. Aroma of barrel, booze, and yummy. Taste is smooth, vanilla, barrel, whiskey. Not too much alcohol. This is good.

Bottle share thanks to beechner224. Pours a deep dark mahogany color with light tan head. Big boozy, barrel, caramel, dark fruity, with more boozy bourbon aroma. A lot of caramel, toffee, and bourbon in the flavor. Tastes pretty high boost.

Rated on 3-17-2010 (Corked and caged bottle) This beer pours a large very fizzy tan head that mostly diminishes, opaque dark brown body, and one ring of lacing. The aroma is caramel malt, chocolate, oak, sweet, dark fruits, vanilla, and alcohol. The taste is sweet, caramel malt, chocolate, dark fruits, alcohol, and has a semi-dry finish. The palate is tingly and this beer is medium bodied. Overall, WOW what a great tasting beer to drink and rate! This is a sipping beer at 12% ABV and not a beer to be taken lightly. It has a sensational flavor, worth trying and a beer I would drink again.

2008 -12.5% bottle. Tucked this away for a while, popped for the Sup... Big Game. Very flat, but sure, it is old and corked/caged. Sediment layer is crazy thick and fully bricked. That 12.5% is a kick in the pants and rides over the taste and aftertaste. Beautiful malt, great barrel aging, but still bit of harshness to the sip after ~5+ years. Hard to rate as, with the high ABV and lack of carb, tastes like a sweet, low alcohol bourbon - or an odd port. While the aging I gave it was overkill, it made it more interesting.
Dark brown colour. Caramel, dark fruit, raisin, vanilla aroma and full bodied taste.

Pours dark brown with beige head. Big aroma kicks in the nose with malts and dried fruits, some caramel. Taste is also BIG, it is a bit sweet, but with a huge body. Fruity, bitter, sour, then alcohol kicks in but I like that it is not too overwhelming. One bottle on 2-3 persons is ok, for one it would be a struggle.
A Lost Abbey Christmas ... this was a gift to be able to find. At the high price point - a bit under value, but excellent none the less.
2010 375ml bottle pours a hazy brown with zero head. Big bourbon aroma. Bourbon vanilla caramel taste. Great beer.

375 ml bottle, 2008 vintage, gifted to me by OldMrCrow -- thanks! After struggling with the cork, it eventually released with a nice, resounding "pop," and the contents poured complete with bubbles into a tulip. I won the carbonation lottery on this one! Clear, dark brown pour with half a finger of offwhite head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is pretty big on soy sauce, raisin, oxidation, but still maintains some of its former identity with notes of caramel, plum, and toffee. Taste: soy sauce and raisin, cola, moderately sweet. Full body, lovely texture, nice, soft carbonation. Overall: Ive had this beer fresh once or twice before, but neglected to rate it because I was sure Id drink it again and again (and also because I was probably too drunk to put down any coherent notes). Deliverance is one of my all time favorites, and one of these nights I should have a small tasting with Serpents Stout, Angels Share, and Deliverance. At any rate, Im going to be a bit generous with the rating here, based on past experiences and what I recall. Next time I have this Ill be sure to append the rating and do a proper averaging. It was great to try this one with some serious age on it, but based on this Id say 6 years is a bit long for this one. Based on this bottle alone: 7/4/7/4/15 = 3.7. Based on memory alone: 9/4/9/4/17 = 4.3. Ill split the difference.

Shared a bottle on Christmas eve. Not a big fan of barley wines but this beer truly blew me away. Full body, strong aroma hits you straight in the face, yet so smooth and velvety. One of the best beers I tried this year!
Wow...AMAzing beer. Super full taste and aromas of wall nut, raisins and malt.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2014 
2013 bottle, 12,5 % ABV


Look: Pours with large 2 thumb thick brown, creamy, slightly reddish foam. Medium retention, some of the foam forms a compact thin layer on the top for the whole ride. Carbonation visible. Color is dark brown/black, murky, cant see through, some yeast visible. Pours with thick/syrupy body, fair amount of lacing.


Smell: Dark, burned caramel, dark/milk chocolate, bourbon, oak, then some sweetness, dark fruit, raisins, vanilla. Holy shit intense - filled the room the second it was opened. Rich, oily, hint of coconut, fat overall. 


Taste: Bourbon, oak, vanilla. Rich complex sweet taste of different types of chocolate, burned caramel. Fat play between bourbon and rich malt character - lovely. Aftertaste consists of malty bitterness and bourbon, maybe slightly sour. Cant detect any hop flavour/aroma. Theres some alcohol in finish. 


Mouthfeel: Full, creamy. Med-low carbonation - expected for such a fat boy. There is some warming from the alcohol.


Overall: Smooth and sweet ride for a 12,5 % ABV bourbon and malt bomb. Aging did some splendid work on it. Was a feast, but holy shit - half gone and I was drunk. Not your typical Sunday stroll.
From a 375 cl bottle shared at home on Christmas eve. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of brandy Flavors of plum, oak, vanilla and caramel. Soft and viscous mouthfeel. Boozy finish.

Vintage 2010

A: pours brown with excellent clarity. Absolutely no evidence of carbonation. Cork removed with no "pop".

S: Minerals. Brett? Very confusing. Ive had previous versions, and this isnt adding up.

T: Yup, brett and/or something. Christ, this is super infected. Absolutely horrible. Maybe some of the original beer in there, but mostly, shite.

M: Thin. Flat.

O: This is one of the worst beers Ive ever had. I took two sips and poured the rest. Absolutely horrid. Ive become more and more leery of all LA beers. Tomme - take care of the issue.

Serving type: bottle

05-17-2011

Serving: 375 ml. bottle from Julios Liquors. Dark, ruddy pour with pretty much no carbonation thus no head. Heavy raisin nose. Slight sour flavor with lots of oxidized notes. Lots of paper. This one is past its prime. Shame.

pours deep opaque amber, not quite black, with a thin tan head. nose of biscuit, caramel, toffee, and bourbon. taste follows and the bourbon accentuates rather than overwhelms. body is solid. many thanks to tleaver33 for the bottle.
Holy crap, what a beer! Great aroma, great appearance, great everything, one of the better beers Ive ever had.
Had at Denver Rare Beer Tasting V, had some nice bourbon and caramel notes, quite flat.

Served in a small snifter.
Feel: excellent except for some high ABV harshness; near full body; very good, ir relatively high, carbonation.
Taste: Sweet up front; Rich and complex; dark roasted malts dominate the bitter/sweet aftertaste. 
O: Outstanding. Improved with warming and more warming.

Ooh, 1000th rating (of the beer, not mine). Even better because it was free -- just too much for some girls at the bar who bailed for something lighter. The most obviously barrel aged beer Ive had, which is saying something. Huge caramel, vanilla and oak over dark malty goodness.

Bottle at Cardinal tasting october. Dark brown color, tan head.Aroma of cherry, caramel malt, raisins and bourbon. Taste of nuts, prune, sweet malt and a aloholic touch. Weak barrel touch. Again a nice one from JP
Complex aroma of dried fruits, dates, prunes, cigar box etc. Similarly complex taste that keep developing in the mouth. Port and fine sherry. Perhaps with a hint of alcohol crudeness.

Fra flaske på Cardinaltreff sep-13, etter det offisielle programmet ("fra gribbebordet": en lekkerbisken for de som er begeistret for store mengder karamell og vanillje. Flytende godteri, og sånn sett en passende avslutning på kvelden. Må prøves i mer objektiv tilstand.
A very good beer but a bit thinner in the mouthfeel than I expected and maybe a little heavy on the bourbon. But overall very solid.

Cask at Great British Beer Festival 2013. Poured a dark ruby colour with a medium, dense beige head. Aroma of caramel, alcohol soaked dark fruits and molasses. Flavours of raisons, dates, peppery spice and vanilla. Leaves with burnt sugar, brandy, hop resin and oak.

Whooo mamma! Ive been hearing good things about this beer and finally know why. Pours black with no head what so ever; typical of Lost Abbey beers. Aromas of big alcohol, caramel, vanilla, and some roast. Flavors of sweet vanilla, caramel, oak, and roast. This is a great beer.

This beer takes Barley wines up to the next level. Wonderful malt, bourbon, followed by vanilla nose and flavors. Very rich and smooth. Blended with perfection. Every year has its differences. Cant make out the date, but, its probably 2012. Bourbon Barrel. 12.5%

Nose rich caramel, brown sugar, whiskey, dark fruit. taste oak and fantastic sweetness of caramel, cola, vanilla, whiskey. Whiskey accents the caramel with perfect presentation. Surprisingly clean finish not cloying and alcohol keeps it light on the tongue. very impressive and first from this brewery as well

Pours a deep dark burnt mahogany color with a huge thick gaseous smokey khaki foam. The nose is rich and inviting with notes of sweet brown sugar, caramel,toasted pecans, boozy vanilla, coconut. The palate follows with a great sweetness that is encompassed by rich round boozy complexity. The finish is not sticky but lends to the earthy leather spectrum with a hint of bitterness and a long boozy linger.

Bottle. Pours a vary dark brown with fine tan head. Aroma is sweet, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and alcohol. Flavor is sweet, mild bourbon, vanilla, caramel, very sweet throughout. Fairly mild considering barrel time. Soft carbonation, medium body, and a very smooth texture. Sweet mild, bourbon beer. Overall a bit of a disappointment.

Poured from a bottle purchased a year ago into a small snifter with zero carbonation.
Aroma is straight up whiskey love!
Taste of heavy dark fruit with a touch of licorice?
A thick syrup of boozy love which makes the year of wait so worth it.
Made my top 10 list....

Bottle - 2009, thanks bul11zeye. Opened with some trepidation. Flat as a board, of course. Pour is murky mahogany, no head, no lacing. Aroma is.... NOT infected. Whew. caramel, toffee, dried fruits, A&J brandy, vanilla. Medium sweet, little bitterness, perhaps just a faint note of tartness, but that may be my imagination. Full body, creamy mouthfeel. Brandy burn. Minimal astringence. Somewhat oxidized. Good, not great, BA BW.
Bottle, Pours brown with little head. Aroma is sweet, dried fruit, sherry notes and oak. Flavour is sherry, cherries, slightly acidic and a warming sensation from the alcohol.

The nose is definitely heavy with alcool. Leather, wood and vanilla in the mouth along with a hint of chocolate and spicy maltiness. Something you want to pair with a salty and caramel fowarded single malt.

On tap at Capitol Beer and Taproom, marshmallow, chocolate aroma with slight bourbon notes. Slightly boozy palate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 bottle drank 2013 July. Infected I think. Pours brown with sediment and totally still. Aroma is acetic sour, fruity, booze, and oxidation. Taste is light vingear sour, not super sweet, mild bitter, wood, lots of tannins, sour cherry. Feel is woody and drying while kind of silken. Other than probably being infected it was still somewhat enjoyable. Its not barley wine like at all but rather more of a belgian stout...if it was carbonated at all.

375ml bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with a thin tan head. Light carbonation. Strong bourbon aroma and taste. Taste of bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel, warming alcohol, raisin. I liked this more than I thought I would. Good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 375ml.
Pours very dark brown. No head. Aroma is of caramel, sugar, fruits, alcohol, oak, roasted malt. Taste is of caramel, molasses, dark fruits, roasted malt, oak, warming alcohol. Palate: Full bodied. Sligthly sticky. Overall: Very good. Boozy. Complex.

bottle shared by minderminder, thanks bro! pours unclear dark brown with a very small beige head, no retention. cognac, rum - candied, brandied and boozy ripened fruits, chocolate and raisins, vanilla and spices, hint of burnt caramel, spices, tad mineral and earthy. low carbonation, medium body - oily and almost sticky, demerara is cleansed by bold grassy-resinous hops for a still smooth finish without being harsh. good bw.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. 2009 edition. Have been putting this off for a long time as I was almost certain this bottle would be infected going off the reviews since I received this bottle in a trade. Pours ugly. Murky ass brown with no head at all. Not even any bubbles. Surprisingly there is no hint of infection on the nose...but Ive been fooled before. Lots of peppered spice, sweet vanilla, milk chocolate, woodyness, oak, grass. Surprisingly not infected at all. Extremely pleased to be able to finally have a good one. Brandy like sweetness in the taste with some pepper on the finish. Very cocoa like with some heavy oaked notes and grass/earthy undertones. Quite spice driven with a fair kick on the back end of the palate. Almost no carbonation but it doesnt matter a great deal. Quite slick and oily. The spices really linger on the back end of the palate and you get this stewed raisiny sweetness coming through. Good stuff. Probably a good thing I kept it this long as it is still quite boozy. Nice

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours oily brown black with no head or lacing, zero carbonation. Immediate aroma of raisins, damp wood, slightly sour cherries and brandy. Touch of vanilla. Taste is upfront caramel sweetness, backed by a bunch of fresh dark fruits and raisins. Wood and light vanilla bean with a slight peppery finish. Interesting beer.

Brown caramel colored... Aroma of vanilla, raisins... Flavor is bourbon, raisins, dates, candi sugar, vanilla, tobacco... Really complex beer... Hint of booze on the finish... Amazing

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2013 Dark brown with a rich brown head. Aroma of oak, vanilla and dark dried fruit. Amazing intense flavors of sweet malt, wood, toffee, vanilla, dates and burnt sugar. Viscous, smooth and very rich with alcohol balancing the sweet malt with just the right amount of dryness. I am a believer!

2009 Brandy aged. Totally flat, but that's ok. Boozy spirits and aged oaky nose. Palate is truly great: smooth brandy, hearty flavor profile with lengthy depth, delicious. Much better than I expected.

2010 vintage on tap at the Brick Store Sweet Sixteen party. The aroma is intense sour cherries, molasses, vanilla, and caramel. The flavor is very sweet, with a significant sourness through the finish. Medium body, acidic, and thin. Overall, this is an interestingly sour beer. The initial aroma is a little unexpected, but it grows on you.

Bottle share at Ale Alpharetta. I love big barrel aged barleywines, but this one fell completely flat. Literally. Pour is dark brown/amber that showed no signs of carbonation. Smell is sweet booze of the brandy variety, malty, almost smell the syrup thickness. Taste is caramel boozy syrup with known brandy. I would think that carbonation would have certainly enhanced the experience, but I still dont think would have been great. Who knows, but the bottle I had was no bueno.

May 19, 2013 - 2010 bottle from Everetts.  Dark brown pour with almost no head that stained the glass.  Aroma was a rich brandy, caramel, vanilla, spice and wood.  Taste was woody, caramel, wine and mild tartness in the finish.

Very enjoyable. Pours dark brown with no head at all, pretty flat looking. Smell is burnt sugar, oak, very earthy. Taste is big brown sugar, oak, and toffee notes with a touch of vanilla aftertaste and some heat. Much better than sleeping with shaggy by not having such an overpowered burning brown sugar taste. Great stuff.
Deep dark brown with no head. Aroma of oak and dark fruit. Taste of alcohol raisins and brandy. Medium-bodied.

375ml c&c bottle.  Should have drank fresh. Tart, lactic, flavor of citrus.  Dissapointment.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a murky dark brown, almost black. Aroma of oak and vanilla.  Taste is tart, dark fruit, prunes, dates and bitter chocolate. Not very good, I would not age this in the future.

October 28th, 2011 - I have a vague memory of enjoying Angels Share long, long ago, before I put any of my reviews and scribbling onto Ratebeer. It was introduced as an example of the paragon of brewing. I tasted it, and immediately recognized it for what it was: a foil. Lost Abbeys Angels Share is everything that everyday beer isnt. If this is one path of evolution for beer, it begs the question of what other evolutionary branches might exist. The Angels Share drinker becomes a craft beer drinker at the instant of the taste. Thats a profound beer. In October, 2011 I had the opportunity to shake hands with this old friend again. The aroma is thick and almost oily, intensely perfumed with fig and concentrated raisin. The caramelized, bubbling sugar of a roasted sweet potato is also present, and laced (or barbed) with the sharpness of copious booze. The taste re-affirms the oiliness of this brew, cut nicely by the assertive alcohol level, like a sharks fin across the oceans surface. Intense, dry, and like a barley wine, Im drunk on both the flavor and beer after only half a glass. The dry character is contrasted against a caramel bourbon burn and residual sweetness, verifying Lost Abbeys proud barrel aging process. One danger present with these kinds of beers is a cloying intensity. I appreciate heavy flavored beers, but even heavy-weights can be too heavy. The beauty of the craft is to nuzzle that line as closely as possible without overstepping it, and I would argue that the Angels Share does that with a certain ballet-like grace. Where most beers strain to straddle that line, Angels Share dances up to it, balancing intensity and balance - a true craft brewing feat. Now, I wonder what this would taste like after a little aging...
Bottle. Infected. Fuck. Just terrible. I was really looking forward to this, never again.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Unfortunately received a bottle that was completely flat as many others did. Flavor was still fantastic. Boozy and rich. Would love to try it again with a better bottle. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

200th rate! Thought this great beer was appropriate. On draft @ Mohawk Bend in LA. Very dark brown pour w/ minimal carbonation. Everything I want in a big beer- bourbon, dark fruit, vanilla, caramel, some slight bitterness. A wonderful beer!

On tap at Memphis Taproom, 2010 Vintage. Pours very deep dark brown color with a light toffee colored ring that laces down the glass. Big rich aroma of figs, dark toasted chocolate malt, bourbon, oak, and vanilla. The taste is sweet and a little cloying from the dark roasted malt and bourbon. Blended nicely with dark fruit, dark chocolate, vanilla, roasted caramel, oak, and bourbon that is very dominating on the palette. Taste is complex, deep, and overall very rich. Mouthfeel is thick and somewhat syrupy, nice gentle velvetycarbonation.

Rating #3800, a special beer here. Deep dark brown coloured body with absolutely no head or movement at all - soy sauce coloured, interesting. Aroma of alcohol, figs, pit fruits, raisins, nuts, complex spices and a bit of sour grapes, but not much - definitely some meat smells as well. Medium-bodied; Strong soy and Worcestershire sauce flavour at first with some apples, pit fruits and roasted malt flavour taste behind, but this is definitely strong, pungent and unflattering. Aftertaste shows a little fruits, a lot of earth and even more soy sauce flavour with meat added. Overall, not a very good beer - there is no carbonation, a bit of oaky and liqour flavours, but the Worcestershire and soy sauce notes are a bit too potent for me. Add this to the price and you can definitely pass this one up. A bad rating for #3800, I wish I would have had something a bit better in my stash. I sampled this 37,5 cL split bottle purchased from Healthy Spirits in San Francisco, California on 05-March-2012 for US$15.99 sampled at home in Washington on 11-February-2013.

As a whiskey lover, i was excited to try this. You can smell the whiskey as soon as it's poured. Has a strong whiskey flavor with toasted coconut, cocoa, and vanilla flavors. Feels very alcoholic. Definitely a long whiskey finish. I loved it, but I probably couldn't drink much.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2015 Bottiglia 2008. Impenetrabile color nero-marrone pressocché privo di schiuma; aroma favolosamente intenso con sentori di malto, caramello, uvetta, zenzero, frutti di bosco e legno da botte. In bocca è dolciastra e vinosa come un Porto con una nota acidula piuttosto ben bilanciata, frutta candita, mou, cioccolato, ciliegie sotto spirito e un finale più asciutto, amarognolo e liquoroso dove si sente la botte e compaiono note di luppolo e Brandy. Corpo pieno, struttura oleosa e spessa, carbonazione assente. Più un liquore che una birra, un particolarissimo nettare da meditazione. Da provare assolutamente.

Bottle via trade with Chris - thanks! Not much pressure when the cork comes out, and it pours with no head. Tastes a little flat too. Dammit. Awesome aroma of oak and dark fruit. Taste is very good, but falls well short of my hopes. Slight booziness as well. Gotta keep it in perspective, this is really good in the grand scheme, but I really hoped for more and Id never pay $22 for a 12 oz bottle of this again.

0.375l corked bottle. Oh my! Been saving this for some time now, but think its about to pop it. Have to admit that it does not start of too good. Had to struggle to remove the cork, and I did not even get a tiny pop when it finally came off. No head what so ever indicates that the carbonation is most likely long gone John, but the beer itself is a deep dark dark brown thing - impossible to look through. The aroma however is most definitely not disappointing: it has lots of sweet caramel, dark sticky glazed fruits, a somewhat strange acidic lactal touch that I guess comes from the barrels, some licorice, dark acidic wood and just all in all its quite a interesting and nice aroma, but Im a bit more concerned now regarding the taste. Its time to taste the thing! Oh no.. Clearly off :( Oh my thats a big big bummer. Acetone and a sourness that just screams I-N-F-E-C-T-E-D. No, oh my thats a shame indeed. Its not completetely ruined, but this is not how this fantastic beer should taste. Still, I get some tones of a fantastic concentrated and sharp barley wine. Caramel, sour wood and Asian spices. This is something I have to get a fresh bottle of and rate again. I really feel that it deserves that. This bottle however, it does not deserve a destiny down my kitchen sink, so Im going to make a concentrated vinegar out of this. Could be interesting? 09.11.2012

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2013 2008. Smells wonderful. So much goodness but Im gonna go straight up qualities cuz the overeem/silva fight is about to drop. Plum, vanilla, dull orange, the fight is brought to you by Corn Nuts. Hints of alc, orange, wood splints, silky brown sugar creamy thing, mild molasses, early sort of choco. More but I gotta move on here. Taste is great! Cream, alc, bourbon and lots, balloons, caramel, blackness, lots of brown sugar lightly burnt, a terrible review. Very very good. Ultra chuggable. I am thankful for the opportunity to drink this.

Thanks, Kaare my giant neibour. 2008 drank in 2013....  Deep brown body with zero cap not one single bubble was produced at pour. Why aroma i want to drink. Aroma burnt sugar, red wine, wallnuts, spice, vannilla. Fuck this is good. Thick feel but way to flat. Taste is the same. Creamy smooth...... wine, spice,  fuck zero trace of 12% i like this beer so very much. I love this beer..... not quit the legend but so dam fine.

375ml bottle:  2009 vintage:  This one pours an inky, opaque brown color.  It is absolutely still:  no carbonation at all.  Nice nose to it.  I definitely get a whiff of the brandy.  A little musty aroma.  Definitely some dark fruits in there, with a little plum on top.  Lots of caramel malts.  Very nice taste.  Thick caramel, some of the brandy, Lots of mingled dark fruits, some coffee notes.  Oak notes also.  It doesnt suffer at all from the lack of carbonation.  Very Nice!

Bottle courtesy of watson1977, thanks Kerry! pours dense date syrup with no carbonation, aroma is rich and complex with tons of dried fruit, leather, rum, lots of blackstrap molasses, date, and rum, finishes fairly dry,  very close to a fine port, delicious!

On tap @ Encinitas Ale House - brandy barrel. Dark red-brown color, cloudy. No head. Aromas: alcohol, booze, medium sweet, with chocolate, booze and raisin retronasal. Flavor is medium sweet, some sourness, raisin. Strong alcohol feel, medium bodied. Finishes very boozy. Like drinking hard liquor with bubbles. Not for me.

Brandy indeed! Pours dark brown with no head. The initial flavor is bourbon-infused maltiness. What holds your interest are the lingering notes of vanilla. The ABV is ever present in the aroma and throughout sipping; my only criticism is that it can be overwhelming at times. I'd prefer a lesser ABV or a more-masked ABV. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wonderful! My husband and I just opened this 2010 bottle after a tough day taking inventory of our beers. We decided on Angels Share because it was the right size for just the two of us. Pours dark reddish burgandy. Smallest rim of head, and very light lacing. Wonderful, heady intense aroma including bourbon, brandy, raisins, other fruits. Taste is magnificient with brandy, raisins, and chocolate. Intense sense of warmth. My husband says it tastes like an alcoholic chocolate bar. Very smooth.

375 ml bottle. 2010 vintage.
Pours dark red color with no head. Aroma is quite intense with ripe fruits, plums and raisins mostly, some yeast and wooden notes followed by mild caramel, rose hip, ripe berries and alcohol. Flavor of sour and still a bit sweet ripe fruits, ripe dark berries, some caramel malts and oak. Faint vanilla notes on the aftertaste. CO2 very low. Mild sourish and somewhat sweet sticky palate, ripe fruity finish. Excellent.
4246

37,5 cl bottle @ home. Brandy 2010, 11,5%
Aroma is sweetish with ripe fruits, some brandy, pear esthers and oaky notes. Flavour is rather strong and rich with pear esthers, oaky notes, raisins, brandy, porto, ripe fruits and warming alcohol. More round and a lot better than the bourbon version. A porto‐like slow sipper.

2009 Bottle courtesy of dcschiller.  Poured a brown color with no head at all.  The cork did not even "pop" when opened.  Big bourbon and dried fruit smell.  Taste is sweet leather taste with tons of toffee.  There is vanilla and raisins.  No carbonation at all, but thats ok. There is an after taste of copper.  Very interesting beer.
Definite burbon aroma. Pours flat with zero carbonation. Highly alcoholic brew, with hints of raisin.

Tämä viskihöyryistä nimensä saanut olut on väriltään tumman ruskea ja erittäin samea. Sen vaahto on niukka ja vaalean beige. Tuoksussa selkeintä on bourbon. Sen lisäksi löytyy vaniljaa (bourbon), rusinaa, soijakastiketta, kaakaota, viljaista mallasta ja siirappia. Alun bourbon hyökyaallon jälkeen tuoksusta tosiaan löytyy monenmoista. Tosin kaakaon löytämiseen pitää jo käyttää hieman mielikuvitusta. Makukin on ensituntumalta makea ja bourbonmainen. Loppujen lopuksi analysoitaessa maku on melkoista karkkia ja ei ollenkaan huonossa mielessä. Mieleeni pyörähtää jostain Kuhnhenn 4th Dementia. Kyllä - tämä muistuttaa jossain mielessä kyseistä olutta. Maussakin on kaakaota ja yllätyksenä jopa suklaata. Olut on kohtalaisen vähähiilihappoinen ja rungoltaan tuhtia tavaraa. Hyvin erikoinen barleywine, joka ei taatusti jätä kylmäksi.

13/11 A 0.375 l (12.7 fl. oz) bottle courtesy of lutonm, thanks for giving away! 12.5% ABV, I guess its 2011 bottle, released in 2012. It poured pitch black body with tiny brown head. Bourbon, chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Very strong flavor, sweetish, with lots of chocolate, raisins, other dried fruits and wood (with some tobacco) of course. Smooth, yet alcoholic, definitely full bodied. Warming, sweeter finish which was quite prolonged as well. Alcohol was not hidden nor any attempts were intended I guess, for its really a wonderful brew this way it is. From joining ratebeer I was thrilled by the story of "Angels share" and it did not fail.

Bottled 375ml. -Courtesy of luttonm(thanks!), shared with Marko and heavy. Deep brown (almost black) coloured, small to medium sized beige head, wood and alcohol in the nose. Roasted malt, bitter chocolate and dried fruits with distinct notes of whiskey (barrels). Warming alcohol and touch of vanilla in the finish. Great one.

2008 vintage 750ml
A vigorous pour produces a viscous black liquid with a handful of bubbles that dissipate almost instantly. Smells of oaky vanilla with a boozy edge. Hints of chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit and tobacco round out the nose quite nicely. The flavor is sweet like an aged barleywine. Sweet sugar and caramel mixed with some vinous notes. A touch of ethanol and a nice flavor of dark fruits, grapes, chocolate, and tobacco. Medium to thick body with a sweet syrupy mouthfeel and not a lick of carbonation. Ive sat on this bottle for quite some time fearing the disappointment that would ensue with the inevitable flat bottle. The lack of carbonation ruins the mouthfeel on this beer and makes a sweet beer even stickier. This smells wonderful! Its too bad I couldnt get a proper sample of this beer because Ill bet its really great!
UPDATED: JUL 16, 2013 Aroma of toffee, caramel, and chocolate.  Pours red brown with no head or carbonation of any kind. Tastes of caramel, cherry cordial, chocolate and toffee.  Sweet desert beer.

I debated this rating but I think its justified.  Pours a dead flat brown color.  Looks like flat cola.  Aroma is one of the most vile putrid conglomerations Ive ever smelled.  Smells EXACTLY like hot garbage.  Just straight up nose of rotting summertime dumpster.  Taste isnt quite as bad as the aroma with some slight redeeming qualities of oak and chocolate that just tries to hide hot garbags.  I cant believe how much is wrong with this flat, infected, swill.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Ok so, this is overly sweet completely flat and infected. It reminds me of the simpsons episode where burns has a lot of diseases countering each other, the infection makes the over sweetness caused by the flatness bearable.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and snifter served with a deep mahogany hue, a thin layer of off white, bubbly head foam that diminished quickly to a narrow ring, and showed a syrupy film on the glass instead of any lacing. The aroma was sweet, dark fruit, vinous, barrel/cask scent, and a dose of vanilla. Rich and full bodied, softly carbonated, moderately bitter, with texture that was syrupy but no too sticky, and appropriate alcohol warmth to suit the occasion. Quite impressive!.

Bottle from Ølbutikken. Pours black with small tan head. Aroma is port, cherry, dark fruit, vanilla, brown sugar, caramel malt, melasses, chocolate. Very sweet! Taste is equally sweet with just a hint of bitterness to balance it up. Strong alcohol and port finish that lasts quite some time. Rich, creamy body with low carbonation. Not as great as the bourbon barrel edition but definitely one of the best barley wines Ive had!

Bottle at home. 2010 vintage. Pour is deep, murky, cola with no head. Looks like this one is completely flat. Cherry cola, light cocoa, whiskey, figs, dark fruits, caramel, and brown sugar in the aroma. Taste is cloyingly sweet, dark fruits, raisins, brown sugar, slightly boozy, roast, slightly acidic and sour, with caramelized sugars and an alcoholic burn on the finish. Syrupy mouthfeel with absolutely no sign of carbonation. Way too sweet for me and the absence of carbonation is really off-putting. Not a very enjoyable experience.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 16.99 Bottle ordered from internet. Pours a dark caramel with deep red hues with very little head. Aromas of wood, oak, whiskey, and a light hint of vanilla. Flavors of whiskey which hits over the top of all other flavors, caramel, wood/oak, and slight brown sugar. The alcohol burns a little through the nose and on the palate and going down. Medium sweet with a little to no aftertaste. The whiskey notes really make this unpleasent as I really dislike its taste. The notes of whiskey are just to strong for my taste. The alcohol is subdued decently.

Bottle from some store around three years ago (2009). Aroma of sheer brandy and barleywine-type bright malt and almost non-existent hops. Flavor was much of the same, and the palate left much to be desired, as these 10+% ABV beers by Lost Abbey have little to no carbonation. Still, this was one of those Utopia-type offerings...a straight sipper. Pretty good beer, but could be much better. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 bottle drank Oct. 12.  Flat almost no carbonation.  Very nice nose of sweet caramel malts, toffee, and some oak.  Pretty one dimensional and a bit too sweet.  Not as good as others I remember, especially the barrel aged versions.
161111: clear brown color with a little foam. Sweet aroma. Very acidic taste may be infected. practice.
Infected as hell.  Been saving this awhile and was super super excited to finally try it but alas it was infected.

Thanks to pushkinwow for this. 2008. Pours a brownish amber with no carbonation whatsoever. Aroma is sweet caramel, slightly floral, oak and dark fruit. Taste is a pleasure, the only thing that holds back is the lack of carbonation.

Bottle, thanks to Leighton at THE Barley Wine Tasting, August 2012. It pours very dark brown, with pretty much no head. The nose is roasty, caramel, toffee, light treacle, chewy malt, oak and alcohol. The taste is sticky toffee, caramel, light spice, oak, some alcohol warmth, light vanilla, treacle and boozy fruit cake. Full body and low, prickly carbonation. Flavoursome, but perhaps a bit too sweet for me. The bourbon version is a better, more balanced beer in my opinion. An enjoyable beer nonetheless.

2008 vintage. From a corked 750ml brown bottle. Brownish red in colour, unclear, not much head, a few large soapy white bubbles that dont last. Nose is sweet with brown sugar and sweet alcohol. Taste has some cocoa notes, brown sugar lots of sweetness. Ends a bit drier, some lasting heat from the alcohol. Medium body, under carbonated. Quite rich and sweet, I fell I would have enjoyed this more had there been some more carbonation to cut through the sweetness.

37.5cl bottle @ Sorbon, Bromma. 2008 vintage, huge thanks to Afram! Pitch black, opaque, small off-white to beige head that disappears almost instantly. Smell malts, slightly coffee, lightly roasty, slightly hops, lightly sour, oak, liquor (brandy?). Taste malts, roasted malts, some caramel, a lot of (brandy) barrel-aged, lightly sourish, slight hints of coffee, oak. Very dry texture, sticky on the teeth, full body, medium carbo.

Draft, poured black with a reddish hugh,  light brown head with fine bubbles and good lacing.  Sweet to the nose, vanilla, malts with woody notes.  Flavors of malt, vanilla and alcohol with a dry alcohol finish.

Bottle @ home. 2010 vintage. No pop or carbonation release upon opening. Deep reddish brown appearance with no head. Rich dark grape, thick tannin, leather, fig, plum, caramel, toffee, somewhat boozy, vanilla, oaky aroma. Very low carbonation. Very rich dark grape, plum, raisin, vanilla, sugar caramel, toffee, huge tannin, oak flavor. Huge tannin, thick grape flavor but the carbonation is completely missing and its a pity. Quite boozy and overly rich but shows potential. The bourbon version was so much better for me.

a dark brown colored beer, with a dark beige head. The aroma of whisky, vanilla, fruits and alcohol. The taste of whisky, wood, vanilla fruits and notes of alcohol. The aftertaste is sweet burny alcohol.

Bottle 2008. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, vanilla, bourbon, oak, caramel, dried fruits. Flavour is sweet, caramel, malt, bourbon oak, sugar, licorice, alcohol, vanilla, dried fruits. Full body. nice beer.

This tasted more like a wine than beer, so take this with a grain of salt as its not what I look for in a beer. Had to try it as Ive had some good barrel aged brews before but this poured with no carbonation of note and minor if any head, taste flat but the aroma was infused with the aroma of brandy and fruit (fruit cake is the first thing I could think of), nice warmth after the sip and a lingering pleasant taste, I wish it had more carbonation and less sweetness...

The last draft from a sixtel, the coke colored head took a long time to settle (e.g.. I tasted a carbonated one).  Pours a deep brown thats nearly opaque.  The aroma is dominated by barrel and brandy with some raisins, vanilla, and cola.  The flavor profile is extremely complex, sweet, and savory.  It sits heavy on the palate, but its luxurious, not sticky.  Fit for the angels, indeed.

Pours a murky dark Brown with virtually no head but looks silky smooth as it enters the glass. Smells of Browned butter, dark fruits, brandy, dark rum, and biscuits. the taste is great, Dark candied fruits soaked in brandy on top of sweet biscuity cake. Chocolate, caramel, vanilla and some nuttiness rounds it all out Mouthfeel was wonderful to me, almost no carbonation but so silky smooth! So what if it is not what you expected, not every beer has to be carbonated as much. Maybe it could have had more but I can not understand people getting so up in arms about it. Not sure about all the controversy surrounding this one but I think LA did a fantastic job as usual. Very full bodied beautiful Beer!!

Very dark brown with red tinge and minimal tan head.  Aroma brown sugar, malt, wood, dark fruit.  Full body with warming alcohol presence that is pleasant rather than harsh.  Complex flavors of caramel, vanilla, wood, raisins.  A little tannic and port-like.  Sweet but not overly so and a bit of bitterness.  Could have been too warm and sweet but its not.  Really good.

On tap. Maybe it is because i am from WI or it is that I am in SD, but this one raped the bourbon one royally.

@Basunen: komplex smak. Tydlig vinös, mycket soya och lite svårdrucken. Lite för komplex och över allt.

37,5cl bottle at Brewdog Camden. It pours a dark ruby/brown-ish color with no head at all. Good lacing on the side of the glass. Aroma is stunning and resembles porto wine and whiskey. Notes of toasted cocoa beans, smoke, figs and prunes. Malt and caramel. Taste is complex, an explosion of flavours. Mostly sweet with a lingering tartness in the finish, it showcases dark fruits, figs plums and reisins, with vanilla, wood and porto wine. Whiskey and cocoa notes again. Body is oily with almost non existent carbonation, just a tad sparkling. Overall, lacks in carbonation for sure, but with a flavor profile so complex and similar to port wine and liqueur, I have to admit it didnt bother me at all. Oustanding.

2011 Angels Share Brandy. Pours a dark brown color with a muddled haziness. Huge prune aroma on the nose with hints of cherry and barrel. Taste is sweet up front with a strong sour/tartness. Finishes with a tannin on your tongue. The palate has a slick flat body with a moderately astringent finish. Very much like sipping on a fine brandy or port wine. Very strong flavors of prunes, wine grapes, and oak with secondary flavors of vanilla, caramel, and  cherry. Very fine sipper.
Bottle.  Cherry, caramel malt, and bourbon aroma.  Chestnut color with no head.  Sweet prune malt and light alcohol flavor.  Smooth as silk.  Excellent.

Bottle: vintage 2008
Pours burgundy-black and clear....just darkness...no head.
Aroma is bourbon and dark wine.
Flavour is more of the same with strong oak notes.....vanilla, very strong alcohol appearance.
Dark, wonderful...powerful.

dedicated to Jay Baer, RIP brother.... (fuck cancer). 2010 bottle pour is jet black. barely a trace of carbonation minus a light ring around the Lost Abbey stemmed glass. very complex on the nose. tons of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, molasses, raisin, and oak. very smooth and very rich. very smooth. a nice rich butterscotch flavor through out that really dominates. nice smooth bourbon and vanilla kick in with a dark fruit and it of heat in the finish. fairly thick body but quite smooth. lots of alcohol burn that almost makes you think there is some bubbles. if this has bubbles, it would be a solid A, maybe even an A+. amazing flavors through out. Reviewed on: 08-30-2010

Bottle 2008. Vinous, chocolate, dark fruit, oaky vanilla aroma. Deep garnet tinted chestnut with no head. Vinous dark fruit, bourbon, vanilla, tannic oak, and alcohol flavor. Full boozy body with a dry finish. Big boozy beer. Im glad I had several people to share the bottle.
Dense dark mahogany hue. Thick date and plum aroma. Rich fruity palate , dates , bourbon and vanilla, residual figgy jam flavor. A sipper.

Bottle. Almost black pour, little head. fruit over challenging, roiling body. hot, rich. This beer changed everything for me the first time I had it, but there are a lot of other beers pushing this now. Very good beer.

Bottle I got in trade with Michael-pollack, Thanks Michael..2009 Bottle ..Nose is wood, brandy, brown sugar, glazed donuts, vanilla, alcohol, sweetness..Taste is vanilla, oak, brandy, brown sugar, frosting, caramel malt , Palate is sweet and bold

375 mL bottle.  First thing to note: theres a piece of cork floating in the bottle, but the bottles cork is still intact?  Hmm.  Anyway, pours a very dark brown to black with no head.  Soy, brown sugar, very ripe raisin and red grape aromas.  Flavors of brown sugar, very strong red wine, soy.  Takes a bit of time to come together, but its pretty good.  Wouldnt mind a bit of carbonation, though.

Bottle to snifter (thanks Bob). Looks good; dark with thin lacing. Smells PUNGENT! Bourbon and vanilla. Tastes pretty good too; much like it smells. Mouthfeel is decent, but will likely improve with age (along with the taste). Solid, but Id like to let it sit for a year or two and revisit it.

2011 bottle (neck says 2010 brandy)  Pours brown with no head...bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Aroma has candied fruits and red wine, fig...tart...boozy.  flavor is very winey and tart atop oaky fig.  Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is winey and dry...warming.  woulc try again...not sure this held up well at all.

With tremendous thanks to Blankboy. Appearance: Red wine, teeny tiny small brown head. Aroma: Stewed fruits, plums, raisins, brandy, I can anticipate a sticky mouthfeel by the aroma, red wine, oak, a little nutty chocolate. Flavour: Tart!!! Brandy and oak, big red wine flavour, malty, sloes, peppery, a little nutty, very sour, just a whirlwind of flavours, crab apples and cranberry. Fantastic. Thanks Paul.

My 3000th rating.  375ml bottle from Crossroads Beer & Wine, Burlington, MA. Marked "Vintage 2011" on the neck, and stated ABV 12.5%. A flat black pour, like a strong coffee, with no head and an oily texture; the aroma hits as soon as the cork is popped - rich fruit cake and vintage port wine; the taste is equally impressive - soused raisins, burnt toffee, oaky red wine, and sweet vanilla; the finish is dry and moreish and masks the alcohol very well. More a super-strong English Strong Ale than a Barley Wine in my opinion - but very nice indeed, regardless of the category.

2010 on bottle: Pours a dark cola brown with a thin tan head that diminishes quickly. Sweet aroma is brandy with hints of oak, vanilla, and fruity apple. Flavor is oaky with a mild brandy presence and vanilla in the finish. Has a creamy texture and well balanced hiding the alcohol very well. Easy drinking and delicious!

straight apple brandy aroma. Pours a very dark plum color with no head. Tons of apple flavor up front with some finishing malt. Also a sweetness of sorts and a little alcohol burn. But other than that no hint of the almost 12%

Bottle 375ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours deep brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, vanilla, coconut, bourbon, oak and caramel. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft.

Sampled at an esbls tasting.  After much discussion it was determined that this was the version.  Such an interesting beer.  This combines a sour, woody effects, fruot, wine, vanilla, and big malts.  Tasty and beyond.

Great barley wine from tap. Beautiful brown color with light brown around the edges. Aroma of brandy, raisins/plums, and malt. The taste had a pleasant sourness to complement to dark fruit sweetness and alcohol.  Maybe just a slight burnt oak taste too. No carbonation to me, very crisp tasting.

Bottle. Prunes, plums, and wine in the nose. Dark, wine or thick cola color.
Sourish, off-putting flavors. This is not in the proper condition. Thin body, right for an aged sour beer, but not a barley wine. Something is disappointingly off with this one.
