Flat bottle, 2009 I think. Dark brown. Tangy fruit nose, dried fruits and grape. Fruity, sour flavor, tangy, plums, vanilla,oak. Enjoyable enough but certainly not what its supposed to be.
This is what happens with a bottle of portwine hooks up with a bottle of beer. Smooth, crisp, and strong flavors of raisina and caramel. This beer is to be savored.
Ya I got one the bad bottles, flat as can be, the aroma was chocolatey and full. the flavour was less then desired and it just was overall not very enjoyable. maybe worth trying a better one

bottle from capones. pours jet black mostly flat with some head . nose of sherry, bourbon. first sip is huge malt with whiskey boozyness, vanilla, port and sherry. finish [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ with strange mouth feek. overated.

Had this the first time a year ago, and it was great.
Now i read through some of the lowest scores, and cant believe that so many bottles could be infected.
And yes, I got another one. Was looking forward for a nice #200, but this is shait.
Sour and not pleasant at all. 
For a beer that costs this much, and is so nice when done right, this is simply not good enough. 
Such a shame.
It poured a dark brown color with a small head. The aroma was of chocolate, alcohol, fruit and raisins. The taste was sour, caramel, berries, alcohol and dark fruits. A very good Barley Wine.

375ml Bottle for rating #4000:   Listed as 12.5%, vintage not marked.   Deep caramel, dirty, sediment collects at the bottom of my snifter, no head, no lacing.   This is as still as it gets folks!   Rich whiskey nose, tons of vanilla, caramel, toffee, toasted coconut, and candied nuts.   On first sip its very warming.   Nearly alcoholic, but the huge maltiness makes up for it.   Body and mouthfeel are thick and well rounded, despite the lack of carbonation.   The 12.5% ABV is warming, but not burning.   Strong graham cracker, vanilla, bourbon, toasted marshmallow, coconut, and rich caramel malts linger.   This is one of those beers that isnt really different from what many try and accomplish, but it is one that preceeds most.   Its well executed, despite being fairly still.   I can think of many examples that wished they could be as well rounded and wished they could have such a delivery, but they cant.   Simply one of the better barrel aged Barley Wine examples out there.
Lots of dark fruit, prunes and raisin and sloe berries, surprisingly fresh for a dark barrel aged beer. Hints of whiskey smokiness. Quite sour but pleasantly cuts though the richness.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/228/2011.  Poured from a 350 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to bauermj for bringing this over.

This has a dark brown hue with light brown edges. It is obviously totally flat, no head or carbonation.

The aroma is full of brandy. Nice red grape, molasses, caramel, and smooth malt notes are present in the nose as well.

Since it is flat, the flavors blend a bit too much together and lose their identity. Molasses and caramel provide the malt sweetness. Brandy and some dark fruits add some further depth.

The fact that it is totally flat brings this down quite a bit. Thick and syrupy, with a fair amount of stickiness. Some burning in the throat from the brandy.

It would be interesting to try this beer if it was not totally flat.

Tap @ Hunahpu 2012. First beer of the day at CCB. Nose is oak, vanilla, booze, and some light red fruits. Lots of booze. Poured nice and dark with a thin lacing around the edges. Not much of a head. Flavors are oak and cherries with a bit of booze. Nice brew.

For a barley wine, the opaque body and lack of head suggested this brew was serious. Aromas were thick of cherries, oak and honey with hints of vanilla. The taste was heavy, but complex and well-rounded with dried cherries and sweet malts. Finished warm and dry with a nice and oaky lingering aftertaste.

Pour is pitch black with absolutely no head. Aroma is of booze, vanilla, and oak chips. Flavor is very heavy on the alcohol with some slight sweetness in the warming effect. Fairly smooth for the ABV, slightly metallic finish. The cork didnt have a pop so I suspect that the bottle may have been oxidized.

2006 bottle shared at 2012 RBWG. Pours a dark brown with small quickly diminishing head. The aroma is oak and vanilla malt. Medium mouthfeel with a vanilla and oak flavor with rich finish. Easy to drink a very impressive barleywine from Lost Abbey.

Bottle 2008, courtesy of gunnfryd. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, alcohol, dried fruits, chocolate and red fruits. Flavor is sweet and sour with some oak, vanilla, roasted malt, red fruits and malt. Full body, average carbonation.

bottle.  Pours darker than I expected, almost black, with basically no head.  The smell is exquisite, brandy, carmel, and other sweet notes.  Therefore I was expecting it to be sweeter than it is.  Taste is sweet, but not as much as I thought based on the smell.  The barrel and brandy flavors really come out throughout the drink.  Probably one of the best Barley Wines I have had.  Cant wait to try the Bourbon one.

375ml bottle @ Kaisla, Helsinki
2009 vintage - Pours dark brown, almost black with no head whatsoever. Massive aroma of oak, wood, syrup, caramel malts, peat, vanilla, raisins and dark fruits. Taste is slightly sweet with malty notes and hints of vanilla, oak, wood, peat, raisins and plum. Finish is slick and oily with sweet chocolatey and fruity notes. Full bodied, but alcohol is well hidden. Excellent and tasty barrel aged barley wine.

375 ml bottle @ Kaisla, Helsinki. 2009 version, 11.5% abv.
Pours a very dark brown colour without a head at all. Very pleasant aroma of toasted malts, sweet raisins and caramel. Flavour of toasted malts, oak, vanilla, raisins, dark chocolate and toffee - all-in-all extremely well balanced. Full bodied, slick and dry mouthfeel and a long, warming, dry and ripe fruity finish. Awesome, just awesome. Gets even better when warm.

Nice beer.  I was expecting something super crazy sweet -- cough syrup-esque.  Aroma brown sugar-ish.  There is more to the aroma but that takes works to put it into writing.  This one has a very smooth and rich taste with subtle brandy and alcohol notes accompanied with dark fruit notes such plum, cherry and apricot.  The middle taste of this beer briefly reminds me of the taste of cola.  There is a malt backbone that is unusual in beers like this.  Very nice taste that gets richer and more complex as it warms up.  I love quality beer, oh yeah there is alcohol in this...

2010 bottle at Trapisseds from Brewdog Online store
Pours dark ruby with fruity and vanilla notes on the nose
Very rich and boozy, low carbonation, sticky toffee and a warming finish. A good one for ending the night on!

Keg @ BrewDog Edinburgh 140212 (1/3 pint in snifter)
Dark brown...murky and cloudy...thin head
Aroma - sweet bit buttery toffee....molten dime bar...chocolate caramels...very fruity.....some odd butterscotch...bit of alcohol on the nose...weird complex aroma
Taste as aroma with some brandy notes...wood...bit of sherry...hint of red wine...yeast...some sourness...caramel....very rich (perhaps too rich)...crazy complexity
Palate - big beer here...very viscous...very sweet sherry and brandy. FInish of intense chocolate caramel, melted dime bar, fruity port, well blended but there is a bit of saltiness
Overall - Strange enigmatic complex beer in every aspect. A beer geeks puzzle. Do I like it? The aroma isnt that great IMHO but is very complex. The taste is much better and very complex, but I could only the 1/3 pint. Its gorgeous but very strange tasting. IMHO Im glad I tried it but I wasnt madly fond of it even I know its a remarkable beer.

2009 Brandy Barrel bottle.  Unfortunately, this beer turned out as I thought it would in some areas and not in others.  I expected low carbonation and sour as they had a few problems with the barrels and bottling in 2008/2009.  This beer poured dark brown, nearly black with absolutely no head.  I could barely get air bubbles due to its thickness.  Syrup is thinner than this beer.  The nose is extreme alcohol even after a few years.  Big vanilla with dark fruits as well.  Flavor was sweet, thank god not sour.  However the insane malt in this is not balanced by any sort of hop prescence. That could be do to the aging I suppose.  Mouthfeel is suprisingly creamy and smooth.  I expected the lact of carbonation to be a real detractor but its was ok.  Ive had it with good carbonation and its a ton better.  As for this bottle, not so much.

*(cuvée 2009): Tout dabord, lexcitation sest dissipé rapidement quand un silence ecclésiastique accompagna le retrait du liège...Aucun son. Le liquide a larôme et la texture dun vin fortifié et en bouche cest un liquoreux, visqueux liquide où règne la mélasse, la vanille, le chocolat et le brandy. Ma langue est complètement asséché par lalcool mais les saveurs riches sauvent de justesse la maladresse de la présentation.

Draft at Beer Revolution. Dark brown color, small beige edge head. Aroma of prunes and plums. Taste is similar, and slightly sour. Very nice stuff. Earlier Rating: 4/2/2010 Total Score: 3.912 ounce bottle at American Craft in Boston.  Not really a beer, this is a tawny port.  Almost black.  Completely flat, no lacing.  Aroma of sweet cherries, port.  Taste is vinuous, dates, prunes, cherries.  Interesting, but difficult to make it through the entire bottle.

Draft at Beer Revolution.  Flat dark brown in color with maybe some purplish hues.  Big complex aroma with raisin, prune, and dark fruit, vinous notes, brandy, and roast.  The flavor is also great. Sweet malt, candied bourbon soaked fruits, plum, prune, raisin, boozy brandy and oak.  Full-bodied and too low carbonated (surprise surprise) with some booziness.  Solid-ass beer overall.Earlier Rating: 2/9/2009 Total Score: 4.2On tap at Toronado on Lost Abbey night.  Tomme didnt show up which was a bummer.  Oh well.  Wow this is good.  Dark brown, almost black, with a light tan head.  Aroma is sweet with vanilla, oak, dark fruit, roasted malt, and some alcohol.  Flavor is more of the same - really complex and really, really, REALLY good.  A lot like a fine port with roasted malts and all kinds of other great stuff.  I couldnt get enough of this beer.  Smooth and full on the palate, but maybe a little low on carbonation.

Tap at Beer Revolution. Pours a very muddy brune to near black with perfect opacity. Looks like the bottom of a keg even though I know the key was just tapped. Small film of yellow bubbles. No lace. Nose is rich tawny Barleywine and bourbon such as FW13/14/15. Seems like a blend of BA imperial stout and BA Barleywine. Nose adds rich run raisin gelato and espresso ice cream. Thick coffee character. Oh wow. Taste is silky, salted caramel chews, muted smoked malt, heavy dark chocolate, caramel macchiato. Yummy yum yum. Actually tastes identical to Amarula, the South African version of Baileys Irish Cream. What the hell is this? A thicker Deliverance? Fine with me. :)Earlier Rating: 7/25/2009 Total Score: 3.7750mL 2008 ed into snifter. Wow- finally I get to try something that has become a fabled presence in the beerophile world. Pours a deep brown almost black (very cloudy and dark once the yeast is tossed in) with no head but a few white bubbles around the edge. Aroma is almost all whiskey with hints of vanilla extract, oak, brandy, sherry. Taste is lots of brandy, rum soaked cherries, oak, molasses, chocolate pound cake, amaretto, toffee, spicy alcohol. Just very boozy in general. Big warming alcohol in the finish. Not too intense and I can see this being very awesome if it was mellowed out a bit by carbonation. An excellent dessert beer- looks like a true barleyWINE. Not sure if being carbonated would really change this beer fundamentally but Im glad I tried it and will be looking forward to the 2009 release. 7/25/2009 7/3/8/3/16=3.7375mL 2009 ed courtesy of BrainLayer. The pour is a flat, muddy brune. Aroma is soy sauce, oxidized dark fruits, tawny port, spicy and sweet brandy, caramel, sweet red grapes. Taste is smooth, rich, no warming alcohol, full of brown sugar and caramel. Goes a little bit tart and ends cardboardy. Meh. 1/11/2011 7/3/7/3/14=3.4
Very sweet cotton candy taste that is almost overwhelming. Let it warm up a little bit and it develops great sour notes that really enhance the complexity of the beer.

on tap @ Wades Wines. Massive chocolate, black liquorice and toffee notes on the nose, accompanied by a light breadiness. Pours a very dark, reddish color with a moderate foamy top. Flavoring is dominated by chocolate malt and an enormous taste of alcohol. Thick texture on the palate and a heavy blast of malt on the finish. Overall, a spicy, alcohol-filled brew with lots of black liquorice and chocolate flavor. A little too much alcohol and malt presence for my taste. Id give this a C rating.

Sample at Eurostash III tasting on 01/12/2012: 2009 bottle. The beer pours a dark mahogany color with a medium tan head that dissipates quickly to an outer ring. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel malt and chocolate. Rich and smooth body with a nice raisin and date character and notes of chocolate malt, caramel and vanilla. Brandy lends a nice warming boozyness in the background. The finish is sweet caramel and molasses with a lingering oak and dark fruit aftertaste. Very good all around, guess I lucked out!

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 11 total infected mess. Took 1 sip and poured the rest. 

3.6 original rating for the 09: While Ive had more flat bottles than carbonated, this is still a very solid beer. I personally think of it more a an American Strong Ale as it has some Stout like tastes to me. Pours a dark murky brown with an off white head, when present. Great woody and sweet caramel/vanilla notes on the nose and taste. For the big price tag this beer is a risk in the bottle, but if you every run across it on tap its a must try!

Popped an 11 Brandy Last night- Completely flat and infected, almost did a spit take. ITs disgraceful. At this point I will now tell anyone who ever asks my opinion of Lost Abbeys beers that they are an over rated waste of money and should be avoided like the plague. Its asinine that they have not corrected this problem. A real brewer (a good brewer) does some quality control and when problems like this continue to surface they take measures to correct the problem. NEVER EVER AGAIN. DO NO WASTE YOUR MONEY ON A FLAT INFECTED WASTE OF MONEY. YOU CAN DO SO MUCH BETTER WITH $20 THAN TO BUY ANY LOST ABBEY PRODUCT EVER. BUYING THEIR PRODUCT IS LIKE PLAYING RUSSIAN RULLET AND ONLY REMOVING 1 BULLET. STAY AWAY!

2009 vintage 375 ml bottle. This pours a muddy, reddish chestnut brown color and barely topped by a few scant bubbles at the head that quickly rejoin the body below leaving a sudsy wash behind. Just no carbonation at all, which is a bit disappointing for sure. The aroma is very boozy, but deeper notes reveal caramel, toffee, chocolate, and dark fruits. The brandy barrel lends a distinct sweetness while offering loads of oak laden vanilla. The flavor follows suit with the caramel and toffee playing a huge part along with ample amounts of stewed dark fruits and vanilla from the oak. The brandy barrel lends its signature fruity sweetness well. There isnt much in the way of hops to balance out all the malt sweetness though. Nearly full bodied, but the palate lacks some due to the lack of carbonation, which doesnt help in covering up the sticky sugars. The finish is long, fruity, and boozy. This is certainly a very good beer, but one that is hindered due to no carbonation. I do enjoy the bourbon barrel version quite a bit more though. Ill definitely rerate if I come across a carbonated bottle.

Thanks to pushkinwow for this at the Ottawa Tasting.   2008.   Pours a brownish amber with no carbonation whatsoever.   Aroma is sweet caramel, slightly floral, oak and dark fruit.  Taste is a pleasure, the only thing that holds back is the lack of carbonation.
Bottle. Pours brown with a red tint and a thin beige head; spare lacing. Aroma is sour fruit, brown sugar, and molasses. Flavor matches the nose. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

750mL courtesy of riversidea... i mean Secret santa (Thanks), 2007 Vintage only gold lettering, Aged in Oak barrels on the label. 11.5%ABV noted on label. Pour is a dark dark brown with limited head, nose is belgian style and malty, but the barrel has faded a bit, taste is interesting having never had the beer fresh there is now a bit of acidity developed, which really adds to the beer. Straight forward belgian strong taste of malt then acidic middle with a sweet note on the exhale.. pretty good stuff.

2009 vintage. Unfortunately a drain pour. Aged for a little over a year and was so disappointed to not enjoy this brew. The words "Hampster cage bedding" were used. I think we just got a bad bottle of it, but it was really disappointing.
Really dark and thick. Smells like rotten raisins. The mouthfeel is great.... The flavor is bad. Oil, and cheap liquor. Maybe I got a bad one?

Dark brown with no head. Aroma is chocolate, dates, raisins, hint of oak. Slightly oily mouthfeel, full bodied, sweet finish with a touch of booze. Taste is raisins, brown sugar, licorice,  brandy. Quite sweet but very nice.

2010 Brandy stamp, so this was the 2011 version.  In a sad turn of events, nearly this entire pricey bottle was poured down the drain.  This beer was purely AWFUL.  Ruddy brown pour looks like YooHoo, which is about the nicest thing I can say.  Aroma was a blast of booze from the brandy and sharp acidic grape.  Flavor is otherworldly sour and not reminiscent of any barleywine Ive ever tried.  The closest approximation I can make is to a spoiled batch of La Folie, with absolutely no redeeming qualities of vanilla or caramel.  I now fear for the Serpents Stout I bought from the same location, heres hoping that it turns out better.

2011 on bottle neck, 375 ml bottle: Sweet caramel and whiskey in the nose. Dark ruby and cloudy, with moderately low carbonation, and minimal head.  Alchohol and wood evident in the first sip.  Sweet with vanilla/oak and alcohol evident.  Needs some aging, as the flavor components are a bit rough.  A bit dissapointed with this particular bottle - Ill have to try again.

Poured a mahogany brown, smells of caramel and lots of alcohol. Tastes the same but with vanilla and a strong burn.  I expected more oakiness, but I think it was overpowered by the malt. Not a fan of the style, but its a great winter warmer if you desire.

2009 brandy barrel, into a snifter at Uber Tavern in Seattle. 

Appeared almost pitch black with minimal head. 

Smells very strongly of espresso and cream. Sort of weak up front, but it somehow gets stronger as you continue smelling. You can tell its very rich.

Taste was sweet and syrupy, with a big alcohol burn. Again, lots of coffee, vanilla, and caramel. 

Palate was sticky with very little carbonation. It was a very powerful, full, full mouth beer. Big warming sensation.

Overall, a real treat. Age helps it for sure.

750 ml bottle from 2009 (marked on label), served in a tulip.  Pour is dull walnut with absolutely no head or lacing, despite a vigorous pour.  Nose is big bourbon, figs, caramel, oak, and some lighter vanilla notes.  There was an odd sensation in the nose that while flavorful, it seemed flat.  Pow!!  Completely flat when I took my first sip, and every one after for that matter.  Despite a looming flatness, which made the booze crack like a whip with every sip, the brew was pulled off just like the nose indicated.  The flatness would have killed a lessor brew, but this score was still respectable; it would have be a truly amazing beer if it had not been flat.  I am not sure if I got a bad bottle, I suspect I have, but this is the beer I have been most excited about trying for quite some time.
375ml cage n cork. Very deep red colour with almost no head. Fresh sawdust oak on the nose with lots of deep stewed fruit. Reinforced on the palate. Super dry for a barleywine. Fantastic stuff.
No carbonation. wine red. smells like malt and new oak barrel.  fresh saw mill wood chips. fresh new oak. nice tasting. big eood notes, chocolate espresso. great and tasty.
Draft from the beer store. WOW. Aroma and taste of bourbon, some oakiness, cherries, and a little resemblance of red wine. Also brown sugar. Big beer. Awesome.
sweet soft vanilla aroma,red/brown, light brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, creamy, soft carbonation, nice soft funny sweet/ sour beer.

Dark amber coloured. Has a white head, fully lasting. Nice aroma, vanilla, notes of barrel, wood, soft. Heavy sweet and acidic flavor, low drinkability. Unpleasent acidity. Creamy, syrupy texture, flat carbonation.

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly deminishing head. Dark red-amber. Heavy vinius powerfull aroma. Moderate bitter weird flavor. Long moderate bitter vinius finish. Oily palate. Weird and totally unbalanced beer.
Bottle (2008). Nice head with medium duration. Color is dark brown/ruby. Aroma and taste are port wine, fruits, vanilla, wood, caramel and malt.

Clear dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is very sweet malty, caramel, vanilla and whisky. Flavor is quite sweet, moderate bitter and moderate acidic. Dry, moderate bitter and moderate acidic with warming alcohol. I have no idea which batch this was, but it was clearly infected. Still a good beer though. 161111
Dark redish brown with no head. Fruity with malty tones. Malt, oak and fruit. Full body and a long, malty and oak finish.

I wish I enjoyed this one more; I wonder if I got a bad bottle.

Aroma: stale prune, tiny hint of alcohol, nothing else. Not a trace of hops.

Appearance: Nice dark brown opaque beer. No trace of carbonation or head.

Taste: I get mostly sour here, with plum & prune overtones. A hint of malt, no trace of hops, somewhat syrupy prune flavor. Alcohol flavor is there, but not at all overpowering.

Palate: Medium body, very little carbonation. Long finish, but nothing coming through other than old prunes.

Overall: very disappointing. I really think this bottle must be infected.

2009 version (11.5 ABV). Dark leather brown colour, no head. Very nice aroma of roasted malts, fruity and vinous sweetness, vanilla, coffee, caramel, dried figs, and an aftertaste dominated by dark chocolate, taste is very nice and sweet with a hint of tart sourness, smooth silky mouthfeel with warm alchohol and very lightly carbonated. This is one of the most amazing things I have ever tasted, similar to port but much better. Great with cheese.

Fall 2011 Ratebeer gathering. I have been wanting to try this one for a long time. It was nice but not all that I had hoped. +++ Sampled from a 12.7 oz corked brown bottle this beer poured an incredibly murky dark brown color with a trace of a soapy white head that faded quickly and left minimal lacing. The aroma was dryish vanilla, bourbon, port wine, cocoa and wood. The flavor was sweet caramel and strong bourbon with moderate vanilla, nut, wood and cherry. Nicely complex in flavor. The finish was long with bourbon, caramel and vanilla lingering. Full bodied. Well done.

375ml bottle, 2009 vintage, brandy barrel. 
Pours a dark murky brown, with no head.
Smells of brandy, sweet caramel, and port.
Feels like creamy silk on the tongue.
Tastes of brandy, vanille, brown sugar, oak  and finishes with a strong warming boozy feeling all the way down the gullet.
Intensely rich, and hits hard, but oh so amazingly good. Wish the bottle were larger!

2007 bottle drank about 8/1/11. This was supposedly the infected batch. Aroma: Sorghum, some brandy. Taste: the sorghum turned somewhat malt vinegary. Strange. Its certainly infected in some way, but it isnt terrible, nor great. Some bread and brandy in the finish.

12.7 ounce (375 ml) caged and corked bottle, 2010 vintage as stamped on bottle.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a murky brown color with no head and no lacing at all.  The cork was on the bottle tight, but once I got it out and there was no "pop", I figured this would be a flat bottle.  The brew smells like dark fruit, brandy, molasses and caramel.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also a red grape and a bit of a weird tart fruit flavor.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a little slick with pretty much no carbonation.  Im lucky I didnt get a totally infected bottle of this, it could have been a lot worse.  This wasnt an awful beer, but it wasnt really enjoyable either.  Id like to try a good bottle of this brew at some point in the future, but thats not going to happen anytime soon after drinking this one.

375 ml. bottle. 12.5% ABV. No year on the label. Pours a minimal, fizzy beige head, of short duration, over a brown (SRM 30) hazy, with occasional small floaters, body....nose is dried fruits, including fig, cherry, raisin, Marmite, beef, molasses....taste is sweet with brown sugar tones, slight molasses, balanced by dried fruits, Marmite, beef, soy, whiskey, vanilla.....mouth feel light, slightly sticky, alcohol hidden, carbonation low. The mouth feel is surprisingly light for a Barley Wine. The complexity of both aroma and flavor in this are absolutely outstanding. It is a remarkable balance of an Abt/Quad and a Barley Wine, tending towards the former. That may be due to age, as the hop backbone may be beyond its prime (I think this is a 2008), but the other forces make this a great beer. BJCP 8/3/16/4/8

Bottled. Thx Gustaf
Vinous and sourish oaky aroma and flavour.
Oaky saison with sweet, tropical fruits.

Bottle care of juiceisloose...you da man.  Pours dark reddish brown.  Aroma is booze...and more booze.  Taste is super complex.  Brown sugar, vanilla, caramel, nouget, oak, brandy...this may be what they drank at the last supper.  Incredible

hard aromas of port wine, big brandy and booze aroma.  some light toasty grain sweetness floating around.  booze is almost unpalatable, but the flavor underneath it is beautiful: lush vanilla, caramel, and smooth oaked- malt.  I would hope that age would temper that raging booze, but this fresh batch was really intense.
on tap at the hangar 9 carbondale.full mouth feel.very complex. lots of caramel vanilla. fruity with lots of raisin and fruit flavor. very good barley wine

Bottle. Very dark brown with tiny diminishing tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, yeast, caramel and plume. Flavour is dried fruits, raisins, yeast, vanilla, plume, vinous, caramel, medium sweet, littler bitter and brandy.

From a bottle at home in Skövde. The bottle was bought in Denmark and must have somehow been infected, it tasted really bad!!
 I have to try a new  bottle and then rate it again.
Very smooth, refined, robust and complex.  Notes of port, roasted malt, molasses and brandy barrel.  Slightly sour and warming finish.  Is it worth $16 for one 12.7 oz "beer" ???  Maybe!
Bottle. Black beer with a small head. Oak aroma, sourish, vinous, figs, raisins, dades, licorice. Vinous flavor, raisins, sourish. Either this is a bad bottle, or this beer is extremely overrated.
Pours dark black with small off white head.  Big bubbles.  Aroma of vanilla and burbon.  Taste is the same with a smooth creamy palette and an alcohol bite.

not quite what I expected, poured an almost pure brown with a little maroon coloring, aroma is of raisins and chocolate, taste is pretty similar, even though labeled as a barley wine I knew this was a little off the mark, and it is. intereting to be sure, but not quite something I would normally enjoy.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2013 Draft. Pour is hazy brown with a nice beige head, good retention/lacing. Aroma is prunes, brandy, figs, plums, raisins, molasses, vanilla. Taste is fantastic: light sweetness, dark fruits, molasses, vanilla, oak. Palate is somewhat dry, moderate carbonation, oily, sticky texture, long sweet finish. I think brandy really complements this and other barleywines quite a bit better than bourbon which seems to add a lot of heat. 8/4/8/5/15

Re-rate: Bottle. Pours dead flat. Aroma is infected: red wine/tannic notes, vanilla, barrel. Taste is moderately sour, lactic, tannic. Palate is sharp, acetic. Not offensive but certainly not a good infection. 7/1/5/3/13

#1000, kinda feels like an accomplishment... Spent some time trying to figure out which this was, bourbon barrel or brandy barrel, opened it and this is obviously brandy barrel, or the weakest bourbon barrels ever were used... This is a dark brown headless wonder, incredibly viscous, coats the sides of the glass.... little lacing... this is a sipper... chocolate, fruity alcohol, vanilla, warming aroma, licorice... initially very sweet, cherry/dark fruits dominate early, dry on the back side, smokiness lightly in the finish, sweet in a fruity way not in a sugary way.... Full bodied, slick, not at all lively, i guess flat applies here, but this is a barleywine and i am very ok with this... but the complexity keeps you sipping more and more... really excellent, im excited for the next 1000....

Had this on draught at the Cheeky Monk in Denver during GABF week.  So Im unsure which version it was.  What I am sure of is that it was one of the best beers Ive had in the past number of years.  Dark brown colour, thick head.  The aroma was impeccable - like a rumbutter-drizzled sticky toffee pudding with walnuts and awesomeness.  Simply the best aroma Ive encountered in a long time.  On the palate, this was unfathomably complex with rich, rich sugars both burnt and unburnt, subtle fruitiness, graham cracker crust and highland whisky. Almost a charcoal accent, like the char on a barbequed steak.  Rich - lots of malts with chocolate, walnuts, cashews, vanilla and deep fruitiness that veers into tartness late, resulting in a compelling  malt-fruit-alcohol combination.  Bombastic ale, very warming, with sugars, malts, raisins, date sugar, orange peel.  I think you could find almost anything in this beer, it has so much complexity and nuance.  Unreal depth.  Ive had Angels Share before, but this glass (correction, these glasses) were beer at its apex.

Pours a thick dark crimson brown liquid with minimal carbonation.  Huge bourbon in the aroma with some butterscotch, vanilla beans, loads of roasted malts and some raisins.  Super smooth and oily mouthfeel with a strong kick of alcohol up front and a long lingering burn.  Loads of malts again along with more bourbon, some anise, roasted grains and more dark dried fruits   Hot, malty and long finish.  A very good barleywine and one with a huge bourbon presence.
Pour is a deep dark reddish brown no head. Smell is leather tobacco and raisons. Taste is a dollar coaster smokey peaty leathery up front sweet fruit middle and sour grape finish.

Sampled @ SBWF on September 29. Pours dark amber with almost no head.  Smell is sweet with prunes and other sweet dried fruits. Taste is dominated by raisins and has a very intriguing acidity to it. Theres also some dried fruit but the sourness of the beer really blew me away.
Sampled at SB & WF 2011. Black with no real head. Smells brandy and smoky. Tastes, chocolate, sour and malty with a similar finish.

On tap at The Cheeky Monk in Denver, also Oskar Blues Liquids and Solids, Longmont.  Super hazy super dark brown, near black. Thin light tan head. Nose is very strong. Dark bittering chocolate, oaked brandy, a bit of honey, and molasses. Really big and intense flavor and palate. Big notes of dark bittersweet chocolate, like Hersheys syrup but darker. Some bourbon or whiskey tones are also there, bringing its oak and vanilla undertones to add to the complexity. But as high ABV as it is, the booze isnt too boozy. Its there and warming, but not off-putting. Not as heavy as some impy stouts, but still a big sipper. Warm bourbon ending with a dark roasted chocolate aftertaste. A delight.

Bottle from Euston Tap. 2009 version. Pours dark murky brown. Nose is sweet pungent alcoholic brandy/whiskey spirit, then orange liquor, raisins and woody oak. To be honest Im getting tired of these overpowering American beers that smell and taste of whiskey/brandy etc and this is the last time Ill b spending money on this type of overblown nonsense. I want beer to taste of hops and malt not whiskey or brandy.
Pours a deep dark brown with absolutely no head. Aroma of chocolate, alcohol, fruit and raisins. Flavor is sour, caramel, berries, alcohol, and dark fruits. Amazingly complex and very good.

Dark red-brown colored, no head. Sour, fruity, licoricy aroma with only thin raisins, plum and rich sherry note. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is also sour with berries, licorice, plum, dark fruits and thin alcohol, complex one, but not too traditional BW. Aftertaste turns to vinous, even with port wine. Complex, and excellent one.

On tap @ the brewery.
Reddish brown pour with very little head.  Aromas of dark fruit, caramel malt, vanilla, and some pine hops.  Flavors of molasses, dark fruit, wood, some chocolate, and caramel.  I would love to try the bourbon barrel aged version of this.

2009 Brandy vintage, poured from a bottle into a glass. Dark hazy brown, completely flat of course. Lots of booze on the nose. Flavor is of chocolate, oak, and alcohol. An alcohol burn as it goes down, much better on the palate when I had this carbonated on tap. Good beer, inexcusably flat given the price point.

Draught at The Wicked Shamrock, Lompoc, USA.
Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, wood, vanilla). Flavor heavy sweet, moderrate spicy and bitter, in a good balance. Full body, some alcohol felt, quite complex.

Appearance is dark brown with weak head and worse retention, little to no lacing either.  Aroma is caramel, vanila, dark fruit.  Taste is vanilla, raisins, molasses, caramel, spice, light chocolate, and licorice.  Body is full, sticky and so lush it nearly cloys; low carbonation, bitter finish.  Overall, I prefer Older Viscosity to this offering, but this is a nice Belgian approach to the oak aged strong ale style.
Dark Black pour. Hints of caramel and slight coffee and vanilla.  Great aroma which was the first thing i noticed. Oaky aftertaste.  Amazing beer.  Goes great after a meal as a dessert beer!

Brandy barrel version.  A very deep murky brown with red hues and yeast.  Very pleasant aroma of barrel notes, merlot/port.  No carbonation at all.  I understand that some styles have extremely low carbonation, but none?  You need a little something to give a little spring to the flavors and add to the palate and mouthfeel.  Flavor falls apart quick.  Some merlot spiked with roasted/toasted malt that morphs into an unbalanced sour bomb.  Astringent/vinegar finish.  Body feels thin for the style, probably from the carbonation issue.  Wouldnt even be good if considered to be a sour ale instead of a barley wine.  Could have been very good, but definitely is highly over-rated, in my opinion.  Aroma and appearance skewing my rating.

Reviewed from notes
Color: Black with light brown tones throughout, no head or carbonation
Nose: Brady, red wine, fruit, burnt caramel
Taste: Initially very sour, fermented fruit, red wine, slight chocolate, with a sweet/bitter medium finish. Medium body with a slightly thick texture

375ml from Logli on state poured into a snifter. Pours a dark black with light brown undertones. Zero head. Aroma is caramel, figs and fermented fruit. Almost smells like a good dry red wine. Taste is heavy sour with a slight bitterness and light sweetness on the end. It tastes like a dark chocolate dry red wine. Medium bodied with a thin slick texture. Zero carbonation and a long sweet and sour finish. Overall, its not bad. Not something I would buy again but something to try once just to say you did.
On tap at Zenos.  Black with quarter inch tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, oak, vanilla and brandy.  Flavor is the same.  Nice and smooth.
I dont really have anything negative to say about this beer. It was strong and smooth at the same time. The oak flavor and a chocolatey flavor dominated my tastebuds. Loved it.
Really complex and interesting.  Taste is like a mix of soy souce, cabranet, dark fruit and port wine.  Fantastic.

375 mL bottle purchased 18 months ago from South Bay Drugs (2009 bottle).  Pours a very muddy brown with not even a bubble.  Enticing aroma of oak and booze mostly (it is really difficult to distinguish between whiskey, brandy, or even possibly rum in this case).  Also some vanilla pokes through in the aroma.  The flavor is really good with everything from chocolate to vanilla, coconut to dark fruit, and some combination of either brandy or whiskey.  The alcohol is certainly noticeable as this one does burn a bit.  The biggest downfall is the lack of any carbonation (which could be a product of aging but I somehow doubt it).  Overall this is a very good beer but at $17 is hard to justify.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2011 2010 BRANDY barrel. Infected! This one had a bit of carbonation, not much, but enough. The problem was that it smelled horrible and tasted like sour orange juice. Absolute trainwreck.

375 ml bottle poured into a Darkness snifter.  
A- Very dark brown almost black color, absolutely no carbonation, no head or lacing, not a very attractive beer.
S- Really sweet aroma, vanilla, dark fruits, raisins, plums, sweet caramel, brandy, slight alcohol presence.
T- Wow not what I was expecting, really unusual sour notes, some vanilla, some brandy, vinegar, some malt but the sour taste overpowers everything else. Not impressed.
M- Medium/Big mouth feel, no carbonation whatsoever, sour taste that coats the palate, really thin and watery.
O- I was very let down by this beer, Ive heard mixed reviews, and all the low carbonation stories that Ive heard definitely apply to this beer.  Under carbonated to a point where it affects the beer, Ive never had an infected beer, but this one tastes like it might be, the sour notes come out so strong and really take away from the experience. I tried my best to finish this bottle but the taste was just too much, had to drain pour.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2011 Buyer Beware!! Either this overpriced monstrosity varies widely in quality, or this is THE most overrated beverage in the history of brewing. First of all, there is NO carbonation. Surprise!! Secondly, you better like thin, and you better like sour if you buy this p.o.s. beer. This "beer" is like a bad joke, and Im not laughing. 

Update for 8/4/2011: I contacted the brewery, and yes, they know they have a problem, so just pass on this beer. Its too pricey to buy and pray that its good. The brewery offered equal compensation from their store. Brewing is an art, sometimes mistakes happen, so I took the offer, and called it even. FYI: they wont be brewing this anymore because of the problems, but there will be other Angle Share beers, for example, bourbon barrel aged.

Update 8/30: The losers didnt even send me my t-shirt after buying their defective beer!!

This bottle was a 2007. Supposedly this was the infected batch. The aroma has some sorghum and molasses (yes distinct from each other) with a really mild vinegar note, some brandy, and some fig. The flavor is mildly sweet and very vinous with some tannic Cabernet Sauvignon character. The beer has a mild lactic tartness and a good booziness throughout with some roastiness in the finish. The beer tastes as much like wine as any beer Ive ever had.

38cl, Vintage 2009, at 11.5%Vol, as Angels Share (Brandy 09 imprinted on the bottle), exclusive American brew, from Den Bierzolder Heule, complex brew, sweet/alcoholic and slightly roasted, heavy, not balanced, hazy, nearly no head, nice brew, yet way too expensive!, needs to be revised

Bottle at unos in neshaminy.  Aroma is a sweet bourbon, red wine, dark fruits conglomerate.  A sweet taste of cherries, oak,  fruits,  bourbon is followed by a mild sour bite.  Toes the line between beer and wine.   Some brown sugar in there as well.  Mild alcohol burn is only a hint or the power underneath.
(375 ml bottle). Pours black and viscous. Aroma of bourbon and vanilla with similar flavor. Soooo rich. This beer hides the alochol very well. Superb!

Maple cloudy color with some white yeasty specks floating around. No head to speak of. Aroma of pear, fig, vanilla and brandy. Taste like a smoky brandy with molasses, vanilla, dark fruits. You can hold this on your tongue and it produces new complexity the longer you let it sit. Then you are rewarded with the results of months of oak aging as you swallow.

Im drinking the 2010.  Pours a hazy deep brown.  There is no head to speak of, but there is a lot of activity on the surface of the beer.  Aroma is sour sweet with dark fruit, brown sugar and citrus mixed together.  The flavor changes a lot very quickly in the mouth.  The beer starts relatively sweet, gets sour quickly, and then slowly works it way back to a smooth brown sugar and molasses finish.  I dont know that Ive had a beer that changes flavors so abruptly and aggressively.  If you are looking for a beer that has a unified bouquet this is not the beer for you.  If you are looking for a different and interesting beer with very strong flavors that will keep you guessing this is definitely worth a try.  I appreciate this beer for what it is, but Im not sure I would drink it on a regular basis.

What happened?? 2009 purchased from Whole Foods in Napa, CA. I was very excited to try this beer, as Ive been a fan of other Lost Abbey brews. This was absolutely horrible. Im going to assume that I purchased a "bad" bottle somehow, I cannot imagine anyone brewing something like this, bottling it, and trying to sell it to the public! A sour, rotten, nasty mess of a flat beer. Im not going to rule this one out for future purchase...but I will make very sure that its fresh and properly stored before I spend any money.
En 2010 ABV från Systembolaget. Tyvärr var min som så många andras lite sur. Antagligen påverkad av bakterier under fatlagringen. Svårt att därför ge betyg på smaken.
#1500. Bottle pours a murky muddy brown pour with no head. Scent is dark over ripe fruits, chocolate and some whiskey. Taste is sweet and sour.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet (Vika), Oslo. Opaque, dark brown colour. Miniscule, beige head. Sweet, concentrated aroma of raisin, caramel, whisky, fermented fruit. Full-bodied, yet nicely drinkable. Carbonation is fairly flat, but theres also a tingly sensation on the tongue. Taste is initially very sweet, but gradually a herbal bitterness becomes dominant. Finishes with an alcohol burn and a herbal aftertaste, which I find a bit rough.

Brandy barrel on tap .... Deep reddish brown pour thin off white head ... aroma of dark fruits/brandy and oaky with some vanilla even more so as it warmed .... taste is of brandy/dark fruits and oak, caramel malts and grainy as well as vanilla which came out more as it warmed ... bitter warming finish ... An awesome sipping barley wine

Well there isnt much to say other than there is an obvious issue with this one. The aroma has elements of vinous fruits, malts and barrel but the taste is watery and acetic vinegar. Horrible. Infected barrel or something.

2010 vintage, 375ml.  Smelled fine, really malty with lush darker fruits and sweeter aromas.  Too bad the palate was horrible, unbalanced, cloying sweet mess of a beer.  Im going into this ignoring the flat abbey remarks, but this needed something, carbonation, whatever.  Sour finish.  So bad!

Bottle shared at Øl og matfestivalen.
All black without head.
Malty aroma with oak, dark fruits, coffee.
Spicy complex taste with chocolate, cinnamon, alcohol and coffee.
Good rich body

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2015 I was very excited about trying this beer. Id like my money back please. Tastes disgusting. Tastes like watered down poor quality brandy. Shouldnt really be classed as a beer. Pours completely flat, very dark brown. Smells of alcohol/brandy. Very strong brandy/alcohol taste. Tastes like bad medicine. Putrid stuff. Very disappointing. Interesting isnt always good.

Take 2. . Dark brown with tan head. Aroma is rich, wood, chocolate, tootsie roll. Taste of oak, chocolate brownies, malty, molasses. Quite flat,  bitter. A different beer.

Bottle, 375ml, at Haandverkerstuene, shared by OleR, thx a lot. An unclear, brown beer with a small, beige head. Looking quite good, and still its all upwards from there. Wunderbar aroma of plums, prunes and raisins, caramel sugaryness, alcohol, and some hints of choclate, cellar and medicine. Its full-bodied and appropriately low on carbonation, some might say flat, I say it suits the beer perfectly, and theres an alcohol warmth that adds to the perfection. A nice bitterness follows you from the first sip and until all the beer is gone, supported by caramel sweetness, dried fruits and a chocolate raisin touch. A fantastic beer indeed. 110211

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 2010 bottle. 
Very dark reddish brown with a minimal tan ring around the glass that disappears quickly.
Aroma: chocolate, licorice, liqueur, some kind of candy.
Taste: vinous, licorice, chocolate, blackcurrants, wine gums, candy, tart/acidic, dry finish.
Almost still, quite full-bodied.
Big and warming, a sipper. Still though, I was hoping for more.

[keg at BrewDog Edinburgh] Pours a nightmarish black with almost no head. Looks like a glass of creosote  hugely viscous and oily when swirled around. The aromas give you the impression you could paint a fence with it as well  massive alcohol and dark fruit on the nose, vanilla, some oaky wood maybe. On the taste, as it totally coats the palate theres a wallop of prunes, raisins and figs before the alcohol takes over. Next time I have a sore throat, this would be tremendous. As a drinking beer its maybe a touch heavy for my personal taste, but you cant deny its not fascinating [18062011]

From notes.  May 2010.  Sample thanks to armin. Pour is a clear, very dark brown, with no head, only a few bubble rising to the surface.  Aroma is dominated by dark fruits, primarily raisins, and is sweet to the point of being heavy, which really covers up some of the other more subtle tones.  Flavor though, is great.  Huge burnt brown sugar notes, lots of vanilla, light oaky undertones bringing it together, with the same dark fruits, though in the backseat.  Just a touch of carbonation on the tongue, but enough to lift it and keep it from being cloying.  Not a bad beer at all, but just a touch aroma heavy for me.
2008 bottle pours a dark brown with no head. Caramel, vanilla, brandy, boozy smell. Flat, dry mouthfeel. Stale caramel, booze, vanilla, dark toffee flavors--
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
2009 version 
head: none 
colour: dark red / brown
smell: red fruits, malts, banana, cheesy , yeasty 
taste: soury oaky start, boozy, red fruits, caramel, woody, grapes, wineous , ginger ,melon , bubblegum, strawberrys, somewhat boozy and acidic end , great !!

Dark brown cocacolaish with no head. Aroma malty, coffee, licorice. Taste sweet sour coffee and some salty licorice. Full body, text thick, oily, smooth, no carb. Finish long sourness. Not my kind at all. Had great expectations.

33cl bottle @ Brewdog Bar in Edinburgh. Pours a murky chocolate-brown with no head. The nose is intriguing - really savoury with blue cheese, then sour cream against an earthy background note. The taste has chocolate and again there is blue cheese and tangy-winey note. The palate has a big structure, a really thick texture and then a fairly sharp, perhaps tangy-sour (rather than bitter) finish. Overall, this is a stunning multi-dimensional beer which is still somehow incredibly balanced and restrained.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. Ive had the famous bourbon barrel version before, now its time to see what the original is like. :-) Pours a near-black deep brown body with a small, light beige head which disappears quickly - as expected. Nose is fantastic, with deep malty caramel notes blended with oaky peanut vanilla and port hints, along with notes of that barley wine woody hazelnut aroma I like so much. Taste is a sophisticated composition of alcohol-propelled wooden vanilla tones, peanuts, burnt caramel, nuts, deep malts, dense bitter hops and hints of salty licorice. Extremely well-balanced, as Ive known Lost Abbey to be in most - if not all - occasions. Warming alcohol finish, subtly wrapped in bitter licorice hops. A really great winter warming barley wine, which most beer geeks like me enjoy just as much in the summer. Another winner from Lost Abbey! :-)

This review reflects a bottle of 2010 Brandy Angels Share that I opened on 5/21/11. It cost me $16.99 for the 375 ml bottle. Let me first say that I find this brewery to be a bunch of cowards. See the end of review for clarification.The cork came out with no sound. It poured black with no head and zero carbonation-not a hint. The aroma was nothing like brandy or any barrel. It was very tart with tons of dark fruits, cherries and lots of grapes but it also seems moldy or like a pile of poop The taste was unbelievably bad and exteremely undrinkable. Massive tart cherry and grape like taste with a moldy taste and Im not making this up-poop. I tried to muster the strength to down it but it was THE WORST BEER IVE EVER HAD. Complete drainpour.


I decided to email the brewey and send them some feedback about it in a respectful way to see what they could do about it. Also to give them a chance to make it right. Now this was 2 weeks before the V009 release and Im sure they are busy people. I heard nothing back just crickets and they totally ignored me. Fast forward to a few days after the V009 release and a user on another site complained about a missing V009 label. He said he emailed the brewery and they responded back within the same day and said they would fix that situation. This is a missing label mind you not the actual product inside. I was a little peeved that I had emailed them more than 2 weeks before about the actual product and they ignored me. But they were really quick to respond about a very minor issue. I sent another email to ask if they care about there customers(which they dont) since they ignored me. After hounding them they offered me a T-shirt ( I wouldnt want to sport your gear now)and told me they couldnt refund my money because a lot of bad seeds had taken advantage of them. Let me tell Lost Abbey you are the ones taking advantage of people not the other way around.


This brewery could learn a lot from stand up breweries like Deschutes and Cigar City who admit when they make mistakes. Intstead these Lost people are hiding behind a curtain and refuse to address a problem because they are cowards. I respect a brewery who when they find a QC problem make a formal announcement(blog post, BA or RB post, just something) and try to make it right. Instead these cowards would rather there customers buy a defective product and screw us consumers over just so they can move on to the next batch. That is horrid customer service and I do not know how I can not give this beer any points because 1) It was a terrible beer and 2) they refuse to acknowledge anything when given the chance to make it right. Clearly these people are Lost at the "Abbey"

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2011 2010 bottle. Pours deep brown, no carbonation. Nose is vanilla, wood, and a touch of charcoal.

The taste is quite good. Vanilla, some bittersweet cocoa, very nice oak and roasted malt, just a touch of brandy. Interesting acidity, very high. Almost has a sour note to it. Dont know if this is by design or if its poor storage on the part of the market. My initial thought is that its by design, as it tastes very good. It is, however, a little out of balance which is why Im a little curious. Tastes as though its a product of the brandy, as that seems a prominent partner.

Overall great beer. No alcohol, very surprising for 11.5%. The acidity was a little out of balance and the oak/brandy is a little too domineering for me to give this a better score. Very happy, though.

EDITED TO ADD: The "sour" note got more and more pronounced with each sip. By halfway through it was wildly out of balance. Did some research and it looks like maybe this batch was infected. 

Still a good beer, but got hard to drink the whole thing. You could tell something was off, and messing with the flavor of an otherwise stellar effort.

Bottle from SAVOR. Poured a dark, near-black color with a small tan head. Aroma was raisins, prunes, vanilla notes, alcohol. Flavor was alcohol, oak notes, raisins, prunes. A bit like a wine, though the alcohol really shines through it.
Bottle shared. Totally black,no head or lacings. Aroma has soya sauce, coffee and chocolate. Body has some acids, full bodied with some sweetness. Feel is oily. Finish is quite hoppy and bitter. Nice

bottle from trade w/Norcalgrowler - this beer blew my mind a little.. huge arouma, exudes vanilla bean, molasses, whiskey, oak and earth. Very sweet, but perfectly balanced by dry oak. Very creamy, chocolate, toffee. Velvety mouthfeel, warm booziness at the finish, coconut, cocoa dust, creme brulee. Some bitter sticks to the tongue. Would make an amazing baking beer, though I cant imagine myself ever wasting it like that. lovely warming notes that makes me want to start drinking whisky

28-05-11 Bouteille: Belle couleur cuivrée, avec une légère effervescence et pratiquement sans mousse. Aromes complexes de brandy, de caramel, de fruits, de sirop dérable, de boisé. Moyement  sucré, avec des saveurs complexes qui sentremlent parfaitement. Le brandy est toujours bien présent, mais prend sa place sans plus. Très drinkable pour une biere de cette puissance. Corps puissant, ronde en bouche avec une carbonisation plutot faible et une finale sucrée et alcoolisée. On en redemande!
Alcohol and brandy on the nose.  Very little carbonation.  Brown sugar and brandy on the palate.  Tongue coating.  Overall very good.
2008 Bottle from Cavie.  Murky dark pour with no head or carbonation.  Aroma is alcohol, chocolate, vanilla, and wood.  Taste is thick, chocolate, vanilla, sherry, and alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2011 2008 bottle with big thanks to drowland! I tried to shoot the cork and it drooped out by my feet. Pours a dark brownish red color. Low low low carbonation. Aroma is dark fruit, cherries, play doh clay and wood. Flavor is heavy dark fruit with a huge alcohol burn. Clay flavor also. Woody malty notes. Finishes sweet and clay.

2010 vintage poured into a wine glass. Pours a dark, murky brown with absolutely no head. No activity at all, for that  matter. Id heard this batch was infected and the carbonation took a hit for it, and it looks to be true. The aroma is still amazing: tons of dark fruit, vanilla, brown sugar, and molasses notes. The flavor is predominantly vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, prune, and a slight bitterness in the finish. Not much alcohol warmth at all for 11.5% abv. Mouthfeel is utterly flat and disappointing. Like drinking a warm Coca Cola that had been sitting on a store shelf for 2 years. Id had high hopes for this, but it just didnt measure up. Not bad, for being infected, by any means, but I certainly wont be comparing other barley wines to this...

Pours a thick reddish brown color with no head. Hardly any hiss when the cork was popped. Notes of vanilla, oak, vinegar, cognac, brown sugar, and caramel. Flat as all hell. Maybe infected, maybe under carbonated. Either way, its not very good.

Bottle. Pours a muddy and dark brown beer with no head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, raisin and coffee. The flavor is same as the nose with additional alcohol and notes of acidity. The palate is sweetness with alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer.

2010 vintage. 375 mL bottle. Lost Abbey tulip.

APPEARANCE: Black. Tinge of light caramel brown/cola.
Head is practically inexistent and minimal foam dissipates quickly. Minimal amount of light tan foam left only around circumference of glass. Zero lace. 

AROMA: Caramel, cola, chocolate, brandy, brandied raisins. 
Hints of prunes, vinous character, as well as some faint nutty notes. 

TASTE: Vinous, caramel, cola, brandy, brandied raisins, grape juice, chocolate, oak. More vinous and cola character on finish.
Hints of tart red stone fruit (e.g., cherry).  

MOUTH FEEL: Nearly inexistent carbonation. Alcohol is relatively mellow for the abv  i.e., alcohol warmth is quite light. Light puckering on finish  due to vinous character. 
OVERALL: Avoid the 2010 vintage due to infection. Although it seemed infection in this particular bottle had yet to take over the ale completely (as some others have written about this vintage) it was definitely undesirable. Unexpected vinous character is prominent on taste, with mild tartness on finish. Despite the above, the caramel, brandy, and cola notes on the nose are fairly pleasant. Would like to try another vintage without infection. Taste is more like barley wine like aged with bacteria in red wine barrels rather than brandy barrels.

This was quite an interesting beer. Not necesarily my favorite, but very unusual. The aroma was a wine/raisin smell. The taste was unquestionably pure prune juice. Its been quite a while since I have had prune juice and that was never voluntarily. Maybe in the 60s? Should keep me regular, I guess.

375ml bottle, 2010 vintage.  Pours a dark brown color with *zero* head.  Aroma is sweet, dark fruit, rasins, alcohol.  Heavy on the palate with *zero* carbonation.  Completely flat.  Flavor is sweet, malty, alcohol, oak, with a dry, tart finish.

I opened this due to rumors that it might be infected, but I dont think this one is.  If it is, the infection hasnt taken over yet.  It is certainly not as infected as the bottle of Mirror Mirror I had.  Overall, a decent beer, but it would be much better if it werent *completely* flat.

I was really looking forward to this one, but it didnt really work for me.  And its because it was totally and completely flat.  The aroma was there - loads of dark fruits, vanilla, caramel mostly.  Definitely smells like brandy.  But theres no head at all and no movement in the glass.  The taste is actually very good - grape and prune flavors, vanilla, tons and tons of caramel and something sour on the finish.  A nice warming effect as well, but Im really put off by the complete lack of carbonation.  Its a great tasting beer and doesnt need much, but completely flat just seems wrong.

375ml bottle from 2009. Pours a reddish brown but clear, nice carbonation. Nice aroma - plumbs, caramel, vanilla, prunes. Little thin but very nice taste - sweet, still get some alcohol, get some oak and brandy that lingers very nicely.

Oak and whiskey nose, strong. Brown and headless. Smooth, easy carbonation. Sweet whiskey flavor, but not overly sweet. First sip is deceptively light and alcohol isnt distracting. It burns on the back end. Finishes with peanut and oak. Not my thing.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is caramel, oak, booze, hops, wood, and toffee. Flavor is toffee, oak, caramel, nuts, booze, hops, and figs. Medium/full body with nice heat.

Tap, Brick Store Feb. 11. Mahogany, dense, with a thinner tan head. Plums and chocolate feature the most in the aroma with a light sweetness, and a bit of yeast and a bready sourness. Really surprisingly filled with chocolate, plum, and rich dark fruits.  Syrupy body, viscous, and a nice layer of carbonation.  Nice treat, but a bit of a chore after a while.

Pours a hazy brown with no head.  Pours flat and no carbonation.  Smells of chocolate, heavy caramel malts, tangy fruit, heavy vanilla, fresh cut oak, char, and more cherry.  Just a wonderful aroma that is heavy and rich.  Tastes very rich with loads of chocolate and fruit.  This is very much like wine and shows its brandy heritage.  The brandy barrel comes through offering vanilla, oak, dark fruit, and loads of chocolate in the finish.   But its flat, very flat and no beer should be flat, irregardless of how it tastes.  Having said that, it still tastes marvelous.

12.7 oz  pours brown and almost looks like a dark apple cider and no carbonation. Smells odd to me, I smell something sour, oak, maple syrup and a hint dark fruits. This reminds me more of a wine than a beer. Lots of flavors here, vinous, chocolate, oak and a certain tartness. Mouthfeel is medium and finish malty and tart.

2010 bottle. Pour looks like flat coca cola there is also a dent in the cork looks like it struck the top on the way in and looked soggy starting to get scared. Aroma super sweet, prunes, plums, dates, bourbon and vanilla. Taste vanilla, bourbon, dark fruit, grape or prune juice? candy like sweetness, butterscotch, caramel. Full thick syrupy body no carb. Overall a sad face not for me at all I want to retry in hope that this was not as intended.
smores chocolate. dark brown no head.  spices, chocolate, marshmallow, cinnamon, pepper.  heat with a medium body

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2013 On tap at ColLAboration LA event. Unsure of the vintage. Simply wonderful. Dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is vanilla, caramel, chocolate, and BRANDY for days. Flavor is sweet and powerful, some fruity sweetness, chocolate, vanilla and lots of brandy taste. This was a great beer. Thrilled to have had it. *RERATE* 1/25/2013. 2008 Vintage Bottle. Deep brown with no head. Aroma is coffee, toffee, vanilla, caramel. Taste is sweet, brown sugar, caramel, toffee; just long on the malt and very smooth. No carbonation. Beautiful; it has legs. Its incredible. Interesting that the years of aging completely neutralized the brandy notes. I have to say they were indeed missed but it turned into something etill quite phenomenal.

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml - 2008 vintage) Dark brown pour with a very thin layer of tan head. Huge boozy and brandy aroma followed by a heavy caramel and vanilla aroma. Flavor is very boozy, surprising for 3 years old, with a nice caramel malt and vanilla sweetness in the middle. Finishes with a smooth and sweet oak and brandy combination. Warming and really silky on the palate.

2009 vintage.  No "pop" from the cork. Aggressive pour into a tulip glass produced no head.  Looks (and tastes) pretty flat.  Regardless it turned out to be quite good.  Nose of brandy caramel, chocolate, and yes soy sauce.  Tastes of brandy, chocolate, malty, and slight soy sauce.  Coates the mouth.  Not quite as good as the bourbon aged version but very good.

Well, that was a surprise.   I "popped" the cork on the 375 ml bottle, but there was no pop.  Uh oh, not a good sign.   Poured it out, no carbonation.  Hmm...   Is it supposed to be this way?   I did some searching and its not clear.  It doesnt sound like its *supposed* to be completely flat, but its probably not supposed to be "fully" carbonated either.   Okay, moving on.  Strong port wine aroma coming off this.  First taste was strange since it was totally flat and didnt think it was going to be drinkable.   But since I actually like port wine and this definitely has that flavor, I kept going.  Good thing as this actually became quite enjoyable.  Prune is the dominate flavor here with vanilla and bourbon-like flavors in the background.   A bit of licorice spice and molasses n the mix.  Leaves a funny tingly feeling behind and the port/prune flavor.   Thinking back (and its been a looong time), this reminds me of Sam Adams Triple Bock.  Not something Id drink all the time especially at this price, but definitely an interesting beer.

rich malt and toffee notes as well as some coffee and sweetalmost fruity like alcohol aroma in there as well, honestly have never smelt a beer like this before it is awesome though it has the sweet malt characters and coffee roastiness of a stout, but still this sweet deep grape/alcohol aroma is well presented as well that is much like a rich quadrupel aroma is a dark brown, first taste is so sweet and creamy mouthfeel, then it goes to this coffee toffee malt taste and finishes rather dry, but with all these tastes left, the sweet taste is that of like a grape juicee it is not at all just unfermented added sugar it is a juicy taste that goes well with the creamy juicy mouthfeel, I am blown away by this beer, with the mix of the toffee and roasty malt flavors with the oak lurking in the background the entire time, mixing with the sweet grape juice like taste, this beer is a treat and worth every dollar i paid, spectacular beer, I am going to go a step further even, with the complexity and unprecedented mixture of these flavors it is the best beer I have ever had, do not let the price tag hinder you, it is amazing
Complex taste but very similar to the bourbon barrel version in terms of carbonation. I was hoping for more, but it is still a very well made beer from a company that has a good barrel aging program.

The beer pours an ugly dark brown with not carbonation at all. I got no head rise, I heard the 08 had a carbonation problem, 09 too?

The aroma is relatively strong delivering a ton of vanilla on the nose with a finish that provides some nice depth with oak dominating followed by some distinct bourbon flavor. 

The taste is super super sweet. There is a ton of vanilla, which is nice, but probably too much here. BI BCS is a better example that provides the perfect amount. The vanilla would be more tolerable if it was better balanced out with other flavors. If there was big hit of oak or bourbon to break up the vanilla which really lasts to the end, then it could be ok.

The feel is pretty poor, its very light without much lasting flavor.

The drinkability is limited by its one-note-edness.

Overall, a little disappointed here. The bourbon is better than the brandy version, but the Grand Cru dominates, them both its not even funny. A couple minor changes and this could be really good.

On draft at Union Jacks poured black with very thin tan head.  Aroma of brandy and port wine.  Flavors of port wine and brandy were most dominant with dark fruits present and a hint of vanilla and wood notes.  A wonderful barleywine sipper.
Pour with no head and a deep mahogany color. Aroma was fruitful and soft. Taste was similar. Strong in the mouthful but not burning. Nice alcohol warming in the body. Its nice but not the greatest.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2011 14 June 2011, bottle. murky brown, no head. meaty, sweet meaty, faint sour notes. thin and faintly fizzy. tastes of raisin juice and alcohol. sugary and bourbon aged barley wine w/ sour competition. 

(original rating - 7,4,7,4,16 = 3.8)
24 March 2011 - bottle at Brewdog Bar Edinburgh. dark brown, looks really syrupy. great nose but something is missing. smells of soy sauce and plum juice. not too salty but not the nicest sweet aroma. full body and super syrupy. almost chocolate syrup feeling in the mouth. faint maple syrup, soft oaky notes, some chocolate milk tastes. really nice but not my cup of "tea"

A dark brown barley wine with a thin brown head. In aroma, a superb aroma of sherry, molasses, dark fruits, vinous, delightful. In mouth, a wondrous sherry like ale with molasses, chocolate, figs, warming alcohol, very sustained, rich and blended, at least 5 years old. And i still have a bottle of this...yeahh! Tasted March 12 2011 with Montreal crew.

Guest keg at BrewDog Edinburgh launch event. It had run out when I arrived, so HUGE thanks to cgarvieuk for saving me some! Funky nose. Boozy port, some cheese/barnyard stuff going on, too. Very dark brown, no head, ruby highlights. Chocolate, raisin, super-smooth, no alcohol burn. Very slight bitterness. Stunning.

2008 bottle shared by MrPickles - Yup, this sucker is flat. Popped the cork--sans pop--to pour a beautiful mahogany liquid topped by nothing--no head at all. Smells of raisins, brandy, leather. Its hot but not sharp, but really, really sticky sweet. Taste is toffee, leather, smoke, brandy, and oak. Again, real sweet, but thankfully not boozy. Real syrupy and hefty--this is one for the snifter to be sipped slowly. Id love a bottle with at least some bubbles to see what this would taste like carbonated. As it is, it was still a complex, interesting--though sugary--beer.

12.7 oz bottle, shared with Brenn79, into a snifter. Pours completely opaque mudpuddle brown with no head. Has an extremely thin collar of light beige foam. Ugggly! Aroma is strong in oak, brandy, chocolate-covered raisins, anise. Taste is sweet, sour and meaty with no bitterness. Beer is completely flat, however. Im not too keen on flat beers, although Im slowly starting to get used to them. Full-bodied and oily. Overall, a delicious beer that is brought down by its hideous appearance and lack of carbonation.

12.7 oz. bottle- Pours flat looking with no carbonation, it looks like dark muddy water. The aroma is up front red wine, then brandy and oak, plums, black cherries. The taste is sour, oak, brandy, and sweet, really sweet. The carbonation is low, almost nonexistant, body is full, finish is alcoholic.  Overall I dont usually like flat looking beers, but this is not horrible, but not really my thing.
0,375 l bottle. Something went wrong with this one. Strange aroma, acidic taste. This just cannot be what everyone is praising. Our bottle must be bad. We will try again sometime in the future :-(

0,375 l, 2009 vintage bottle as a gift, thanks nbutler11!
So, we had some problem with this bottle. It has an unpleasant acidic feeling both in aroma and flavor. Sad but true, we cannot drink it...Disappointing, very disappointing... :(

Tastes like a great beer thats gone flat.  Bottle pours almost black with no head.  Aroma dark fruits.  Taste very complex with dark fruits, dark chocolate, caramel and bourbon (I know it says brandy but tastes like bourbon to me).  Palate thick and rich.  Alcohol very apparent with nice burn on end.  Essentially no carbonation.  Boozy pleasant finish.  Unfortunately it tastes flat.  With some carbonation it would be one of the best beers Ive ever had.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 3-17-11.  Draft.  Brick Store Pub.  Complex chocolate.  Thick palate that delivers a rich experience.  The best.  Pub ran out three or four days after I got there.
5-22-11. 12.7 oz Bottle.  Headless.  Minimal lacing.  Coffee-colored.  
Aroma is bacterial sweaty sweats and rotting groceries, licorice cough syrup and woody note.
Taste is quite sour.  
Palate is watery with some fizz and definite stickiness.
Maybe its me, but this bottle isnt nearly as good as the draft and may be something wrong with it or- again - me.
7-9-11. 12.7 oz Bottle.  Headless.  Minimal lacing.  Coffee-colored. 
Aroma is roasted caramel, coffee, chocolate but with a sour twang.  Not good.
Taste is also sour. 
Palate is syrupy with very little carbonation.
Bottom line is that the sour ruins this beer.  It was not present in the draught.  No more dollar / ounce bottles of this.
Very special stuff. So intense. Great malt, caramel, tobacco and oak notes. Maybe a little too sweet wich makes it hard to drink more than a small glass. So this is an incredible beer to share!

Chocolate, leather and oak on the nose.  A medium brown with light off white head. A strong alcohol flavor with woody undertones. Medium mouthfeel with effervescent carbonation. Rasiny and oak notes make this an interesting ale once the alcohol tones down. Very smooth.

Bottle pours deep red/brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of sweet toasted caramel, oak, dried fruit, and brandy.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of figs, dates, vanilla, and a touch of oxidation. Overall body is full and viscous with some warming alcohol on the finish.

had at hunahpus day. pours a reddish brown. boozy vanilla and caramel nose. taste is brandy, nuts, caramel, and wood. a definate sipper but ohh so good. alcohol warms you up. overall an excellent beer. cant wait to try the bourbon barrel.
Glass on tap at Hunahpu 2011. Pours a dark ruby, sweet, delicious. This is very drinkable, sweet dark fruits. Another home run from Lost Abbey.

Bottle (2009 Vintage)...  Poured near black with no head.  Big sweet and malty nose.  Viscous and cloying with lots of dark brown sugars, caramel, creme brulee, and a mild cocoa-hazelnut tone.  A bit of a dark fruit-prune like tone in there too with a big boozy, malty finish.  Just wish it had some carbonation.

On tap at Papago last week in snifter from memory because I lost my fing notes.  Dark reddish brown with dense thick tan head.  Caramel sweet vanilla and some roast aroma.  Roasted caramel vanilla coffee nuts bready with woody roasted mildly bitter finish.  Extremely complex; extremely delicious.
Vanilla, cholocate aroma. Taste of vanilla, and red fruits, prunes. Strong alcohol aftertaste that should probably be better if aged more. Almost no carbonation.

750th rating. Smell of dark fruits, sweet caramel, chocolate. Black with a deep red hint. No head, not enough carbonation for sure. I hate that... Dark fruits, prunes, chocolate, alcohol, sweet caramel at the taste. Really sad about the gas-missing. A lot of alcohol at the aftertaste. A bit to liquorish, and to sweet, but decent brew.

Grabbed a smaller bottle of this, didnt note the ounces.  Maybe 10-12.  Corked.  Dark brown minimally carbonated beer with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of dark, dried fruits, chocolate/vanilla/caramel.  Very desserty.  Flavors make me think of a chocolate infused port.  Thick, oily, and extremely complex.  An out-of-this-world after dinner beer.  A real mind job.

375 ml bottle, stamped 2010 Brandy.  Pours a deep opaque brown with virtually no head.  Intense aroma, major oak with underlying vanilla, raisins, figs, and a touch of funk.  Dark fruits like raisins, figs, and plums dominate the start, the breandy really comes out in the middle and finishes with a slightly sour note, kind of like sour candy.  Syrupy,  this one could almost paste your lips together, has a definite cognac feel to it due to the lack of carbonation and burn.   Worth a try if you are wiling to pay.

Courtesy of magnus. Pours black with a tiny bubbly tanned head. Aroma is meaty, almost imperial but still excellent BW character. Madeira, vanilla, raisins and prunes. Fullbodied alcohol and fruity mf. Fruity, raisins, madeira flavor; fantastic good. Alcolic malty palate. Finishes a bit salty and balanced tart and dark fruity.
Draft at Local Option.   Nose of dark fruits.  Tastes of figs, cherries, dates, and other warming fruits.  A bit of inviting sour apple.  Too much going on to quantify.  Excellent.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2011 Rating #1: 2/22/2011 - Draft at The Porter. Pours dark cloudy brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is intense - loads of chocolate with a touch of cherries. Some woody boozey character along with earthy tobacco. Cocoa powder sprinkled over it all. Flavor is lightly fruity and very rich with chocolate and toffee as well as slight boozy character and slight big-red-wine character (like a red zin) in fruitiness, body, and dryness (that finishes with a soft tickle of acidity). Big and malty. Dry chocolatey vinous finish. Mouthfeel is drying with brisk bubbles and medium body that is quite velvety in texture. Overall, very interesting. Not what I expected, but quite good. (8,4,9,4,16). Rating #2: 4/18/2011 - caged and corked 375ml bottle. No pop or carbonation hiss when cork removed. Dark brown pour with hints of red - cloudy with no head. Aroma is intensely rich with molasses and maple and slight tart fruit acidity and some alcohol. Flavor starts intensely rich with caramel, chocolate, touches of cherry and grape, with light boozy notes - like sweet vermouth wit lots of malt sweetness. Rich in the finish with hints of licorice and vanilla and dark sweet malts. Boozy warm finish. Mouthfeel has touches of tingly bubbles - despite the flat appearance. Fully body that is surprisingly well-cut and lightened by the alcohol. Overall, a fantastic brew - very rich but still fairly drinkable (8,3,8,5,18).

Smells of chocolate, port, and bourbon.  Wonderful.  light brown head, dark dark brown, completely opaque.  Tastes like chocolate, subtle but lovely alcohol, caramel and cherry tones.  Aboslutely wonderful palate, nice and thick.  clean finish.  Wonderful, wonderful beer.

Bottle from 09. Poured a dark opaque brown. Nose is boozy , sherry port wine. Mouthful has the consistency of port wine. Almost no carbonation flavor is rich and intense. A blast of the barrel a hint of fizz. A touch sweet with dark fruit. The barrel carries a lot of the flavor but its backed up by a full bodied beer. . More than worth a try. Almost sublime.

Burgundy colored body was very still, and displayed no carbonation at all.  The beer sat in the glass looking just like a red wine.  Fearing a bad seal in the cork, I smelled the beer, but could not detect any heavy oxidation aromas, so the flatness seemed to be by design.  The smell was very vinous, and reminded me of raisins soaked in whiskey.  The taste was sweet and oaky, with lots of vanilla and raisins, and no hops.  This was pretty much a red wine through and through, and was not at all like any other beer.  The body was dense and still, and made for a nice sippping beverage.

2009 Brandy Barrel version. Dark brown pour with pretty much no head. HInts of vanilla, caramel, dark fruit, oak, and a bit of brandy come across the nose. Flavor matches the aroma with the sweetness from the malts coming through a bit more. It finishes with a slight alcohol burn that compliments the beer well.

2010 - At first I didnt like it. I wondered where this faint tartness was coming from and it wasnt pleasant cause this beer had no carbonation. But I let it warm and then I really enjoyed it. It was over my head I think. Total complexity. All the things you want in a american strong...dark oaky, rich malts, sweet yet balanced. There was definitely a sutle tartness about this beer. And it was slightly bitter on the finish. Showed it weight in alcohol when you drank it but wasnt overpowering. Chewy mouthfeel, especially without carbonation....which I enjoyed for this brew. I was surprised to find bourbon barrel qualities when it was the brandy barrel angels share. Maybe I dont know enough about brandy. Alot of vanilla up front. A super confusing beer that, in the end, won my heart.

375ml bottle, this was determined to be the 2010 batch.  Hugely boozy, bourbon barrel nose, notes of vanilla, cherry, brown sugar, wood, earthiness, brown malt sweetness, raisin and faint fruity tartness.  Opaque dark brown color, head is nearly non-existent.  Flavor is likewise strongly redolent of bourbon, very sweet and malty, moderately alcoholic with plenty of bourbon barrel character and sugary, dark malty sweetness.  Very low in carbonation (famously so) , warming and fiery on the palate, body is hugely full.  Certainly good enough, but Im not sure what all the fuss is about...

375ml bottle, Brandy barrel 2010.  Pours flat murky dark brown, nearly black in the glass.
