Powerful aroma of overripe dark fruits, raisins, a lot of fig and prune, black currants, strong vanilla notes, oak, with underlying leather, dark-fired perique and burley tobaccos.  Excellent strength.  Flavor is sweet and strong with all the dark fruits found in the nose and then some, along with molasses, caramel, vanilla, oak, anise, some definite wine-like qualities.  Alcohol has a warming effect but is integrated well without being too hot or solvent.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, sticky, zero carbonation.  A fantastic brew, but the lack of carbonation keeps it from reaching its full potential.  Almost want to look at this more in the perspective of a fine wine than a beer given the flavor & aroma profile and the appearance & mouthfeel.  Still, very glad to have tried it at least once...unfortunately the high price tag will make it difficult to revisit anytime soon.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 2009 on tap at Churchills anniversary. 

The appearance was alluring. It poured a deep dark brown with a burgundy copper hue with a thin off white lacing. The color lent a bit of mystique as to how it would smell and taste. After a few seconds of looking at all I could think was, "man I hope this beer tastes as complex as it looks!"

This beer smells like Caramel and bourbon with chocolate in the background and oak. A slight hint of vanilla and maple syrup are present as well.

The taste can be compared to a beer version of wonkas everlasting gobstopper. For the first second it was bourbon, followed immediately by caramel, then a nutty oak with a little smoke, finished with a slight bit of vanilla and more oak. The longer I kept it in my mouth the more the profile would change and develop. I tried to let it sit for a while but unlike wonkas gobstopper this treat did come to an end (an empty glass).

Mouthfeel was prefect. It has a rich silky feel at first and transitions to an almost savory feel if that makes sense.

The drinkability is top notch. I drank it as slow as I could but it didnt last more than 15 minutes and I was in great company too but nothing could stop me from plowing through it.

Angels share is One of the most complex beers I have ever had. I have a few bottles tucked away in my cellar and I cant wait to do some vertical tasting with the different vintages of brandy and bourbon aged varieties!!

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2012 Bomber Bottle. (2008) Pours deep, brown/amber with absolutely no head and no lacing. Aroma is absolutely insane; chocolate, raisins, roasted malt, walnut, barley, sour brandy, cherries and hints of vanilla, honey, and coffee. Body is completely unique. Not quite, full, more of a robust, bold, warm mouthfeel. Finish is insanely long and beautiful. Maybe the best barleywine out there.

bottle.  2010?  orange lettering.  deep opaque brown with no head.  viscous pour and oily looking.  aroma of vanilla, oak, chocolate, nougat and caramel.  flavor of vanilla, caramel, butter, brandy, nutty, nougat.  full body and velvety.  smooth as butter.  the palate is incredible.  english style BW that rivals(if not pinnacles) the best of them.  i now believe the hype!  wow.

2009 bottle Ive had for so long I dont remember where I got it or who gave it to me. 11.5% ABV, so thats how I could tell it apart from my Bourbon Barrel version of The Angels Share. Pours a deep, murky brown color with some brighter highligts around the sides and visible sediment toward the end. No carbonation or head. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, vanilla, brown sugar, oak, brandy, cherries and other berry fruits, raisins, and chocolate. Very sweet and big on the barrel notes. More warmth from the alcohol shows up in the flavor, along with dark fruits (grapes, cherries, berries, raisins), vanilla, toffee, oak, soy, and chocolate. Medium-full bodied, with virtually no carbonation and a sweet, chewy mouthfeel. The flatness didnt really bother me that much, as this big barrel-aged barleywine can get away with it more than a lot of other styles. Nice, sweet, savory sipper.

Bottle @ Unibar, Århus. Pours black with a light reddish tone along edges, no head, but leaves laces on the glass. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, toffee, chocolate, coffee, caramel, port. Taste is very complex with bourbon, good ruby port, bitter coffee, raisins, toffee, oak, vanilla, english licorice, each sip adds something new. Full body, very low carbonation, silky mouthfeel, long finish. Overall this is a great beer, a sipper,and a little on the sweet side. 220111

Dark reddish brown, no head, none, looked like port in the glass. Aroma of dark fruit, raisons, vanilla, and a slight mustiness I presume from the oak. Complex, raisons, fig, dates, vanilla, caramel, molasses, wood. Alcohol hidden very well, excellent beer, but a tad too sweet for my liking, I wonder if some age in the bottle would dry it a touch.

375ml Bottle.  Pours mahogany with no head. Nose is alcohol, dried fruit, bourbon, and slight maltiness, not unlike a port wine.  Taste is much the same, bourbon, currant, vanilla and oak, slight toffee malt and lightly bitter dry finish.

2010 vintage.  No pop, or any sound for that matter when I popped the cork.  Poured a dark murky brown, just about opaque.  Zero head and no sign of any carbonation whatsoever.  Wow, what a nose.  Easily one of the best smelling brews I have come across in quite some time.  Immaculate mix of light bourbon, maybe its brandy, semi-sweet malts, oak and excellence.  Flavors were, in essence, the aroma kicked up a notch or two.  Beautifully nuanced bourbon notes throughout, hints of oak, and sweet malts.  Good bit of heat in the finish but welcomed in every way.  This is the nectar of the gods, just Heavenly.  The total lack of carbonation didnt bother me a bit.  A+.

Pours a dark reddish brown with minimal carbonation. At first the aroma was that of a sweet barleywine, but as it warmed it smelled and tasted like a well-aged port. Each sip gets better and smoother. Prunes, raisins and dates simmered in a fruity red wine. Delicious.

Another great beer by a great brewery.  This one courtesy of Clingman71 via Binnies in Chicago.  An incredibly complex and delicious beer with aromas of raisons, vanilla, malt and oak.  The flavors of this beer ranged from raisons and dates to vanilla, oak and spice.  Sweet, fruity and big, this is one great Barleywine!
Bottle 2008 vintage. Dark brown body with absolutely no head. Aroma is raisins, dates, dried fruit, oak and alcohol. Flavor is raisins, dates, caramel, sourish notes alcohol, oak and vanilla.

31-DEC-2010, 2008 bottle 375 ml from "Fish & Beer".
Brown with no head.
What is this?
It is sour...
...like red wine with almost no carbonation.
long sour red wine aftertaste. Overripe cherries.
Barrels? I cannot quite nail it. Bourbon? Or perhaps more likely cognac?
I cannot help being a tad disappointed. It ends thin and is not very complex.
The others are off for another brew...
...I am still wandering if it is meant to be sour?
I can see that a few others have mentioned it here, so I guess it is not due to poor storage conditions at home.
Perhaps I should retaste with a more recent vintage?

2008 - aged 2 years...Pours deep mahogany into a snifter. No head on vigorous pour, but foam hugs rim. Strong vanilla and oak aromas. Thin with raisins, dates and brandy-soaked pit fruits upfront turning to licorice and vanilla in the dry, lasting finish.

Poured from 375 ml bottle at Lost Abbey.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, caramel.  Tastes of bourbon, vanilla, caramel.  An amazing beer...one of the best I have had.  Tomme got plenty of grief for the prior vintages that shipped flat.  This one had some carbonation, but who really needs it...this beer is a flavor explosion.

2009 bottle. Completely flat. Muddy dark brown red. Strong boozy aroma, smells like bourbon to me, though this is the regular AS; sweet raisins and bourbon. Very sweet raisiny flavor. Even completely flat, a standout in the barleywine category. Very similar to Founders Backwoods Bastard, but flatter and more densely concentrated sweetness. Sappy Slappy Bastard? This has the mouth drying, dehydrating quality of hard liquors. The heat is a natural part of the flavor. Very nice, I dont know what everyone was bitching about.

2010 Bottle shared by JB/customercopy. Pours a dark mahogany with a ring of beige bubbles clinging to the glass. The nose is very boozy; lots of sweet bourbon with just a touch of malt backing. Medium-bodied and flat with a mildy drying and lightly bitter finish. Tasty but surprisingly uncomplicated: mostly sweet and malty with a whole lot of bourbon. This is a tasty beer but I couldnt justify 20 bucks for a 375 ml.

Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Nose fills with cherry wine, marzipan, raisins and prunes. Whiffs of sherry, vanilla and oak. A clear amber body with no head. Sweet on the heavy side,there is also acidity and alco warmth in this full bodied, syrupy concoction

375mL bottle (2009 edition) shared by bmanning at a recent tasting.

A: Dark brown with very little head. Some head after a bit of agitation.

S: Brandy, oak, dark sugars, dark fruits, and a bit of alcohol. Very nice complexity.

T: Very similar to the nose, but a little heavy on the alcohol at this point. A greater emphasis on the brandy than in the nose.

M: Didnt really have any carbonation issues--this one fits about right considering the style and alcohol level. A bit boozy, my only complaint at this point.

D: Very drinkable for how hot it was. Nice and complex, this is a good one to savor for a while.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-17-2010

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2010 375mL bottle, pours dark reddish brown with a tiny beige head. Aroma of bourbon, smoke / peat, wood, caramel malt, brown sugar - amazing complexity. Flavour is reminiscent of that of a fine brandy - brown sugar, oak, vanilla, and molasses. Almost no carbonation. Definitely a rare treat.
2008 vintage and Mikeys tasting. Pours dark brown. Nose and taste of toffee, oak, licorice, vanilla and booze. A little flat, but tasty.

2008 A strange one this was. Completely flat. A lot more sour than I expected, perhaps coming from the huge amounts of oak aroma and flavour that were in this. So sour in fact i was beginning to wonder whether I might have gotten a bad bottle, still quite drinkable and enjoyable none the less. Need to rerate, a different vintage perhaps.

750 mL bottle, 2007 version sampled Nov 2010: dark brown garnet gold colored body...strong tan head that leaves wisps...oaky vanilla aroma with strong alcohol malts and slightly tart cherries.  Soft cherry flavors that ebb to and from tartness. Slightly bitter vanilla notes and honeycomb tartness.  This is wonderful and 3 years is perfect for timing!!

2009, brandy barrel, opened to celebrate my wifes birthday.  Its a walnut brown beer with lovely ruby highlights and, as expected with no pop of the cork, there is no head - just a few watery bubbles.  But, as if to make up for this, the legs are impressive indeed, looking like a fine spirit.  And the nose!  What a nose!  Its heavily wooded and as heavily drenched in brown sugar, maple syrup and molasses.  As the beer breathes this aroma grows port-like and so very nutty.  These notes carry through to the palate, but here the brandy is felt, both in taste and in the alcohol heat.  I really enjoyed the chest burn from this; something so spirited needs the booze just to cut through some of the saturated flavour.  The body is very thick and, yes, completely flat.  I thought the 2008 Older Viscosity was a shameful beer to have no carbonation in; but here the lack of fizz is well suited.  The finish is sweet, woody and theres just a bit of a salty Dutch liquorice thing going on.  It easily lives up to the hype and happily in this case the brewers indulgence has produced a very indulgent beer.

0.75l 2008 - The nose lets you know what youre in for.  The raisins and yeast are mixed with a massive boozy note.  There is no carbonation, looking like a flat cola in the glass.  The dominant flavor is cream to me, maybe nutty.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 2009 vintage, 11.5% ABV. 375 mL bottle from West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, served in a snifter. Pours hazy chestnut with no head. The nose has aromas of brandy, oak, vanilla, molasses, raisins and cola. The flavour is intensely sweet with a strong brandy quality. The finish is long and malty with a slightly alcoholic feel and hints of spice and cola. It is full in body with an oily texture and no carbonation. Overall, a very nice barley wine. It is smooth, mellow and very brandy-esque. The malts are big, heavy and very complex with notes of raisins and molasses. Vanilla notes complement nicely. The brandy barrels used for aging are quite apparent. A fine choice for a cold winters night by the fire. 2010-10-23

2010 vintage. 37.5 cL bottle from the Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, served in a branded stem. Pours dark chestnut with virtually no head. On the nose, there are big notes of molasses, vanilla and oak, along with a hint of brandy and a touch of earthy hops. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout, with vanilla, molasses, raisins, toasty notes, brandy and earthy hops. The finish is long and roasty with a touch of brandy. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and almost no carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent barley wine. A very nicely constructed brew, much more subtle than the bourbon version. Oak and brandy complement the brew, rather than dominating it.

impervious to light black color (i used my flashlight), just a few bubbles float on top of the brew, no lace.  nose is fruity with the brandy barrel playing a prominent role.  once the brandy barrel begins to fade, dried fruit flavors become apparent and linger.  medium bodied, fruity finish.  quiteenjoyable, but not a favorite style of mine.  sampled at FoBAB 09.

375ml corked and caged. Pour murky dark brown, almost black, with small head. Aroma is brandy cocoa, molasses, vanilla extract, chocolate pecan pie, oak, white grapes, strong boozy backbone. Taste is rich and intense - cocoa toffee molasses syrup swirling with gamey flavors into a warming brandy burn down throat.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2011 Bottle thx to Magnus/Hjalmar, cons 2011-02-26 Göteborg
New. plum cake in aroma and flavor new rating 4,0
New average: 4,2

Sample from bottle at SBWF 2010, cons 2010-10-08, Nacka 
AP: pitch black, no head
AR: honey, roasted coffee, cholcolate
F: alcholic, honey, roasted coffee, chocolate, full body, steawberry??

Bottle, 2008.  Opened the bottle with no pop from the cork whatsoever.  Pours nearly black with zero carbonation, a couple of bubbles, but no head.  Smells great with oak and vanilla coming through with an overall sweet and boozy aroma.  Taste is oak, vanilla, and dark fruits with a decent amount of booze.  Mouth feel is flat and watery, leaving me wanting more.  Overall pretty enjoyable.

Poured from 12oz. bottle into a Dogfish Head snifter glass.

The color is a complete black with no highlights and no head or no lacing.

The smell is a bit grape in flavor with a nice molasses flavor. Some hints of coffee flavor comes out to take this beer on to the next stage.

The taste is really strong with a nice brandy warming flavor. It has great deep oak flavor that comes up on you in a quick minute. There are hints of coffee grounds, cola syrup, dark malts, motor oil, brandy, and a full bodied cigar.

The feel of beer is heavy bodied, and its best to be prepared for it. It will sneak up on you if you take it too lightly. It slowly goes into a gradual lowering of flavor. It hits then drops, slowly with a smooth texture and a nice kick. It is the beer you will talk about for time to come.

Near black, very little head. Sweet, alcohol aroma. Sweet flavor of toffee and alcohol. Not particularly beer-like, more like a toffee-flavored Kahlua. Might need to age. I think this is a 2010 bottle.

Wanted to try this one for a while, therefore muchos gracias to my friend dEnk, who brought this along today. Extremely full aroma with loads of leather, brandy, vanilla and slightly salty. Strange afterburn. Very thick bodied and in-your-face brew. Slightly flat though.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2010 09 Bottle @ home to celebrate my graduation. Aroma is absolutely huge and intense with bread, sweetness, peat, wood, liquorice, fruit, brandy, oak, vanilla, roasted malt, chocolate and much more. Touch of alcohol.
Flavour is intense creamy syrupy sweetness. There is an alcohol note, but in a good way, like a very smooth single malt. Very malty, roasty, smoky, peaty, woody, brandy, caramel and much more.
My expectations were not too high but this actually is some good stuff.
Still way too expensive here in Holland, but at least it is a very nice experience. You can only drink so much though.

All round rating at the Kernel Brewery with Evin. 

Pure bourbon and brandy on aroma; death black opaque appearance, tar leather, brandy schnapps, sweet wild berries, excellent balance, dark malts, really thick rich and guey chocolate, a master piece by an awesome brewer. Definitely lives up to its reputation. This one can be laid down too.

2009 edition bought from Beermerchants. Cheers.

1 oz sample at the GABF.  Dark, cloudy, no head. Woody, vanilia, carmel, sour white grape aroma. Sweet taste with a plum/dark fruits, and clover.  Low carbonation, alcohol burn. Dry, thin, medium body.

Bottle, shared at the post-GCBF gathering. Viscous dark brown, dense brown crown. Rich bourbony-vanilla figgy aroma. Richly flavoured palate, treacle, cocoa, figs, cigar box, vanilla, wood. Velvety and warming. Again, the rest of the crowd was not impressed with the barrel-aging thing, but I loved it! More for me!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: This is not for chugging. Pours a luscious creamy dark brown with a thin tan head that lasts throughout. The aroma is whiskey, wine, fruity, caramel, some booze.  The flavor is a bunch of stuff all coming together in a wonderful way. The oak and  vanilla comes through along with some fruit and of course the brandy. It becomes more complex as it warms so pour it into a snifter and let it mellow a bit.

Bottle 2008. Dark, slightly murky, brown pour no head. Lots of barrel aging up front in the aroma, brandy, oak, grapes. Followed closely by honey and cherry and a bit of aniseed. Taste is quite sweet, lots of honey, some winey grape/plum flavors in here as well. Palate is completely flat, it really could have used some carbonation, and quite a bit of very enjoyable spirit-like alcohol warmth.

12. 7 ounce bottle, 2009.  Very dark brown, almost black.  Very minimal head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, caramel, oak and vanilla.  Tastes very sweet, sherry like.  Not much carbonation.  Strong alcohol taste.  Didnt quite get it, will try again.

Shared bottle with Bernt at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. 2009 vintage. Pours murky dark brown, like coke, with almost no head at all. Big aroma of sweet malts, caramel ,chocolate, port, vanilla and raisins.Taste follows up the aroma in all matters, big malty sweet body, feels like a port in the mouth, some sweet delights in here as well. Well hidden alcohol. Lingering medium sweet end. This is a beer for long evenings.

Found a 12oz 2009 bottle of this at Total Wine and shared it with a good friend. It poured jet black with 0 carbonation, head, or lacing. The aroma is booze, coffee, dark chocolate and oak. It tastes fantastic. Smooth bitter chocolate, oak and bitter coffee linger on your palate. The alcohol is obvious but not overpowering. Unfortunately the bottle I got had zero carbonation in it which Ive heard is common for this year. This would have been almost a perfect beer had it not been completely flat. That said it was still fantastic and Ill pick it up again if I can find it.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2011 Opened a bottle sent to me by Changeup45! This stuff is just incredible and I have a hard time finding any fault in this beer except for the minor carbonation issues.  The oak, vanilla, fruit, and brandy come together to create something very special.  Always looking for another bottle. 
Bottled shared by Tmoney at Natifest 10.  
Poured basically flat no bubbles or head.  But the flavor was so damn good that I barely even noticed the lack of carbonation. Aroma and flavor are filled with sweet malts and fruit with the perfect amount of oak and brandy.  One of the more complex beers Ive had the pleasure of tasting.  [8/4/9/4/17]

Bottle.  Blackish-red with a thick visual ... the aroma could battle a meatloaf for beefiness.  This drinks with a wicked whiskey-laden woodiness, the copious alcohol clearly evident.  Not for the meek.  (#3982, 9/12/2010)

100th Review! Bottle - 12.5% 2008: Pours a Dark Brown, with a very very subtle beige head, into a snifter. Aroma is that big bourbon , coupled with some caramel malt sweetness. Nice chewy taste, very mild bitterness, Flavors are chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, port, caramel malt, nice mouthfeel, by far my favorite Barley Wine thus far. Its really no contest
Bottle. Barrel nose, wooden, bourbon vanilla. Black no head. Port and stout  base, sweet bourbon. Mellow  mouthfeel. Inoffensive barrel-focussed beer

Had this the same day as the Bourbon barrel edition.  I must say they are both perfect in there own way.  This brew though not as tasty has a god like mouth feel and really is the epitome of American craft beer genius.

"im grading the Brandy Barrel (standard) Angels Share, but it hasnt been 10.5% since 2006. 11.5 in 07, and mine (08) came in at 12.5, same as the bourbon barrel. the funny thing is, the massive amounts of malt used still brought out vanilla/oak characteristics of bourbon aging, but sans the pepper. In addition to that, this was easily the darkest barleywine ive ever seen, althought the 12 months (not 6) it spent in barrels renders the beer style nearly obselete. beyond the obvious, the warming effect of the alcohol was very pleasant, although at first i though it was going to be a little hot. the tobacco/cigar flavor added an unexpected level of complexity to the malt, vanilla, and sweet raisin flavors. This is a great sipper, surprisingly not cloyingly sweet, given the aroma and lack of hops in the flavor. no issues here. best...cigar...beer...ever? different bottle 12/09-the tobacco still there a little in the aroma but not so much in the flavor. more brandied fruitcake, and a touch hotter. still excellent, but slipped JUST enough to let the Bourbon Barrel surpass it."

Out of a tulip glass at Rose and Crown in Palo Alto. Pours an opaque black with a big brown head. Sweet, strong bourbon with rich dried fruit on the finish. Alcohol on the mouthfeel, a little burn and nice blanket like covering. In addition to the bourbon and fruit, some roast and chocolate on the finish.

2009 12oz bottle-

Looks like murky grape juice. Smells like expired grapes and rubbing alcohol. Tastes like root beer and beets.

2009 - $17 for a 12 oz bottle bought in Illinois.

Appearance is a deep red to brown to black. Aroma is fart, grappa, and a dog in heat. Flavor is menstrual blood and lots of sugar. Lots of sugar. Beets, prunes, purple grapes, black olives. I think they over did it with the sugar.

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours dark brown with no head or carbonation.  Aroma of toffee and caramel, and same flavor  Strong caramel finish.  Thick texture, but needs carbonation.  Still an amazing beer

12.7oz bottle, 2009 version.  Pours a dark brown black with a little fizz for a head that quickly disappears completely.

The aroma is dark fruits, bready chocolate and molasses, some vanilla and a harsh medicinal alcohol.

The flavor is sweet sugary plums and figs and vanilla with some bready malts and a harsh alcoholic bitter finish.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with no carbonation.

Overall, its interesting with a lot of complex flavors, but its way too over the top for me, esp in alcohol and sweetness - more like a liquor than a beer.  Tastes a  bit like plum or fig cough medicine.

2008 (last years) vintage (not the new release). 375ml bottle into DFH snifter.

A - Open with a loud "pop". Poured aggressively so there was a huge head. Black with a frothy tan head that leaves a good amount of lacing behind. The head is very sticky and hangs on to the side of the glass.

S - Dark fruit, boozy bourbon, chocolate. Smells very smooth and complex...a lot more then I can describe in a review. A sweet smell fills the nose after the initial notes fade.

T - Wow. Very good. Plums, raisins, milk chocolate, malts, dark cherry, smooth bourbon flavor. Better then I expected, truthfully. 

M - Medium bodied, fizzy carbonation, rich, creamy, smooth. Great to swirl around in your mouth and savor. 

D - Very smooth for the style and barrel aging. Easy to drink, alcohol is smooth and subtle, very smooth. Lost Abby hits a HR on this one. Very good.
Aroma was sweet with a lot of malt. Taste is very good full of flavor. Nice sipping brew. Palate was good. I would definate try again.

Definitely pours a deep brown with virtually no head.  Aroma is caramel malt and a wine-like sweetness - malt and wine. Taste matches - definitely a very sweet brew that lingers. Gets better as it warms. Very nice, no doubt.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2014 bottle at natifest 2010.    Pours a hazy, murkey brown with little to no head.    Aroma is oak, sweet malts, and brown sugar.  Notes of bourbon, vanilla, and molasses.  Palate is strong, breaking out a alcohol flavor.  Really, really good.

Bottle. Poured reddish brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy dark fruit, toasted malt, alcohol and wood aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Moderate to heavy dark fruit bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy dark bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a complex standout beer.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2010 2009 375ml bottle.  What a wicked brew from Lost Abbey.  It poured dark brown with no head.  This demon is awash with a multitude of flavors.  Its sweet and I got big raisin, fig, carmel, vanilla, and molasses notes.  This beer has some port or sherry qualities about it.  Good stuff...

(Bottled, sampled 2010-03-02) Very dark amber with no head. Intensive, sweet-raisinu, oaky and liquourish, warming, smooth-alcoholic nose. Lots of raisiny-fruity, grainy malt in the flavor, with vanilla, syrup, and warming alcohol. Aftertaste dries a bit, no roastiness. Quite full body, almost no CO2, alcohol warming for long in the aftertaste. Very tasty, complex, and (despite the sweetness) a balanced barley wine.

Bottle 2009 vintage thanks to JohnGalt1. Pours out a brown topped with a ring of a head. Aroma was so awesome sweet caramel, vanilla, brandy, and toffee. Taste was more of the barrel lots of vanilla, sweetness, caramel, a little pit fruit, and the alcohol definitely shows through.
Vanilla bourbon notes dominate, malty smooth, dark blue in color, lacing and hed average. 10th of 10 movie in July in Chicago.  98%

Ominously deep brown body with a slight reddish tint.  Soft light tan head.  Abundant fruit and oak on the nose along with a strong brandy note and light vanilla character.  Very hearty malt body that immediately brings wood and warm brandy flavors along with the deep brown sugar sweetness, caramel, figs, raising, and toffee segueing to the tart finish.

The Lost Abbey The Angels Share is amazing. It pours out a dark brown like cola. It has absolutely no head and has no carbonation. The aroma of was outstanding. It exudes brandy undertones with molasses, plum, and brown sugar. The flavor was more skewed towards raises, brandy, and caramel and this is definitely a sipper. Sip this beer through and through. It has a great body as well. You would think that the lack of carbonation would hurt the beer, but it doesnt. It seems to work just fine in this brew. Its a pretty strong beer, and I didnt really notice the taste of the alcohol at all although it did have a slight burn as it was going down. Sip this while eating some dark chocolate type dessert and itll really shine. Again, this was simply an amazing drink.
Poured a 12.7 oz bottle from 2010 into a snifter. Amazing caramel and vanilla presence- not to forget the smooth oaked bourbon flavor. Drink slow and enjoy. Worth paying a few extra $
Black pour with little head. Thick nose of malts, creaminess, and slight booze. Thick delicous flavors of malts, dried fruits (dates and raisins) and a toffee/vanilla/cream. Addictive mouthfeel.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of cascading foam medium sized brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque dark brown colored body and a good lacing. The strong aroma was malty and licorice. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mildly vinous dark malt and hops. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Pours a murky brown liquid with no head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit, caramel, vanilla, with hints of chocolate.  Sweet chocolaty caramel taste up front.  Then a nice hit of bitterness with dark fruit and some more velvety chocolate on the back end.  Vanilla throughout and on the aftertaste.  Very complex and tasty brew.  The alcohol comes through a bit and gives it a bite.  But otherwise a top brew.

Brandy barrel version, tasted side by side with the bourbon.  Dark fruit, sweet brandy, and caramel toffee tastes meld well together, while two seperate brews this one blended better and seemed like a more well put together brew.

375ml, corked & caged bottle, 2009 edition from bev4less. pours a thick, rich, cider-brown with a razor thin beige head leaving a tight ring of bubbles around the edges. aroma is absolutely wonderful, one of the best ive experienced, with huge notes of rich toffee (like the inside of a praline shop!), chocolate, and caramel malts with rich, sweet fruit notes of dried apricot, fig, and berry backed by oak, vanilla/coconut icing, and a touch of spicy, warming brandy. flavor is fantastic as well with big, sweet notes of warm praline, butterscotch, and woody vanilla up front backed by dried fruit notes of raisins and figs with notes of port coming through late and finishing with hints of coffee and a bold alcohol warmth. palate is full bodied and very rich with very little carbonation but i feel it really works with this beer. overall, a rich, sweet, and boozy barley wine for sure but at the same time its elegant and complex and worth every penny.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 On draft @ local option...

Aroma is pure bourbon. Flavor is even more bourbon but with some nice malt sweetness balancing things out. Not overly thick or oily and well carbonated which makes it surprisingly easy to drink especially when you factor in the strong bourbon elements, and the overall high ABV.

Im not huge fan of bourbon barrel aged beers, but I would drink this again anytime. Very tasty!
Pours dark brown with a thin head. Aroma is caramel, dark fruit, vanilla, oak. Flavor is concentrated dark berries, chocolate, cocoa, and a hint of alcohol. An extremely complex beer.
08 bottle pours almost black. Aroma is rich and deep chocolate and malt. This beers flavor is complex and wonderul with a rich and sweet yet non-cloying finish. Fantastic.
UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 Pours dark and thick. Aroma is sweet with caramel and some alcohol. taste of caramel, dark chocolate, raisins and ofc some alcohol. very nice mouthfeel with a dry end.

09 bottle from CAH.  Pours turbid blackish w minimal off white head.  Nose is oaky bourbon, prune, vanilla, plum, blackberry, port...great nose here.  Tastes rich, malty, with prune, plum, blackberry, cacao, some cloying molasses, and nuts.  Thins out late, and good but not as good as advertised.
Bottle thanks to Tampabrew: Poured a reddish brown to black with no head. The aroma is boozy, woodsy, and vanilla. Taste was sweet dark chocolate, caramel malt, oak, and vanilla mix.

Bottle.

A - Very dark mahogany, almost black, with a smaller than average, tight, foamy light beige head. Disappears pretty fast leaving a bit of patchy lacing.

S - Rich alcohol dominates the nose with brandy dominant, but some rum also sneaks in. Good amount of oakiness. Some dark chocolate and caramel malt also in there with some cherry and grape aroma with other dark fruits (plum and fig) with a slight tart/vinous aroma.

T - Very strong brandy taste with a lot of grape, plum, and fig dark fruit flavors. Quite a vinous taste to it. Starts off a bit more sweet and jamy with the dark fruit and this gives way to the brandy taste. Some dark malt and a bit of earthiness and roasted flavor, but this is really a background flavor.

M - Medium body with little carbonation. Very smooth and slick feeling. 

D - Brandy and alcohol flavor is a little too strong for me to really consider it all that drinkable. Not horribly drinkable, but not bad.

Notes: Vintage 2008. This picked up a lot of the brandy flavor and is a very vinous beer. Hints of dark malt come out, but it is really an afterthought. I wasnt overly impressed by this one, but it was decent. Would probably be great if you like brandy, but that isnt necessarily me (I dont hate it, but just not really a fan of it).

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Bottle, 2009. Pours a dark, amber-brown with a creamy, beige head. Plenty of sweet malts in the aroma, with wood, alcohol and some ripe fruits. Flavor is very sweet and bold, with caramel, toffee, raisins, some light chocolate. Full-bodied with soft carbonation and vinous texture. Really nice overall. (4.2)Bottle at THE Barley Wine Tasting, London. This was one of my contributions. Pours dark brown with no head. Sugary aroma, brown sugar, light soy sauce, soy sauce, dark fruits, prunes. Big sweet flavor with some dark malts, massive dark fruits, prunes, figs, dates, light cocoa, brown sugar. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Faintly warming finish with big sweetness, rich brown sugar and toffee, figs and dates. Quite a bit of complexity. Not overly sweet. Quite beautiful and robust (4.2)

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

2009 vintage. The beer pours dark brown with only a few bubbles. Looks like this is one of the flat Lost Abbey beers. The aroma is brandy, oak, maple and alcohol. The flavor is even better with a lot of maple notes as well as some oak. You also get a lot of vanilla, brandy, dark fruit chocolate and alcohol. Very low to flat carbonation and a medium to thick mouthfeel. Even with the bottle conditioning issues, this beer was very good. It was sampled side-by-side with a 2010 Bourbon Angels Share and this beer was superior in my opinion due to the strong maple notes.

Bottle shared with Michele @ The Dome. 2008. The beer is brown, bright and with burgundy hues, and a cappuccino like veil of foam covers it all. The nose is very intense and complex. Lovely cocoa powder, very vinous, a lot of berries and a slight apricot note, a bit boozy as it warms up. Just a hint of oaky vanilla.  The flavours are a bit overwhelmed by a strong acidity. It is nevertheless very fruity and caramelized, with somewhat leathery notes. Silky and very attenuated. Challenging but  nice.

Clearly there is love and effort put into this beer.  Dare I call it the pinnacle of The Lost Abbey?  But to me it does not stand alone as one of the best in the world.  There is complexity in the mouth:  dried and tropical fruit, caramel and cotton candy.  But the sweetness is overwhelming - it is missing depth.

Had from 375ml bottle - 2009 vintage.  Pours dark brown, with maybe a hint of red with absolutely no carbonation or bubbles.  Aroma is of fruit, alcohol, oak, and malts.  Flavor is complicated, but being flat, leaves much to be desired.  Overly sweet, syrup-like, with flavors of caramel, raisins, malts, alcohol and wood.  Leaves a sticky film behind and finishes with sugar and alcohol.  Really expected much more from this brew.

This poured a very dark red to brown color with basically no head. Aroma was lots of oak and alcohol some fruitness, dark chocolate, and toffee. Flavors was several different layers of port, dark fruits, currants, caramel and coffee, and lots of booze. Excellent stuff.

Bottle.
Oak, maple syrup, some hops lurking underneath. Nectar. Very oaky.
Smoke and chocolate.
Dark brown almost black in color. Smells really strong like caramel and butterscotch. Also can taste the really strong alcohol. A pretty good beer.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2010 From a 2008 750ml bottle,Black in color,no head,Coconut notes yet burbon has a strong smell and taste,vanilla is also tasted as well.Its worth the money

12.5% abv. Served cold from bottle. Aroma is caramel, alcohol, dark fruit, soy sauce. Black in color with minimal head. Sweet flavor mimics aroma, alcohol, brandy, caramel and soy sauce. Silky texture. Finish is slightly astringent.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2010 Rerate bottle, vintage 2008, kindly shared by gunnar. Dark brown colour, low head. Very strong aroma with loads of malty sweetness and molasses (too much). Flavour much like the 2009 vintage. Original rating: 12.7 Oz. corked and wired bottle, as The Lost Abbey Angels Share, 2009 vintage, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 11.5%. Nearly black colour, low tan head. Strong sweetish fusel aroma bordering on "sickly",  strong oaky notes. Moderate carbonation in the glass. Intense sweet and malty flavour with strong notes of oak, dark dried fruits and old sherry, partly balanced by noticeable hops in the finish. Oaky aftertaste.

Another awesome beer shared by the legendary footbalm 
Appearance: Black with no head, some legs left on the side of the glass 
Aroma: Vanilla, oak and caramel 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel. Vanilla, oak and dark fruits 
Great Barley Wine. This is just a great beer to sip on and enjoy.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Nose of caramel, sweet malts, brown sugar, oatmeal, bread dough, and foliage. Pours muddy to very opaque, with little head. Tastes of over-ripe banana, bread dough, scotch-whisky, oak, and leather. Palate starts very sweet and rich with a long and strong hot, scotch-whisky finish.

daaayaaaam... Wow, very very good.  Booze & barrel in the aroma...wants to be syrup, and man what a finish. Zero head on my sample, and it really reminds me of another favorite beer, Bourbon County Stout. Very malty, sweet, with a slight bitterness snuck in fo rgood measure. Very smooth, and I really think this beer will age for many years. This stuff has legs and coats your mouth leaving you wanting more. One of the best beers I have tasted this year. Tasted from the bottle at 60F.

On tap at the Sunset Grill in Boston. Brandy Barrel. Dark brown color - no head.  Chocolate and strong alcohol aroma - brandy. Complex flavors of ripe grapes and warming alcohol like chocolate covered cherries. Made for sipping slowly, and not too much at a time. Beer at a different level.

from crackedkettle.com; 2008 vintage - pours a dark brown colour with no head retention; stupendous and complex aroma showing woods, a fair amount of vanilla, plums and dark cherries; it develops notes of nuts and pine needles while getting warmer; thick and hugely malty, nice balance between sweetness and bitterness, low carbonation and quite sticky; very long bitter finish with lot of residual sugars, vanilla, chocolate, raisins and  robust warming alcohol notes - a mind-blowing, complex and robust contemplative brew

Bottle.  Pours a murky dark brown and pours flat.  Strong aroma of dark fruit and bourbon.  Flavor is complex.  Plums, bourbon, cherries, vanilla, caramel, etc. the list goes on,  Nice warming sensational, but not overpowering.  Good beer, but overpriced at $16.00 for 12.7 oz bottle.

Pours a deep brown with hints of crimson. Misted with a light skim that dissipates immediately. Heady and boozy aroma with dark chocolate cherry cordials. Oh! yummy... those cherry-filled chocolates bring a caramel companion to the tongue, again, boozy but in a good way, the balance is right. Big bodied and warming, quite unlike anything Ive had from this excellent brewery. This is like a Christmas holiday in my mouth. Ill admit I love this, though I feel I could only drink one every now and then. Just really, really rich.

Brandy barrel in the bottle.  From memory about two weeks prior.  Smooth vanilla and brandy aroma.  Plum, malt, dark fruit.  Much preferred to the bourbon that tends to take the beer over.  Pitch black and flat as water.  Taste more than compensates for the absence of carbonation as it is smooth with multiple intense, complimentary flavors.  High ABV barely noticeable.  Very drinkable and perfectly so in a small snifter-type glass.  Worth buying if you have access.

2008 bottle from stefanje via trade.  The pour was a hazy dark brown with almost no head to speak of.  The aroma was caramel, vanilla, smoke, coffee, chocolate and booze.  The flavor was mostly sweet, with the caramel and vanilla mixing with the booze.  A bit of the smoke and coffee came out at times.  The body was medium, the carbonation non-existent and the warming alcohol was very nice.  Decent.  Not earth shattering.

375mL bottle of 2009 vintage. Pours a very dark, dirty motor oil brown color with zero head or carbonation. Strong bourbon nose on the beer, mild toasted notes, light dark fruit and some light alcohol. Flavor is overrun with bourbon and oak flavors. There are some  mild chocolate and toasted malt notes in the middle with a light vanilla and dark fruit ending. Body is lighter, zero carbonation with a slightly dry, alcohol ending. Overall an interesting brew. The beer definitely gets better as it warms up as the flavors blend more smoothly. Still, I found the brew was just okay as the bourbon oak flavor was extremely strong and most of the characteristics of a beer are absent. I honestly think this is a prime example where price paid for the beer has influenced the rating, as no one wants to pay a high price for crud.

2008 Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with no head and minimal carbonation.  Aroma with presence-vanilla, caramel, and brandy.  Taste is amazing-lots of vanilla and caramel, a hint of coffee and brandy. The brandy is key here.  It has presence, but does not overwhelm and hits the palate subtly.  One of the best Ive had in a while.

Draught at 515.   Totally random find if you ask me.   I like this Norcal Lost Abbey distribution nonsense that is going on.   Served in a snifter with a brown looking body that has honey edges and a very scant head that leaves lasting beige foam.   The aroma is a total brown sugar, dried fruit (dates), oak, and brandy bomb.   The barrel treatment blends so well into the malt that you almost cant tell how heavily barrel-aged this beer is.   Its heavy.   The flavor is sweet and rich, but with enough alcohol and oak tannin to provide all the balance that you would want in a sipper of this magnitude.   Hops are buried.   There is a light chocolate donut touch to go with the brown sugar and oak.   Decadent and rounded.   Full and silky, with perhaps a little more carbonation than is optimal, but a little swirling remedies that easily.   A very nice barrel-aged barley wine, which is probably my favorite style to put in a spirit barrel.   Heavy on the brandy, but it just works in this case.

Rating #1000. 375ml bottle, 2009 Vintage. Pours a very deep brown, mostly black colored body with a reddish tint. Absolutely no head that leaves only a clear, oily lacing on the glass. Wow, this aroma is excellent. Abundant, complex, sweet, bold, and very soft. Tons of dates and figs, sweet fruits, extremely rich caramels, chocolate, buttered nuts, brown sugar, molasses, licorice, and smooth vanilla. Behind all that is sweet brandy, raisin and plummy bourbon, and a soft oak. A welcoming alcohol ever so slightly creeps in as well. Flavor is a bit more about the brandy, but still very nice. An alcohol heat sits on top of everything reminding me to take this one slowly. Personally, I think a couple years in the cellar would do this best, but I appreciate the soothing quality of the alcohol. It doesnt distract me from the rest of the flavors. Tons of rich molasses, figs, dates, caramel, and buttery nuts alongside pitted, dark fruits. The vanilla and wood comes out more in the flavor than the aroma and the chocolate falls back a bit. A light spice joins the soft wood and brandy as they grow towards the finish and help this slowly and delicately dry with a subtle, but present bitterness. Very lengthy aftertaste with a moderate alcohol warmth. Full, silky, oily, chewy, creamy body with a very light, syrupy carbonation. Very interesting palate with many different feels to it. Overall, I figured rating #1000 was as good a time as ever to open this one. Sure, its probably a little young as the flavor clearly has a rich, sweet brandy element to it, but this is extremely complex and well put together. I would love to try the past vintages. Great barrel work making for a very impressive beer.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2013 37.5cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. No readable date info.
Massive black colour with. Faint red hue. No head at all.
Aroma is massive notes of oak, caramel, molasses and of course alcohol. Flavour starts off bitter, but soon becomes very sweet
With notes of caramel, molasses, alcohol, wood and dark chocolate.
Long lingering aftertaste.

And just for reference, heres my old rating from 2010-05-05.
37.5cl bottle. Very Dark Brown, almost Black colour. Aroma is highly oaky and Laden with alcohol. Oxidized. Flavour is sour and oxidized. Dark red fruits and yeast. Too sour for my tastebuds. (5,5,5,2,12)

Had a sample tasting at Dark Lord Day -- big thanks to the folks in SF who brought this. Took a picture of the label and what I tasted (and am reviewing) is a smaller bottle - I think its 12.7 ounces -and says "Lost Abbey 2009" and below says "Malt beverage aged in oak barrels -- Angel Share Ale".  Dark brown almost black in appearance, with little head or carbonation present. Pleasant alcohol and brandy aroma along with some vanilla and oak. Intense flavor that just really blew me away. More pleasant brandy and alcohol flavors, along with dark fruits, vanilla, oak and roasted maltiness.  Little or no carbonation gives the beer more brandy-like qualities. Full bodied, thick and oily. My first experience with Angel Share -- this was a sheer delight to taste. Very much a sipping beer, Id rank this up with any barley wine or after dinner cordial.
bottle, muddy brown pour with caramel edges, no head, caramel, peat, molasses, aroma, flavors of licorice, toffee, fruit cake, flat coke, finish is like brandy

Muddy brown. Flat and watery with not head at all. The aroma has weak notes of oak, vanilla and sour apples. The flavour is very ... strange. Indeed, very strange. First there are earthy and oaky notes with some herbs as well. Then an unpleasant sourness sets in as if the beer has been infected. I dont know if its me who doesnt get it. But it more or less tastes like really bad cider. One of my worst beer experiences, since I had looked forward to tasting this one for over a year.

On tap at 515 in Santa Cruz. Ive tried most of Lost Abbeys rarer barrel program beers but this, one of the most common ones, has always eluded me. And even when I did see it in stores, I was wary of paying 30 bucks for probably flat beer. So obviously Im extremely excited to pay five bucks for a snifterful of the stuff. 
  
Nice deep mahogany color with a fluffy tan head that sticks around quite a while. Aroma is fantastic. Lush brandy notes, plenty of sweet toffee maltiness, vanilla, fruits, and a bit of spice. The flavor is out of this world. Raisins, molasses, pudding, chocolate, high-quality spirits, caramel, port. Thick and sweet, definitely a sipper meant to be enjoyed slowly. A little heat but not too much. Nice lasting finish.
  
For all the shit Lost Abbey gets over their carbonation problems, I felt that the level of CO2 in my force-carbonated glassful was far too high. It would have been completely suitable by any other beers standards, but that much carbonation in The Angels Share is TOO MUCH. After a period of swirling to kill off the excess, the result was simply incredible. This beer clearly CLEARLY benefits from lower carbonation.
  
Note to LA carbonation haters: Youre wrong. You are wrong. Your palate is wrong, your taste is wrong, your reviews are wrong, your indignation is wrong, your opinion. is. wrong.
  
Angels Share is right.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2010 April 28, 2010
Lost Abbey
The Angels Share
We have been really excited about this one. Pours dark brown with no head. Oily as hell. Strong aroma of bourbon, raisins, butter, brown sugar, and the kitchen sink. Maybe the best smelling beer yet. Flavor is strong port wine, bourbon, dark fruits, coffee nips and almost everything else. This is a huge beer. Warming finish, and better as it warmed up. Unbelievably good.  Holy Shit!

Pours a beautiful deep brown color dark and beautiful. The small tan head quickly dissipates slowly. Average lacing and surprisingly above average carbonation. Usually, barrel aged beers become flat. Not this beer. I appears o be bottle condition. Smell of strong bourbon and sweet roasted dark malts. Tastes of strong bourbon/whiskey, coffee, sweet roasted malts, coffee, and toffee. Complex and very tasty

2008 vintage 750ml bottle. There were posts about low carbonation in this batch and that you should let it age for a bit because its bottle conditioned. Well, I let it age for a year since I got it and its flat as a billiard table. Murky brown color. Bready aroma. Thankfully the flavor is still wonderful. Lots of vanilla and toasted coconuts. Slight roastiness to it. Aftertaste of black strap molasses. Ive got another bottle in the cellar. If it its any different than this one Ill update my rating. Ive knocked off points for Appearance and Overall due to the carbonation issue.

Appearance: Dark brown-ish black, no head (disappointing), and few bubbles  Smell: Brown sugar, molasses, and a touch of liquid black licorice.  Taste: Boozy.  I found the flavor profile heavy handed.  Maybe my bottle wasnt in its prime?  Mouthfeel: I found it to be surprisingly thin. I think this is where I was left most wanting for this beer. It just had so little body.  Drinkability: Perhaps not a spot-on sampling? I can only rate what I taste. Not my cup of tea. To the next one.

Trade with BrianJames1.  Now I will finally know what all thehype is about.  Gorgeous aroma of oak, dark ripe fruit, vanilla, chocolate, alcohol (almost medicinal, but it works here.)  The color is a dark, opaque burgundy color, very small head (I understand that has been an issue with this beer.)  The flavor is as beautiful as the aroma, oak, dark fruit, vanilla, again some cocoa (??).  The finish is sweet, alcohol warming in the throat.  Awesome thick, oily mouthfeel, but the beer is fairly flat, making it almost like a wine.  Still, an awesome beverage.  Thanks, Brian.

The strong aroma of brandy with notes of raisins. The appearance lacks almost any carbonation and there is no head at all. The sweet, malty, brandy flavor without any bubbles gives the beer a punch. But somehow it is a bit smooth for a barleywine.

2009 .375 bottle.Pours a dark and dull brown with NO HEAD.Nose is heavy brandy and alcohol with caramel.Taste is very much alcohol at first but changes to sweet brandy and caramel with very pronounced alcohol.The finish is very long as if it was a brandy or a cognac.I wish this beer had a bit more carbonation but its a very unique experience none the less.As this beer warms it improves drastically...

(Sample Date: 1/16/2010   Source:beerandit)   RRBG10 Bottle courtesy of beerandit. Brandy and wood in the aroma with a dark fruit an carmelized sugar background. Clear deep amber with no head. Sweet dark sugar  with a ton of alchhol. Very nice brandy finish with lots of carmelized sugars. Very Tasty.

On tap at Oggis Carmel Mtn. Ranch.  Really, really good.  They did NOT have the proper glassware so it was poured into a wine glass.  Dark cola brown with light tan head and lace.  Nose is rich sweetness and alcohol.  Nose is remarkably subtle compared to the first taste.  The first taste is like drinking a swig of brandy or bourbon, and I dont think this was a mis-labeled BA version.  The following drinks became a warm rich elixer of caramel and vanilla and bourbon.  Great smooth rich darkness followed by warm booziness.  Absolutely beautiful.

09, 375ml brandy, written on bottom edge of the bottom. slight pop of the cork, very dark pour with a small but complete head that fades quickly.  thick and syrypy in the glass with legs to make any port jealous. the nose has a good bit of heat, and lots of prunes, vanilla, oak, and the usual supporting cast of flavors. the flavor is much the same, with a bit more dry charred bitterness showing up, which is nice for balancing the sweetness. the body has a very light carbonation, it is there. very thick and oily on the back palate, with some hints of heat showing in a nice way. next to the grand cru which has more carbonation, i do think that this one suffers a bit from it, but is still acceptable for the style. but the grand cru blows this out of the water in a lot of ways.

2008 vintage bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Dark brown in colour and flat. Aromas are of hot brandy, heavy malts, stewed fruit and soy sauce. More heavy malt, sherry, cooked fruit, and cheap milk chocolate in the mouth. Weighty and hot on the palate. Not very impressive. The bourbon barrel version was vastly superior.

375mL. Pours black, very dark, pretty much no head, noticeable sediment. Cherry dominant aroma, bit of chocolate, tiny bit of malt. Cherry and chocolate rush on the tongue that slowly mellows. Medium body, low carbonation, slightly sticky texture, likes to hang on the tip of the tongue.

09 "Brandy". Pours still as the night. No sign of carbonation and absolutely no lacing. The color is a dark brown with deep red/ merlot hues. The aroma is heavy on chocolate, raisins, vanilla, caramel, oak and brandy. The alcohol stings my palate and is very present (More so than many other beers @ 11+ %).
Rating 1700!  Sampled at RBWG 2010!  Huge Wow this is amazing. The aroma and flavor are both awesome vanilla, apples, coconut, barrel, and so much more. Amazing stuff!

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2011 Tasted with DeDolleWaitor. Pours brown with a small beige head. Aroma is malt, heavy brandy, vineous. Flavour is heavy acidic, vinegar, lactobacillus, brandy undernead. This beer is infected. I must taste this again. The aroma is very nice, but it tastes like shit. 7-3-3-2-8 2.3

Update new bottle. 
Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, raisin plum, chocolate, oak and vanilla notes. Flavour is roasted malt, dark fruit, raisin, plum, chocolate, alcohol, light oak and vanilla notes.

Pours a prune purple with no hint of a head, flat. The aroma is of burnt coffee and tones of gain and chocolate. The tones are complex and even handed. The high alcohol is tempered with prunes, chocolate and a hand fruit sweetness. There is a nice warm vanilla finish which is very long lasting.

 There is a little underlying carbonation which keeps this from being too heavy on the tongue.

 The incredible depth and complexity of this well crafted beer is stunning. The tones from the Bourbon are not overwhelming as with less thought out beers that are over-exposed to the barrels. Well Done!

Vintage 2008 375ml Bottle.  Cork comes out of this one and you can immediately tell that it is completely flat, no gas vapor and no pop.  Has a deep mahogany color and a head like the headless horseman.  I love the nose on this beer which reminds me of grown up candy.  Tons of sugary brandy, aged wood, burnt brown sugar and a touch of vanilla.  Complex flavor profile with a huge malt base, raisins, prunes, caramel, vanilla beans and a bit of old leather.  Slightly heavy on the palate without a trace of carbonation which makes it a little too cloying and syrupy to get a perfect rating.  Ive had other vintages of this beer that were properly carbonated and they are among the best beers in existence. Finishes with a tiny bit of alcohol heat and a lingering note of damp wood. Definitely a one of kind and one of the more complex beers out there.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge. Very dark viscous body with no head. Lots of wood in the aroma, with some alcohol, dark fruit, and caramel. Very complex flavor...similar to the aroma, with some sweetness and alcohol burn. Thick body with no carbonation. Not as good as I had hoped.

2009 Bottle at the 2010 March Metro Detroit tasting. Poured a dark cloudy brown that was significantly lighter on the edge with no head. Aroma had notes of sweet grains (a bit burnt), caramel and alcohol. Flavor had a strong alcohol note with an underlying sweet grain and caramel touch. There was no carbonation, but I didnt think it really hurt the beer.

Had the 09 brandy barrel version of this at the 2010 Hard Liver Fest in Seattle last weekend. Colour... nearly black with no head.  Nose... redolent of brandy and brown sugar. Palate... very caramelly, sweet, coating, boozy with bitter edges and loads of creme brulee, toffee, oak, vanilla and butterscotch discs.

Draft- Chef Pauls Bavarian Lodge.  Had to get this one on tap.  Black pour, no head.  Aroma of sweet coconut, raisin, oak.  Extremely thick body.  Slow alcohol burn up-front, then comes cocoa, and a bitter chocolate finish.  Very unique- the cocoa is prevalent throughout, along with the syrupy thickness.  Surprisingly clean finish.  More raisin, port flavors.  Im a big fan of quads, as well as oak-aged beers, and this one was good, but just a bit over the top and too sweet and thick for me.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL. Went there today without even knowing that they tapped this one the day before. My lucky day! A very good experience overall. Bold all around. I think of this almost like a blend between the barrel aged barley wine and imperial stout styles. It came poured with a layer of dark brown cream head and the rest basically looked like sinister reddish black ink. Rich bourbon brandy on the nose. Big caramels and nutty almond malts everywhere. Also, a subtly sweet vanilla, and some dark pitted fruits. A great sipper here. Soothing alcohol is probably the best way I can describe it, but definitely rich, creamy, strong, but not at all hard to go down. Quite woody with a heavy bourbon/brandy presence in the flavors. The nutty caramels seem to stand out to me though. Grainy, roasted almonds with rich, bittersweet caramel. Balanced out with a fairly non-distinct earthy hop. Some darker fruits, not overly sweet dates. Finish of vanilla brandy. Loved this one.

375 ml bottle from Binnys (Orland Park, IL). 2010 release. Pours a very dark brown, a touch of ruby, opaque, with a small offwhite head that dies to a ring of bubbles clinging for life on the edges. Aromas are a combination of caramel and toffee malts, dark fruit raisin and plum, a touch of jam, wet oak, vanilla, Brandy is moderate, a fruity edge as opposed to bourbon, sweeter, a touch syrupy. A lot going on here, a touch of warming booziness. Initial is heavier end of medium bodied, coats well, a small carbonation that tickles the palate a bit. Starts with sweeter edged malt of caramel, toffee, biscuits, jam, syrupy maple, vanilla, wet oak, and dark fruit. The barrel becomes a bit more prominent, maple syrup and warming alcohol and vanilla. Fruitiness, jam and fruit cake, syrupy thickness takes on a bit. I enjoyed the bourbon more, this is a bit sweet for me but the flavors are full, stick to the palate well, touch of bitterness. The booziness is not bad, but the beer is just a little too sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 750mL bottle, 2008 vintage.  rated 3/21/2010.  6/3/7/3/15  Opaque, pitch black, with zero carbonation.  Smells like sweet bourbon and alcohol, a bit too sweet.  Taste has lots of alcohol and sweetness, pleasant but not great.  Too flat, its a real pity this didnt have any carbonation to it.  Should have used a carbonator cap or something.

375mL bottle, 2009 vintage.  Rated 5/23/2010.  8/4/7/4/15  Carbonation!  Not too much though.  A small pop when the bottle opens.  Aroma is sweet, with raisins, chocolate, and a bit too much alcohol.  Taste has sweet dark fruit, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Again, too much burn.  Finish has lots of bitter malt.

Flaske 0,75l spandert av  og delt med Skinnyviking under hyggelig besøk hos ham 19 Feb 10. 0 skum. Sort på farge. Aroma av rosiner. Vinøs konsistens. Sammensatt smak med plommer & svisker i forgrunnen. Langvarig syrlig og svakt bitter ettersmak.

Bottle, 2009 vintage.  So I had heard much about the carbonation issues with this years AS, but given how much I enjoyed the Bourbon AS, I figured what the heck.  Well, opening without so much as a pop, my AS experience didnt go all that well. Pours murky brown with no head whatsoever. Aroma of HUGE plum, dates, sherry, caramel and brown sugar.  Flavor matches aroma in intensity, then throws some alcohol on the finish to heat things up. Ill say it:  for this beer, with the weight of the flavors and the boozy sweetness, the lack of CO2 became a huge distraction.  It made an ordinarily powerful and delicious brew cloying, and ultimately difficult to drink more than a few ounces. I will eventually give this brew another shot, but this wont be forgotten.

375ml bottle of the 2008 flat edition. No pop upon removing the cork. Pours dark brown with no head at all even with a very hard pour. Aroma of brandy, toffee, alcohol dark fruit and wood. Flavor of alcohol, bitter dark roasted malt, chocolate and prune juice. Mouth feel is oily and muddy, the lack of carbonation really hurts it. Overall this is a good beer that needs to have some carbonation, but weve all heard that.

Draft at Teresas Next Door, Wayne, PA on 03/06/10.  Arrived at the table a deep mahogany color with absolutely no head.  A strong aroma of soy sauce, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, and oak.  Full-bodied and quite syrupy.  The flavor starts with plenty of caramel and dark chocolate and progresses to some licorice, roasted coffee, and a hint of soy sauce.  Molasses, plums, and raisins in the mix too.  A cloying, bittering finish with lots of oak and vanilla extract.  Very warming and heavy on the booze throughout.  Good stuff, but Id have to be in the right mood to drink another.

2009 bottle, thanks Ryan!

Pours a deep brown, looks like flat cola. Aroma us super complex! Oak, dark fruits, plums, figs, dates, vanilla, mollasses, brown sugar and booze. Flavour is very rich, the alcohol warms and actually tingled. The carb is super low but works well. Super complex but so enjoyable. There is a great sweet brown sugar vanilla finish that sticks and us wonderful. Amazing stuff!

So I opened a 2007 bottle a couple months ago and it was sour.  Horrible scene really until Eric sends me this 2009 bottle.  It was shared with a friend.  Pours opaque dark brown with a nice thin light tan head.  It lingers a little bit.  Aroma is dense and rich.  Dark fruits dominate.  Prune, fig, plum, booze, brown sugar.  I am smelling perfection in a glass.  Medium mouthfeel with the perfect amount of carbonation.  I have now had Angel Share beers that were overcarbonated.  Not carbonated.  This bottle is just right.  A little amount of carbonation makes this a near perfect creation.  Flavors follow the nose and finishes semi-sweet that is not cloying in any way.  Easily one of favorite beers of all time.  Thanks Eric again for sharing this gem.

2009 Bottle - Thanks JohnGalt!! - Pours almost still with practically no head, clear, dark garnet colored...aroma is amazing, vinous oak, sticky sweet old fruit, vanilla and raisin...flavour is more dry than the nose suggests, more dried fruit, toffee, some cocoa, terrific barrel presence, warming with the slightest carbonation...this was a tasty treat...

2009. Pours so deep a red as to be nearly black. No head... life goes on. Nose is oak and fruit, something like bourbon. W/ only the tiniest twinge of carbonation, this comes off very much like port wine and, indeed, those lovely oxidative nutty port notes are strongly present. Sticky sweet, thick and heavy on booze w/ load of vanilla. This is a special beer for special occasions. Well worth the price of admission.

2009 375 ml bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours brown/black with the tiniest ring of tan bubbles that dissipates fully.  Aroma is extremely sweet smelling, raisins, caramel, molasses, oak, and brandy.  Taste is very sweet and rich.  Smooth, kinda thin, mouthfeel with almost no carbonation.  Worth the price of admission for the aroma alone!

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2010 Draft at Uber Tavern.  Black pour with a small tan ring of bubbles.  Lovely aroma on this: very boozy, with raisins and other sticky dried fruit notes, sweet toffee and caramel, and quite a lot of vanilla.  This is pretty dominated by the barrel characteristics.  Flavor is sweet toffee, vanilla, a touch of anise, raisin/dried fruit, molasses, a hint of roasty coffee, and a lot of dry oak on the finish.  Has a full, rich, sticky body, and a fairly sizable kick of alcohol warmth.  Theres a little too much alcohol heat for my tastes, but it isnt entirely unpleasant with the big sweet flavors of this beer.  This is definitely something that needs to be slowly sipped.

Tiny coarse head. Opaque black body. Plummy roasty soy sauce aroma with sherry and chocolate notes. Dry-sweet plummy port and chocolate taste with alcoholic vanilla and paper notes. Mid-to-full body. Mild, soft mouthfeel, quite hot from the alcohol. Dry alcoholic vanilla and chocolate taste with port and nuts notes, as well as some wood. Good, but too oxidized and alcoholic. (0.75l bottle shared by kestral. 2008 vintage.)

2008 bottle.  Pours very dark brown, opaque, no head, and little lacing.  Sugar-cane, molasses, raisin, vanilla, wood, and some rich earthy aromas.  Full body, creamy, flat, and slightly crisp.  Deep, rich sweet flavors, earthy and oakey, a hint of citrus, warming alcohol notes, a long gentle finish.  Nicely balanced.  Reminiscent of a port, particularly with the lack of carbonation.  I look forward to re-rating the 2009 vintage.

2009 bottle from RiversideAK. Thanks Alex. This thing produced VERY little head. There were some bubbles, but not many. Nice dark brown color. Looks decent, but I wish there was some head on this. Nice wood-aged aroma. Some vanilla, sugar, wood, and sweet caramel malt coming through. Very pungent aroma. This is a very nice aroma, and quite nuanced. Wow, I dont understand the bitching about the 09 bottles. This thing is insanely delicious. Nice sweet bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar, and wood aroma are dancing on my taste buds. Nice sweet caramel malt flavor complimenting the afore mentioned flavors. Slightly boozy, but damn this thing is nice. No hops to speak of. This thing has the PERFECT amount of carbonation. I think this beer is ridiculously smooth. Perfect palate. The alcohol is cutting through in some bad ways, but still this is a VERY nice barley wine, and I am very happy I tried it when it wasnt fucked up.

(Bottle, 2009 vintage, at Pikkulintu) Poured almost black and almost clear with hardly any head. Aroma contained malts, alchohol and cognac. Palate was full bodied, burning and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were cognac, malts, raisin, sweetness and mild bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, sweet and mildly bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2010 Big bottle, kindly shared by Kestral. A thin layer of tan bubbles upon a cola colored, softly carbonated body. Massive aroma of caramelly dark malts, marzipan, wood,  and plum marmelade, or maybe extracted plum marmelade. Also a scent of alcohol. Taste is vinous. Port-like, with a strong and sweet malt body, an intense plummy fruitiness, and tones of English licorice, chocolate and vanilla. Prononced alcohol, feels thick and hot in the mouth. Fat body. Sweet malts lingers in the finish. Big and beautiful!

From Sun Devil Liquors in Mesa, AZ. Employee explained how this years (2008) batch had almost no carbonation, and ended up with a bit of extra sweetness. There was no noticeable carbonation. But still complex with lots of malt and caramel. Pretty sweet with a hint of maple, which works for someone like me from the north country.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2011 I can appreciate the high rating of this beer in its nose, complexity etc.  The taste just doesnt do it for me.  It pours dark dark brown with no head. It had a great nose, very strong  and complex( oak predominant with vanilla, dark fruit)  The taste wasnt to my liking.  A little too heavy on the oak and too boozy.   less enjoyable than I had hoped.  overall a well done beer, (great nose and mouthfeel) just the taste doesnt work for me.

2009 bottle thanks to a friend who brought it back from california for me.  poured a dark brownish amber with no signs of a head and some nice legs.  aroma was complex with bourbon, prunes, raisin, touch of licorice maybe, vanilla??, and some old oak.  flavor was bourbon, vanilla, caramel, dark fruits, what seemed like some brown sugar type flavor, dry oakish flavor, and maybe some pecan shell.  body was heavy with no signs of carbonation, but it kinda worked out for it.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, vintage 2008, 1 year oldIt pours a dark brown color, viscous and totally flat. The aroma is an interesting blend of caramel, vanilla, woody sourness, some alcohol. Good body strength, but the mouthfeel is quite spoiled by a strong alcohol presence (maybe the brandy barrel is not a good choice); caramel flavor, sweet, vinous, woody, with a touch of vanilla. In the final, the alcohol trace, although not strong, is disturbing.Something is appreciated (the vinous character in a Barley Wine), something is less appreciated (the alcohol).Confused.

A: The pour from the cork and caged bottle is a dark, dark brown color with some highlights and a ring of tan foam. There was indeed a nice pop upon opening the bottle, but not too much in the way of visible carbonation.

S: This is definitely not for the faint of heart. A rich, chocolatey aroma with lots of brandy notes and also a bit of oak and sugar.

T: The flavors follow the nose for the most part. The brandy is very prominent on the front end but quickly fades to a combination of chocolate, brown sugar, and a slight oakiness on the finish.

M: A low level of carbonation on the tongue, but it really lends the beer a silky and full feel on the tongue.

D: I want to keep drinking this, but I also dont want to fall on my face. A great strong ale in that it hides the alcoholic burn, but its present enough to remind you what youre drinking.

375 mL bottle of the 2009 vintage purchased at the brewery on release day in January 2010.  Yes, the 2009 has (some) carbonation.  Pours a dark brown.  Although it is quite effervescent coming out of the bottle (even making some noise), it produces no head.  Wonderful aroma of caramel, wood, maple syrup, chocolate, vanilla, and some (pleasant) booze/brandy.  Flavor is similarly wonderful and complex, containing much of the same as found in the nose with a great rich chocolate-ness coming forward more.  The finish has more rich fudge-like chocolate goodness along with a distinct booziness (just in case you werent sure you were drinking a great big beer).  Whatever carbonation was here seems to have escaped very quickly.  Though it seems to have become popular to rip on Lost Abbey over carbonation issues, it doesnt stop this from being a world-class beer along with its bourbon-barrel cousin.  How much carbonation do you need in a sipping beer this big and rich anyway?  But $15 for a 375 mL bottle is on the pricey side...
 (572, 233)

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2010 Nose of whiskey and chocolate.  Appears flat brown to black, no head, no carbonation, leaves no lace.  Sippin beer, almost as nice as a DogFish Head World Wide Imperial Stout, with about half the alcohol, which is tough to do and a big plus.  Mouth is rich and silky, then dead flat.  Carbonation is a good thing, especially in a beer this sweet.  Over all its a fantastic beer, but at the equivalent of $365 a case it had better be.  Lovely stuff, but not in the league of a Westvletern 12, a DFH WW Imperial, or a Deus ... those are all very different styles, but probably represent better value.  // Had two more bottles.  One had some carbonation.  Last one was, once again, dead flat.  Starting to get annoying.

375ml bottle from DK. Pours dark brown with zero head. Nose is big oak and whisky notes, really an amazing nose. Taste was a bit disappointing for me compared to the nose as it was overall very sour. Had nice malty notes, raisin, port. Overall a big disappointment for me.

Fortunately, ive had this on tap at the brewery but my recent experience was from a 2008 bottle that didnt have a bubble in it.  Ill rate it from my prior experiences.... Brandy and bourbon mixed with an intense blend of plum and raisin. Color is very dark. Im getting some toffee too. Caramelized sugar. Still very tasty.  Amazing with some carbonation...not nearly as good flat but still tasty...crazy

750ml Bottle thanks to scrizzz. Thanks! Pours dark, dark reddish brown, quite like coke, with a tiny ring of small brown bubbles. Aroma is almost salty soy like, with massive amounts of caramel, some liquorice, vanilla, plums, prunes, maple syrup, and alcohol. Nicely oxidized. Flavour is extremely big, just a barrage of flavours pelting the tongue. More chocolate than on the nose, and a lot more boozy than sniffing it gave away. The alcohol makes it quite raw in the finish. Thick bodied, damn near flat, but it works in an enormous, boozy beer like this, as its not very beer like in the first place. I would have liked it better if it was a bit less big, actually, a bit less boozy and with a bit more carbonation. Nevertheless, an impressive brew which I thoroughly enjoyed.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2016 2008 bottled. Pours deep amber-brown with virtually no head. Nose of roasted malts, raisins, vanilla and overriped fruits. Very Sweet flavour with caramel, brown sugar, roasted malt, oak, brandy and dark fruits.Full bodied. Ends up more dry with alcohol notes. No bitterness. A great Barley and a tasty sipper. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

I thought we were over the carbonation issues. Not really. A little bit of carbonation. But the taste does pack a wallop. Brandy and bourbon mixed with an intense blend of plum and raisin. Color is very dark. Im getting some toffee too. Caramelized sugar. Still very tasty.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2017 After two flat 08s and an infected 07, I finally hit pay dirt with a perfect 09 bottle. This is insanely good, rich and dark pour, very sweet in the 4th dementia vein, but with the added complexity of beautiful, smooth brandy and oak. I love it. The beer itself definitely holds it own against the superb Bourbon Barrel AS (which I gave a 4.4). And, while one might complain about quality control this beer, Tomme made it up to me big time, replacing the beer and then some. Thanks, Tomme, for the best customer service one could hope for. 


After a few more flat bottles, Im now enjoying a well-carbonated 8-year-old 2008 bottle. I knew I was in for a treat when I saw the puff upon opening the bottle. Yep,  absolutely amazing and totally deserving of the 4.4.

Draft at capones. Pours dark amber brown with no head and no carbonation. Lovely aroma of sweet brandy, caramel, toffee and notes of oak and some vanilla. Flavor was very sweet with caramel, raisins/figs, brandy, toffee slight vanilla with a sticky sweet warming finish.

On tap at the Sunset Grill ...Hazy ,deep brown pour.minimal beige head , no lace . Aroma is alcohol , roasted malt and dark fruit . Flavor is sweet caramel malt , vanilla ,wood ,raisin and alcohol . Smooth ,medium bodied , warming and delicious .
Rating #500.  2009 bottle.  Very dark brown-red pour with no carbonation or bubbles.  Boozy alcohol aroma, fruity brandy and bourbon.  Bourbon taste.  Smooth at first with a rough alcohol finish.

Appearance: 3/5
Dark brown liquid with just a small ring of foam at the edge of the glass, that didnt leave any lacing.

Smell: 8/10
Plums, dried fruit, milk, sour, nuts, wood. 

Taste: 8/10
Sweet, sour, dried fruit, wine, plums, berries with an alcoholic finish.

Mouthfeel: 5/5
Smooth and very nice mouthfeel. Medium body with a pucking feel to it. 

Comment:
A very interesting and complex beer. There where allot of different flavours both sour and sweet with a combo of different aromas. If this is a barley wine (never thought of it while tasting) I would say its more of an english style barley wine rather then the more hopped up varieties we usually get from the US. I think it would work great with cheese, preferable something tasty like a strong blue cheese and some sweet marmelade or similar. However it worked just great on its own.

2008 bottle. Dark muddy brown in color, no carbonation. The aroma is a nice malty, sweet, tofffee, drired fruits, and very nice.  The taste is sweet, malts, dried fruits, alcohol, figs, slight vanilla, and wood.  Very good beer.

Tasted from a 750 ml bottle from the 2008 vintage.

Appearance - Pours with no head whatsoever.  It is completely opaque and cloudy.  The color is almost black with a tint of red.

Aroma - Molasses and brown sugar malt are the first aromas that come to mind.  It is also slightly nutty due to some oxidation.  It smells a bit like a high alcohol zinfandel.  The brandy characteristics are truly coming through.

Taste - High in alcohol.  Burnt brown sugar, with a nice charred bitterness.  There is a very dried fruitiness, date or fig, that is faint but quickly wiped out by the high alcohol.  The nutiness comes through lightly as well.  I would rate this beer as having a high complexity.  Every drink I take, I am getting a new flavor.  Now, a musty earthiness is coming through as well.

Palate - This completely coats the palate with a full body, consistent of the high alcohol.  The feel is also very round, hitting and sticking with every part of the palate.  I have read a lot about people having problems with carbonation in this beer.  It does not pour a head, but on the palate, it feels like a beer.  Although the bubbles are very small and dissipate quickly, they are undoubtedly there.

Overall - This is very interesting, and not really like any other beer I have had.  I really enjoy it, and think it will continue to get better with even more bottle age.

On tap at Blue Palms.  Cant believe I havent entered my past ratings for this yet--wait, yes I can.  2009--listed at 12%--cloudy orange ruby with a small light beige head, and didnt take long too fade to nothing.  The only thing detracting in the nose is some pretty intense old scorched toffee/raisin sweetness.  Other than that, fantastic.  Lots of old barrels, leather, tobacco, and caramel toffee notes.  Some alcohol is present as well.  Thankfully the flavor isnt quite so diabetes-inducing.  The booze and barrel dries out the beer to make it taste nothing short of great, and seems a couple years old already.
